!

Used in the 2 times the square root of area formula, the exclamation point denotes a factorial. This formula becomes very complicated, if the factorial's argument is not an integer, which is likely to be the case when taking the square root of a random number (area).

$660.00/g

about $18,000 an ounce

'd been a confarmed...

I'd been a confirmed bowl-splatterer for years beyond counting. I'd been barred from the facilities at all the truck stops betwixt here and New York for years. The wallpaper in the loo at home hung in these curled sheets from the wall, I tell you. But now one day . . . I'll remember it always. It were a week to the day after I stood up for my ninety-day chip. I were three months sober. I were there on the throne at home, you know. Not to put too fine a point on it, I produced as usual and . . . and I were so amazed as to not believing my ears. It was a sound so unfamiliar at the first I thought I'd dropped my wallet in the loo, do you know? I thought I'd dropped me wallet in the loo as god is my witness. So down I bend betwixt my knees and had a look in the dim of the loo and couldn't believe my eyes. So good people I do then I drop to my knees by the loo and had a real look. A lover's look, do you know? And friends it were a lovely past my poor powers to say. It were a turd in the loo. A real turd . It were firm and tapered and ever so gently arched. It looked . . . constructed instead of sprayed. It look as I felt in my heart God himself made a turd to look. My friends, this turd of mine practically had a pulse. I stayed down on my knees and thanked my Higher Power, which I choose to call my Higher Power God, and I been thanking my Higher Power on my knees ever since, morning and nighttime and in the loo as well, ever since.

(4)

Notice that after listing points (a), (b), and (c) about clichés, Gately moves on to (4) rather than (d).

- way it can be film qua film--answering their phone

this next paragraph is most likely about the movie Infinite jest. Sounds like porn. DFW speaks on the coming of virtual reality porn in a few 1996 interviews. VR headsets and porn will be released at the end of 2015.

... the way W. Penn in his Quaker Oats hat in like the 16th century must have felt trading a few trinkets to babe-in-the-woods Natives for New Jersey...

William Penn (1644-1718) was the British-born founder of the colony (and later state) of Pennsylvania. For the hat, see right. Penn obviously lived later than the 16th century and he had no involvement in the founding of New Jersey, which Pemulis seems to be conflating with the purchase of Manhattan by the Dutch for about $24 worth of jewelry.

....somebody had taken an old disk of McCartney and Wings [...] and run it through a Kurtzweil remixer and removed every track on the songs except the tracks of poor old Mrs. Linda McCartney singing backup and playing tambourine

An alleged isolated vocal track of Linda McCartney singing along to "Hey Jude" at a concert did circulate, but the production itself may have been a hoax. Kurtzweil appears to be a misspelling of Kurzweil, referring to Ray Kurzweil, an inventor in audio and speech technologies, artificial intelligence, and futurist author. See [13] .

...a grotesquely huge woman whose hose bulged...

It's Helen Steeply.

...a mule, a burro...

A mule is a hybrid between a horse and a donkey (ass). A burro is just another name for a donkey.

...a regular verb, transitive...

In English, regular verbs end in -ed (or -d, for infinitives that end in -e) in the past simple or the past participle. An irregular verb does not follow this rule. For example, "implore," a regular verb, is "implored" in the past simple tense. "Fall," an irregular verb, becomes "fell" in the past simple tense.

...all three O.N.A.N. time zones...

Three is considerably fewer time zones than the five the U.S. (including Alaska and Hawaii) currently span, plus the Atlantic Time Zone, in which some of Canada can be found.

...an employee at the Academy of Tennis...

This would very likely be Poutrincourt (that's does not sound right: it says this person "joined the Canadian instructor")

...as if from the Rose Garden...

like the President of the U.S. answering a question from a reporter

...asks if they knew him...

"Alas, poor Yorick. I knew him, Horatio..." ( Hamlet ).

...bearing their shields rather than upon them...

Spartans were carried back on their shields when killed in battle.

...best of British luck to you...

From Brewer's Dictionary of Phrase & Fable comes this definition: 'Best of British Luck' — an ironic expression of encouragement, implying that the required luck may not materialize... an elaborated form of 'the best of luck.'

...Continental Controlled Substances Act of Y.T.M.P., O.N.A.N.D.E.A.'s hierarchy of analgesics/antipyretics/axiolytics...

There is no such act, obviously. Y.T.M.P. is Year of the Tucks Medicated Pad . The second acronym is Organization of North American Nations Drug Enforcement Agency. Analgesics are painkillers. Antipyretics are fever-reducing drugs, and anxiolytics are anxiety-reducing drugs.

...corruption of the French blesser,...

Blesser is French for "to injure or wound."

...darkness dance on the face of the deep...

a play on Genesis 1:2 And the earth was without form, and void; and darkness was upon the face of the deep. And the Spirit of God moved upon the face of the waters.

...digging some dead guy's head up...

See Hamlet, Act V, Scene i.

...Donald Gately and I dig up my father's head...

See Hamlet, Act Five, Scene One.

...each month's prime numbers...

Which would be the second, third, fifth, seventh, eleventh, thirteenth, seventeenth, nineteenth, twenty-third, twenty-ninth, and thirty-first (when the month has thirty-one days)

...etymology of the word blizzard...

While Hal believes the etymology is unknown, there is one offered here .

...go find a short pier...

and take a long walk, being the implication

...had the word Homo in the title...

The film is James O. Incandenza's Homo Duplex .

...his late great Da's...

Clearly Pemulis has no idea that his brother was molested by their father.

...Hobbes is just Rousseau in a dark mirror...

Thomas Hobbes (1588-1679) was a British philosopher and author of Leviathan . In it, he suggests that the only escape from living in a state of nature that is "solitary, nasty, brutish, and short" is to build societies. Jean-Jacques Rousseau (1712-1778) was the Swiss-French philosopher who wrote The Social Contract, in which he advances the same argument but idealizes the state of nature.

...ill-swallowed cocktail onion...

The editor choked on a cocktail onion.

...in a flaming L.A....

This would make the year 1992.

...intra-provincial crisis...

A crisis occurring within a province.

...isn't even iambic, much less quatrameter/trimeter...

This is to say that the poetry of Dickinson is not in iambic pentameter, also known as verse. This is the style of poetry Shakespeare is written in ("Now is the winter of our discontent") -- ten syllables, and five iambs (feet, or beats) per line (thus pentameter). Quatrameter/trimeter would be the rhythm scheme of "Yellow Rose of Texas" and "Mary Had a Little Lamb" (although note that the first foot of the latter is incomplete).

...it was in its last season of representing an American university...

Presumably under the constitution of O.N.A.N., Syracuse, N.Y., became part of Canada.

...launching even one ship or vessel.

unlike Helen of Troy, whose face "launched a thousand ships" according to Homer

...like a seahorse...

Seahorses actually have two eyes.

...like Roosevelt at Yalta...

a reference to the supposed bullying by Stalin of FDR at the conference at Yalta in 1945 to cede Eastern Europe to Soviet control

...look down her shirt and spell attic...

and thus saying, "A-T-T-I-C" or "a titty I see"

...one slim cat with an outsized leg...

i.e., Orin Incandenza

...only to be asked if his refrigerator's running...

Another ancient phone gag : Prankster: "Can you check to see if your refrigerator is running?" Dupe (after a pause to check): "Yes, it is." Prankster: "Well, you'd better go catch it!"

...part the veil of Maya..

This means to glimpse transcendental truth by parting the veil of Maya . Why Idris, a Muslim from Pakistan, would be aware of this Hindu reference is not explained

...play a game with a small beanbaggy ball...

a reference to hacky sack (or "hackey sack")

...Popsicle sticks and twine.

The passage in which Hal eats the mold is reproduced not quite verbatim from DFW's purportedly autobiographical 1991 Harper's Magazine essay "Tennis, Trigonometry, Tornadoes: A Midwestern Boyhood" p. 70.

...rosebud, his dark star...

his anus

...something whimpery instead of banging.

a reference to the last line of T.S. Eliot's poem The Hollow Men

...stereochemically not dissimilar...

similar, based on the spatial arrangement of atoms

...that skull fragment out of the Hamlet graveyard scene...

i.e., "infinite jest"

...the color of Thousand Island dressing...

the pastel salmon color resulting from mixing mayonnaise and tomato ketchup (among other ingredients, including pickle relish)

...the fat women in the Viking hat having sung...

Another way of saying, "It ain't over till the fat lady sings." This expression refers to opera, particularly those by Richard Wagner.

...the last thing Gately saw was an Oriental bearing down with the held square and he looked into the square and saw clearly a reflection of his own big square pale head with its eyes closing as the floor finally pounced.

See page 934: "He dreams he looks in a mirror and sees nothing and keeps trying to clean the mirror with his sleeve."

...the one about ultraviolence and sadism.

Gately is thinking of Stanley Kubrick's 1971 film "A Clockwork Orange."

...the thing it's not entirely impossible he may have fathered...

This is to say that C.T. may have been Mario's father and not James O. Incandenza. Given that C.T. and Avril are blood relatives, this would explain Mario's profound birth defects.

...to cyclize OH...

To cyclize something is to have it form rings. OH is the hydroxy radical .

...to smack, to scag, and to H...

all the same thing, being street names for heroin

...using just audio...

The implication here is that in the time of the book, there are videophones.

...what she's said for three years of midnights...

Up until 'Look at that fucker Dance,' the rest of her introduction is from Genesis 1 .

...when Luke removes his high-tech targeting helmet...

Hal is referring to a scene from Star Wars ; Luke is Luke Skywalker.

...who use whomsoever as a subject...

"Whosoever" would be the proper subjective form of this word. Hal is saying that the Deans, even with their limited grammatical abilities, would find the recent essays appalling.

...with a sword and a plowshare...

A plowshare is the blade of a plow; the reference is from Isaiah 2:4 ; they are symbols of war and peace, respectively. The syringe and soup-ladle mentioned in the carving could be symbols of similarly opposed addiction (or poison, but probably not medicine) and sustenance.

1,400,000 curies

A curie (Ci) is a measure of radioactivity, defined as 3.7×10 10 decays per second. The more commonly used measurement in science is the becquerel . 1.4 million curies is equal to 59.2 million gigabecquerels.

This is one-third of a revolution per minute. LPs go literally 100 times faster.

I.e., the 40-yard line on the football field. One hundred meters is slightly longer than the length of the field.

a "rodney" is a cigarette. 100 millimeters is a standard length of a "long" cigarette, and is roughly 4 inches long

128-256 Alphabetville

Because of his injury, Schacht was ranked in the lower 128 seeds in the tournament just after his hurt his knee. Alphabetville could refer to a ranking convention. A common 'Equal Point Score' guideline for when two or several players have the same Ranking point score decides the position according to the player with most tournament participation within four years, and if these conditions should apply with both or several players then the Ranking position is arranged alphabetically after the surname.

Redundant because "proof" is an expression of alcohol content. Doubling the alcohol percentage gives you proof, i.e., 2% alcohol is 4 proof.

30,0000

This must refer to the attendance for the game at Boston College's Alumni Stadium, which has a capacity of 44,500 (see page 293 for schedule). Nickerson Field at BU has a capacity of less than 10,000 people. BU also played at Rhode Island in Hal's first four weeks, but its field has a capacity of only 5,180.

32 mb²

this would, presumably, be 1024 megabytes, or 1 gigabyte. This is strange on many counts. First, a megabyte is normally denoted as MB, not mb. Lowercase 'm' commonly means 'milli' or one-thousandth and lowercase 'b' would refer to bits instead of bytes. Second, the superscript 2 on an indicator of units typically refers to a two-dimensional unit as in, for example, square feet. Why not just say 1GB?

5/4

A relatively rarely employed rhythmic meter in music with five quarter-notes per measure, famously heard in the Dave Brubeck Quartet's recording of Paul Desmond's "Take Five" and in Lalo Schrifin's "Theme from Mission: Impossible. " In usual practice, the jazzy rhythm actually has four beats per measure, the first two of which are half again as long as the others: long, long, short-short; long, long, short-short; and c.

82 Share

This refers to the Nielsen ratings of television audiences. Share is the percentage of the total number of televisions in use that are tuned to a particular program, and 82 is incredibly high. By comparison, the "Who Shot J.R.?" episode of CBS's primetime serial Dallas, first aired 21 November 1980, received a share of 76. (See the list of the most-watched United States primetime broadcasts here .)

90-yard punt

The record for a punt in both college and professional football is 99 yards. Presumably in each instance the punting team had the ball at its own 1 yard line and the punt, through the air and then with fortuitous bounces, came to rest in the opponent's end zone. Orins's punt is said to have traveled 90 yards in the air, which is a bit beyond the outer limits of what even a top pro can do on his best kicks.

Referring to the work of 20th century figurative painter Francis Bacon and his "screaming pope" paintings.

Orin's helmet is white because he hasn't been tackled.

a duet

possibly "O sink hernieder, Nacht der Liebe" ("O sink down, night of love") sung by the title lovers in Act Two of Wagner's Tristan und Isolde

A formula for the temporal relation...

To understand why Hal's insight is true, first take a look at the Trammel of Archimedes . Now imagine a system in which the two shuttles travel back and forth along their respective axes and flash each time they reach the ellipse before reversing direction. Both shuttles are confined to the ellipse, so that the shuttle on the major axis travels farther (and temporally longer) between its flashes than does its counterpart on the minor axis. There are two formulas for describing the ellipse, one for the major axis on the horizontal and the other for the major axis on the vertical.

a hundred m.'s

a little over 328 feet

a kind of idolotry of uniqueness

i.e., a worship of individuality

A la contraire

A French mistake: Should be au contraire (masculine)

a philosopher instead of a king

Although Plato stresses, in the Republic, that kings should be philosophers (and vice-versa), this is obviously rarely the case.

A Program of Attraction

AA refers to itself as this, meaning that it doesn't need to advertise.

a sepulchral Czech kid named Lendl

Sepulchral implies the grave and can mean "hollow;" syn. "cadaverous." The Czech kid is probably Ivan Lendl, although Lendl has not committed suicide.

a Type and a Symbol

These words are used by Mr. Hooper to describe the veil he wears in Nathaniel Hawthorne's story, "The Minister's Black Veil."

a combination of "a whole different kettle of fish" and "a horse of a different color."

In Dante's Inferno, the sign above Hell reads, "Abandon all hope, ye who enter here."

Abu Kamal is in eastern Syria, near the Iraqi border. As-Suwayda is also in Syria, near its border with Jordan. This is to say that Ingersoll is patrolling Syria's eastern frontier.

Acadian Zionism

Acadia is the traditional name for what is now (in part) eastern Québec. Zionism is used here as a synonym for nationalism, rather than with its specific Jewish connotations

an upward slope

To grow together; fuse.

accumulates; increases

of or pertaining to the process of natural growth

ace

a service winner in tennis, i.e., a legal serve that is not touched by the receiver, most commonly seen on the first service

acerbic

sharp or biting; acidic; sharp or biting

acerbity

acervulus-nosed

having blisters on the nose

Acetate

Rayon

Achilles' heel

This denotes a single weakness, taken from Greek mythology and the warrior Achilles, hero of the Iliad, who was made invincible to weapons by his mother dipping him in the river Styx. However, because he was held by his heel, he was vulnerable in this single place; Paris was able to kill Achilles by wounding him in the heel with an arrow.

Achilles' tendon

A tendon in the back of the leg, near the foot, named for the great Greek hero of the Trojan War. But Achilles was mortally wounded by Paris's poisoned arrow, not by a thorn, which instead figures prominently in Aesop's tale of Androcles and the Lion .

achondroplastic

having dwarfism as a result of a disorder of bone and cartilage

acne rosea

also known as rosacea

ACOAs

Adult Children of Alcoholics

ACOGs

ACOG is most commonly the American College of Obstetrics and Gynecology, but in this context it probably stands for Adult Children of Gamblers.

ACONAs

Adult Children of Narcotics Anonymous

ACROMEGALIC

suffering from acromegaly, a chronic disease characterized by enlarged bones of the extremities, face, and jaw, caused by excessive secretion of growth hormone by the pituitary gland

acronym

MASH stands for "Mobile Army Surgical Hospital."

acrostics

Dr. Rusk might be composing acrostic poems, in which the first letters of each line, read sequentially, spell a word or phrase or create a mnemonic device, but it's more likely that she's solving acrostic puzzles, in which the letters comprising a quotation (typically 180-225) are scrambled into a set of clued entries (most commonly 22-26), the first letters of which spell out the name of the author of the quotation and the work in which it appears.

Actaeon Complex

This is not a real psychiatric disorder. Actaeon was a figure from Greek mythology who fell in love with the goddess of the hunt, Artemis, only to anger her and then be changed into a deer, which was then hunted unto death — all of which perhaps suggests an underlying reluctance in the men to pursue Joelle because she might pursue them in return.

Actaeonizing

Reference to the story of Actaeon - "In the version that was offered by the Hellenistic poet Callimachus (Hymn v), which has become the standard setting, Artemis was bathing in the woods when the hunter Actaeon stumbled across her, thus seeing her naked. He stopped and stared, amazed at her ravishing beauty. Once seen, Actaeon was punished by Artemis: she forbade him speech — if he tried to speak, he would be changed into a stag — for the unlucky profanation of her virginity's mystery. Upon hearing the call of his hunting party, he cried out to them and immediately was changed into a stag. His own hounds then turned upon him and tore him to pieces, not recognizing him." ( Wikipedia )

actaeonizing

a neologism in reference to Actaeon, a young hunter in Greek Mythology who looked upon Artemis bathing, who turned him into a stag; he was then killed by his own hunting dogs

actinomycete-class antibiotics

antibiotics effective against Gram-positive bacteria called actinobacteria

Acton

town in Massachusetts about 25 miles west-northwest of Boston

Actors' Guild

a reference to the Screen Actors Guild

actuating

putting into action

acuity

acuteness of perception

acutance

the edge contrast of an image. Hal appears to be correct insofar as contrast is more or less the same as resolution. Acutance is related to a pulse's slope and height. http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Acutance

ad

a tennis term meaning "advantage" for one or the other player

ad court

service box, left box on the player's own side where odd points are played

ad service box

the box to serve into when an odd number of points have been played (so when one player or the other has the advantage, i.e. is ahead in points); as opposed to the "deuce service box" where one serves when an even number of points have been played (in particular when the game is tied at deuce).

ad-in

indicates that the server has the advantage, meaning that after a previous deuce (40-40) the server only needs on more point to win. otherwise, the score returns to 40-40 (see the note for deuce on page 653)

Addis Ababa

the capital of Ethiopia

adenoidal

sounding as if the nose were pinched due to enlarged lymphatic tissue in the throat behind the uvula

adepts

expert players

adipose

adipose tissue, i.e., fat

adit

entrance or passage

Adriatic

the sea between the west coast of Italy and the Balkan peninsula

ads

i.e., advantages

adtorsion

turning inward of both eyes

adulterant

an impurity

Advent

the four Sundays preceding Christmas; the month-long period before Christmas

Advertable

best guess is this is a neologism combining "advertisement" and "avertable"

advertorial

Normally this word denotes an advertisement written to appear as if it's journalism, but here Wallace seems to mean bearing an ad.

aegis

sponsorship or auspices; from the Greek for "shield"

aerodyne

a heavier-than-air aircraft deriving lift from motion

Aetna

a real insurance company

affable

showing warmth and friendliness

afflatus

inspiration; a divine imparting of knowledge or power

afghan

a type of blanket

Agamemnon and Helen

Steeply has this one wrong.

aggregate

total, e.g., the aggregate IQ of the people in a room would be all their individual IQs added together

agnate

Paternal, related on the father's side. In this case agnate seems to mean that the shadows come from the same source, the setting sun.; Maybe he means "argot" (rather than "related paternally")?

agora

a place of congregation, originally marketplaces in Ancient Greece

agora-compulsive

addicted to the market (shopping)? or doesn't want to leave the home, i.e., compulsively agoraphobic

agoraphobic

suffering from an irrational fear of going outside

Ahts of Vancouver

another name for the Nuu-chah-nulth, the indigenous peoples of Vancouver Island, Canada

aide-de-camp

assistant to a general or other high-ranking officer

aides de camp

confidential assistants to a military officer

Aigner accessory

Etienne Aigner is a designer of women's handbags & leather goods.

Aigners

a Parisian brand of fine shoes (as here) as well as handbags and other leather accessories

aigrette

decorative feather or plume

ailanthus

a common form of urban plant

aile

aisle

Ainsi

French: so to speak

Air Force One

technically, any United States Air Force aircraft carrying the President of the U.S.

Air Force Two

the designation of any aircraft carrying the Vice President of the United States

airbus

a short- or medium-range passenger aircraft

akido

Lenz means aikido .

akimbo

with hands on hips

Akron

a city in Ohio and rubber capital of the world

alacrity

willingness; quickness; eagerness

Alan Watts

Alan Wilson Watts (1915-1973) was a British-born philosopher and writer in the field of comparative religion.

AlaTeens

a support group for teenage children of alcoholics

albatross

a burden, literally a large seabird, from Samuel Taylor Coleridge's poem The Rime of the Ancient Mariner

Albertan

From Alberta.

Albertan champagne

an oxymoron — champagne comes only from the Champagne region of France

Albertan ultra-rightists

There is a tradition of separatism in Alberta.

Alda

a reference to M*A*S*H star Alan Alda

aleatory

Of or pertaining to accidental causes.

Aleutians

an archipelago of Islands stretching west from the coast of Alaska toward (and over) the International Date Line

Alexandrian

Referring to the reign of the Byzantine emperor Alexander who ruled from 879-913 c.e.

alfresco

Al fresco in Italian means "outside."; outside

ALGOL

an ancient computer programming language

all of Vienna

implying all psychoanalysts, or at least all adherents of Sigmund Freud and Carl Jung

All was calm. All was bright

seems like a reference to the lyrics of Silent Night: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Silent_Night#Lyrics

allay

put to rest

Allen to Allen

a reference to American director Woody Allen (born 1935 as Allen Stewart Königsberg), who casts himself in many of his films

Allston

A part of Boston proper, west of downtown and across the Charles river from Cambridge. The fictional Enfield most likely occupies part of what is in reality Allston.

allude

here used to mean "give an impression of"

almometer

i.e., Alma Mater

alms

charity

alpaca

wool taken from an animal closely related to the camel and llama

alpenstock

a metal-tipped staff used by mountaineers

Alsace

a region of France bordering the Rhine border with Germany

Altman

Robert Bernard Altman (1925-2006) was an American filmmaker noted for his use of ensemble casts, multiple plotlines and overlapping dialogue. His major films include Nashville (1975), The Player (1992) and Short Cuts (1993). The TV series M*A*S*H, frequently referenced in Infinite Jest, is based on his groundbreaking 1970 film.

alto

having a lower female voice

altruistic

tending to do good things for their own sakes

Amalfo

apparently a misspelling of Amalfi, a brand of shoes

Amanita muscaria, a.k.a. the fly agaric mushroom

a poisonous and psychoactive fungus, usually red with white spots. It was used as an entheogen in Siberia. It has also been proposed that this is the "Soma" of the Rig Veda . ( Wikipedia )

amanuensis

someone who writes from dictation

amanuensis-cum-operative

The professional conversationalist is saying that Luria P----- is both an amanuensis--a secretary who takes dictation--and a secret agent.

amanuentic

secretarial

ambient

of or pertaining to the surrounding environment

ambit

sphere of operation or influence

ambulatory

able to walk

Ambush

a real perfume

American Council of Disseminators of Cable

Look at the first letters of the capitalized words.

American Falls

the American part of Niagara Falls

American Twist

another name for a kick serve

Amherst

Jeffery Amherst, 1st Baron Amherst (1717-1797), was a British field marshal and veteran of the French and Indian Wars. Town in Massachusetts named after him also gave its name to Wallace's alma mater. The story of Lord Jeffery Amherst discussing coating blankets with smallpox and distributing them to Native Americans is well-known at Amherst College.

aminating

introducing an amino acid into something

AMNAT

The United States of America and other NATO nations

amniotic

pertaining to the fluid that surrounds a fetus in utero; taking place in utero

among the very cream

as in, among the cream of the crop, or among the very best.

amperage

strength of electric current

Ample make this bed

The full poem is here .

Amway

the American-based international direct-sales retailer

an ascot or a very fey tie

An ascot is a scarf or tie with broad ends typically worn for formal occasions [5] . If the tie very fey, it is excessively refined [6] or fancy to the point that it could be confused with an ascot.

an old-fashioned one-sharp-sided razor blade

still manufactured but perhaps more commonly used in certain kinds of box-cutters than in razors (see right)

anaclitic

in psychology, dependence on other people or another person

anaerobic

thriving without oxygen

anal rage

He's probably referring to anal-retentive rage, rather than rage specifically located in the anus.

anality

anal-retentiveness

anamorphic

see here for a discussion of the cinematography technique

anamorphosized

changed from one form to another as a step in evolution; in optics, an anamorphic lens changes the shape of an image

anapestic

In poetry, an anapest is a trisyllable metrical foot of the following pattern: two unstressed syllables, followed by one long or stressed syllable. (Eg the line "'Twas the night before Christ mas, and all through the house " contains four anapestic feet.)

anaplastic

Adjective meaning either relating to the surgical restoration of a lost or absent part or relating to or characterized by cells that have become less differentiated/primitive.

anathematic

likely to be greatly hated

Anbesol

a brand name of benzocaine used for tooth pain

ancipitals

double-edged

and c.

Et cetera or etc. is Latin for "and other things." Here Wallace has translated et and left c untranslated.; et cetera

And Lo

a reference to the opening of the M.P. radio show

And one particular guy with snakes in a tank in a trailer in Allston

Tommy Doocey or Bruce Green (Page 39)

andante

in music, this word indicates a moderately slow tempo

Andover

as in Philips Academy Andover, alma mater of both Presidents Bush

anechoic vestry

Anechoic means "characterized by a low level of reverberation;" a vestry is where the priests' vestments (clothing for mass) are kept between ceremonies.

ANEURISM

a misspelling of "aneurysm," it's a bursting of a weak blood vessel, if in the brain, usually causing a stroke

anfractuous

full of twists and turns

Angenieux

a company that produces high-technology optics devices

Anglophone

English-speaking

anhedonia

inability to feel pleasure

anileated

annihilated

annular

see annulus - still the same meaning "ringlike". The inguinal ring is annular and at either end of the Inguinal canal where sperm is made.

annulation

The formation of rings.; forming rings. Possibly a metaphor for having children. Robinson annulation is used to make cortisone. Himself most likely had cortisone shots in his knees after his fall.

anodized

coated with metal

anomaly

something like nothing else (i.e., an outlier)

anomic

absence of the social, cultural, or ethical standards typical in a given individual or group, (here, a possible malapropism for "anemic")

anorak

a hooded pullover jacket

Anschluss

German for "annexation," it most often refers to Nazi Germany's annexation of Austria in 1938.

antagonists

a drug that acts against an agonist, i.e., a drug that stimulates a certain receptor

antebellum

before the war, here the U.S. Civil War

antenna

Referring here to the portable phone's antenna.

Anthracite

a type of coal

anthracnose

another name for the plant disease known as canker that usually has no cure.

anti-Capital activists

I.e., against the death penalty

anti-Picaresque narrative statis

This is one―or a small part of one―of Molly's pseudoscholarly (not to say "Rube-Goldbergesque") tropes. A picaresque work is the satirical, episodic story of a roguish hero (or antihero) of low birth and behavior that borders on the criminal (see here for examples of picaresque novels, including Don Quixote, Tom Jones, and Huckleberry Finn ). The phrase here may imply a storytelling technique at odds with the picaresque literary style (i.e., not a first-person narrative or not told from the protagonist's point of view; not without plot; not static in terms of the [anti-]hero's character development; not satirical; etc.). Also, of course, see Endnote 331.

anti-sclerotic

tending to ward of hardening of tissues (as of arteries, here)

anticonfluential

against things coming together

antidote

Orin means "anecdote."

antinomically

in a manner suggesting opposition of laws

antipyretic

designed to combat fever

Antitoi

French for "against you"

Antonioni

Michelangelo Antonioni (1912-2007) was an Italian filmmaker probably most famous for Blowup .

Antron

a real company

aperture

An aperture is an opening through which light travels. A tight aperture means better focus.; a small opening

aperçu

an insight

aphasia

speechlessness

aphasiac

inability to speak

aphonia

loss of or inability to speak due to damage to or disease of the larynx

aphotic to apochromatic

Aphotic means without light, while apochromatic means not altering the colour of the light passing through it.

aphrasiac

the inability to speak words in intelligible order

aplomb

self-assurance

apnea

the tendency of mainly overweight people to stop breathing intermittently in their sleep

apneated

as if punctuated by temporary cessations of breathing

apocopes

losses of syllables from words, particularly unstressed vowels

Apologia

An Apologia is a defense of one's beliefs, religious or other. Here, Barry is out of his league in his ability to put up a good defense of the religious beliefs that may help get his brother out of his own spiritual funk.

apoplectic

Overcome with anger; extremely indignant, so much so that it could induce a stroke

apostrophe

direct address of an absent person, in rhetoric

apothegm

a short, pithy statement

apotheosis

the process of being raised to godlike status

apotheosizing

apotheosis is the glorifying of someone to a divine level

apotropaic barn-signs

Hex signs commonly seen in Pennsylvania Dutch Country, ostensibly intended to ward off evil, but now probably used more as a decorative element

appalled

dismayed

apparition

a ghost, but here referring to Mario

appetitive will

That part of the will that desires physical things.

Appian Way

an ancient Roman road

appointments

furnishings

apposite

suitable or well adapted; pertinent; appropriate; appropriate with regard to the current circumstances

apprised

informed; informed

Approception

apparently not a real test

appropriation

taking something as one's own, without permission

appurtenances

equipment, e.g., clothing, tools, or instruments, used for a specific purpose or style of living; accessories or equipment

après-garde

French for "rear guard," it's the opposite of avant-garde.

aqua-line nose

an aquiline nose

Arabian Sea

the part of the Indian into which the Persian Gulf (or Arabian Gulf) leads

arachnodactylic

having fingers like spiders

arational

not irrational, but also not rational -- rather lacking the ability to tell one from the other

arbitrage

simultaneous purchase and sale of the same assets in different markets

argot

slang; slang, jargon

Arias and Krickstein

James ("Jimmy") Arias (born 1964) was a former American pro tennis player. Aaron Krickstein (born 1967) is also a former American tennis player.

armamentarium

an arsenal, particularly used by physicians to refer to drugs or treatments

Armenian Foundation Library in horrid central Watertown MA

This is probably the same as the Armenian Library and Museum of America . Watertown is a suburb of Boston nine miles west of the city, and it has a very large Armenian population.

ARPA-NET

The Advanced Research Projects Agency Network, development by the U.S. Dept. of Defense, was a forerunner of the Internet.

arpeggio

in music, a chord played in parts (i.e., one note at a time) rather than together

art-gesture films

apparently a created genre

artistic influenza

not actually one of Bloom's concepts

ascapartic

A word coined by Wallace, it means gigantic, as Ascapart was a giant depicted in the fiction of, among other people, J.R.R. Tolkien.

a volcanic island off the coast of Africa

ascot

a neck scarf

asexual

not sexually active or not attracted to either sex

Ashland KY

a city on the Ohio River about 120 miles south of Columbus, Ohio

Asian subcontinent

Better known as the Indian subcontinent, it includes India, Pakistan, and Bangladesh.

aspersion

a disparaging remark

asphyxuated

There's no clear reason for Orin's mispronunciation of asphyxiated . Perhaps he's combining asphyxia and evacuated .

aspic

meat jelly

aspirating

inhaling

assassination

Obviously President Limbaugh was assassinated in the recent past.

Assiduous

showing great care and perseverance.

assignation

a meeting between lovers; tryst

assuasive

soothing, calming

astigmatic

failing to have light rays converge on a single point

astringent

a chemical that tends to dry something else out; here it probably means "severe, austere, stern" (OED); a substance or preparation, such as alum, that draws together or constricts body tissues and is effective in stopping the flow of blood or other secretions

astrolabes

a type of navigational device used before the invention of the sextant

at bay

subdued and remaining at a distance

atavistic

relating to or characterized by reversion to something ancient or ancestral.

atavistically

Atavism means reversion to an earlier evolutionary type; i.e., Hal's complexion resembles his grandparents or earlier ancestors more than his parents

athe[-]ling

Anglo-Saxon prince or royal heir

athwart

side by side with

atrophic

shrinking in size

attar

attendant

old terminology for Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder or ADHD. Hal's objective symptoms describe the Inattentive Type.

reduced; weakened, also pertaining to the propagation of waves in telecommunications

attenuates

lessens

The wearing down of the enemy's strength and morale by unremitting harassment. "War of attrition" (OED)

Austin, Jaeger, Graff, Sawamatsu

Tracy Ann Austin Holt (born 1962) was an American tennis player who won Wimbledon in 1979 and 1981. Andrea Jaeger (born 1965) was an American tennis player who is now an Anglican nun. Stefanie Maria Graf (born 1969) is a German former tennis player with twenty-one Grand slam titles. Naoko Sawamatsu (born 1973) was a Japanese tennis player who retired in 1988

castration of one's self

autolysis

perhaps used here in the sense of digestion, although the term actually refers to self-digestion, the destruction of a cell through the action of its own enzymes

autolyzed

the seven Regional Bell Operating Companies (RBOCs) that came out of the Bell System divestiture, a result of the outcome of an antitrust lawsuit (1974) against the monopolistic AT&T

This is a real hotel, with a Web site here .

bagmen

people who collect payments in organized crime

baguette

a long roll of French bread

Bainbridge

This isn't even close to Steeply's name.

baking soda

Joelle is making crack, as opposed to 'freebase cocaine' which requires ether. Crack production is procedurally distinct (and safer) from that of purer 'freebase cocaine,' but the freebase products are the same: the baking soda serves to free the cocaine base from the pure cocaine hydrochloride. Both methods produce crystals that can be smoked. The production method of Joelle's earlier "home made freebase cocaine" is uncertain, but conventional terminology suggests she makes the ether-based variety at home.

baklava

a Near Eastern dessert made from filo dough, honey, nuts, and spices

Balaclavan

a reference to Balaklava, Ukraine, and the suicidal Charge of the Light Brigade

ballast

meaning an electric ballast, which is used to regulate and stabilize the current in lights; heavy material placed on the bottom of ships to provide balance and stability

ballism

another name for hemiballismus

ballyhooed

advertised in a sensationalist manner

banal

hackneyed or trite

bandanna

a large printed handkerchief, typically red or blue with a white design

Banfis

expensive Italian shoes

banks

makes something (here, the spoon) glance off a surfaces (or more than one; here, the insides of her cheeks)

banshee

In Irish mythology, the banshee is female spirit, who acts as an omen of death. They are known for "keening," i.e., shrieking.

Banzai!

a Japanese battle cry

Baobab tree

a tree native to Africa and India

Baraka

Imamu Amiri Baraka (born Everett LeRoi Jones, 1934) is an African-American poet, playwright, author, and political activist.

Barbicide

a brand name of disinfectant used for combs and hairbrushes

barney

a heavy padded cover for a camera to reduce the amount of noise from the camera's moving parts getting onto the soundtrack

barnwood

This word refers to "aged and weathered boards, esp. those salvaged from dismantled barns" ( Random House Unabridged Dictionary ).

baroque

extravagantly ornate; of, relating to, or having the characteristics of a style of artistic expression prevalent especially in the 17th century that is marked generally by use of complex forms, bold ornamentation, and the juxtaposition of contrasting elements often conveying a sense of drama, movement, and tension (Source: Merriam-Webster ); bizarre or complex

baroquoco

This would seem to be a mix between "baroque" and "rococo" .

Basel

a city of Switzerland about 50 miles north of the capital of Bern

baseline

the line at the end of a tennis court, parallel to the net, that marks the boundary of play

Basilar

related to or situated at the base, especially the base of the skull (as with the basilar artery); capitalization could suggest a fictitious branding, perhaps a competitor of Otis

basilar-stem artery

a stem of an artery that carries blood to the brain

basilisk-breathed and pyorrheic

A basilisk is a type of dragon, and pyorrhea is the condition of having gum disease.

Basin

A natural depression in the earth. Used often in geological and anthropological contexts.

Basque

The Basque language, spoken in part of northern Spain and southwestern France, is unrelated to any other European language and possibly any other living language.

bassinet

an oblong basket for a baby

basso

having a very low voice

bathetic

appealing to bathos, i.e., insincere pathos (emotion)

batorial ammonia

Thrust must mean bacterial pneumonia

baud

a unit equal to bits per second; a baud rate is the number of bits per second a modem can send/receive; a unit of one bit per second in data transmission; see Wiki for page 60, where this paragraph appears almost word-for-word.

Bauhaus

short term for Staatliches Bauhaus, a design school in Germany during the Weimar period that gave rise to a particular form and style

Bavarian

Originating from Bavaria.

bayou

a marshy arm of a lake

Bazin

André Bazin (1918-1958) was a French film theorist and director.; André Bazin (1918– 1958) was an influential French film critic and film theorist.

a downward-moving stock market (characterized by more selling than buying)

being...buggered

Belfast

the capital of Northern Ireland

Belfast Bobbie

This is an oxymoron. 'Bobby' is an English slang term for a policeman (after Robert Peel ), but the armed Northern Ireland police force (the Royal Ulster Constabulary ) were never known as 'Bobbies'.

bell curve

the curve formed by the normal distribution of IQs -- a concept fraught with problems of political correctness, racism or racialism, and different concepts of what "intelligence" is

bell-jar

a type of laboratory glassware -- also the title of a novel by Sylvia Plath

bell-lap

a term from track, this is the final lap of a race

Bell-shaped steatopygiacs

A steatopygiac is a person suffering from steatopygia ; if you're bell-shaped, it just means the fat is closer to the bottom than the top

rang like a bell

bellicosity

a warlike disposition

Bellow's Falls VT

Here meaning "smoothed out" and misspelled, beveling is the making of 45º angles where perpendiculars meet.

Big Red Soda Water

a real brand similar to cream soda, only red. This was originally only sold in Central/South Texas and Kentucky and is still popular in that region, though available elsewhere.

having two sides

the compound that makes urine yellow

blue and white Quenucker flag

A blend word derived from "Quebec" and "Nuck" (offensive for Canadian, and seen throughout I.J.). The flag here is the Quebec flag, as seen to the right

Blue Flames

probably some sort of depressants

blue neon

In fact, neon has a distinctive orange-red color when electrically charged; this "blue neon" is probably argon with some mercury, as shown in the Wikipedia entry for Noble gas (see the section on "Discharge Color").

good-natured and direct in speech or behavior

Bob Hope

Cockney rhyming slang for "dope"

bodegas

small grocery stores, usually in Spanish-speaking neighborhoods that are also usually owned and operated by Spanish-speaking people

bodychecks

a term used in sports, esp. ice hockey, meaning to impede another's motion with one's body

bogey

something that annoys or frightens

boilermakers

shots of whiskey chased with beer

boilerplate

standard text entered identically, as into contracts

bolections

mouldings that cover joints

Bolex

a Swiss camera manufacturer

bolt of death

i.e., a deadbolt lock

bonded

Sorkin had put up Gately's bail.

bone of dissension

Orin means "bone of contention."

bonerfied

bona fide

bonhommic

a neologism meaning "good-hearted"

boniface

an innkeeper

Bonwit's

a department store in Boston; a reference to the now-defunct upscale department store Bonwit Teller

book

probably stemming from the gambling phrase "make book on," meaning to make or accept bets on; so, "odds-on" or "most likely"

book-long

The "book" length of a punt is not the same as its physical distance. Hal kicked the "baptismal competitive punt" 90 yards in the air, but was only credited with a 40-yard punt. Because the line of scrimmage was Syracuse's 40, and Hal kicked the ball through the end zone, the punt is recorded as 40 yards (the distance from the line of scrimmage to the end zone). The ball would be placed at Syracuse's 20, so the "net" on the punt would only have been 20 yards.

booming lowering

play on the phrase "lower the boom on" which means lay down severe punishment

Boosters

members of a booster club

boosting

stealing

boot

junkie slang for injecting drugs

boot-knife

defined here

booted

injected

Booty

treasure taken from a defeated party

Borderline

suffering from Borderline Personality Disorder

boric acid

Also used as a detergent and a barrier against insects.

boscages

masses of trees or shrubs

Boston's Roxbury and Mattapan districts

two lower-income, primarily African American and Hispanic neighborhoods in Boston

bosun

slang sailor term for a boatswain

Boswell

James Boswell, 9th Laird of Auchinleck (1740-1795), was the Scottish biographer of Samuel Johnson.

both H'sseins

Hussein I (1935-1999), king of Jordan, and Saddam Hussein (1937-2006), president of Iraq

botulizing

infecting with botulism

boudoir

a bedroom or private sitting room

Bouvier

Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis 's maiden surname

bovine

like a cow

Bow&Arrow

a reference to the Bow and Arrow Pub at 1 Bow Street. Closed in 2000 due to a building renovation and the rent being raised.

bow-biters

1980's plastic clips that help keep shoe laces tied

BPL

Boston Public Library

brachiform

in the shape of an arm

Brachistochrone

a reference to a brachistochrone curve

bradyauxetic

slow in cell development

bradykinetic

Describing abnormally slow movement.; slow moving

bradyphrenic

slow witted

bradypnea-afflicted

afflicted with an abnormally slow breathing rate

Brag's-Diseased

This would seem to be a type of glioma, though it is mentioned almost nowhere.

Braintree

a town in Massachusetts about 13 miles south-southeast of Boston

brambled

beaten with thorns

Brandeis

Brandeis is a Jewish-founded university in Waltham, Mass., about nine miles west of Boston, named for Louis Dembitz Brandeis (1856-1941) the first Jewish Supreme Court justice.

Brandt

Another German name, most famously the nom de guerre of the future mayor of West Berlin and Kanzler of Germany, Willy Brandt, born Herbert Ernst Karl Frahm (1913-1922).

brandykinetic

with slowed movements due to neurologic dysfunction

brang

Stice's solecism for "brought"

Brattleboro

a town in Vermont about 75 miles west of Manchester, N.H.

bratwursts

This is a small German sausage composed of pork and beef; the name is German for "chopped meat sausage."

Brazilian Nuevo Contras

These would be "new" contras, the old ones having been U.S.-funded anti-communist guerrillas in Nicaragua in the 1980s. Note, though, that Nuevo being a Spanish word would not be a likely name for a Brazilian group (where Brazilian Portuguese is spoken).

Bread & Circus

a small chain of health-food stores that first opened in Brookline, MA, in 1975 and acquired by Whole Foods Market in 1992

Bread & Circus in Inman Square

a real health food store on Prospect Street in Cambridge between Central and Inman Squares. The Bread & Circus chain was bought by Whole Foods, so this store is now operating as a Whole Foods.

Brecht

Eugen Berthold Friedrich Brecht (1898-1956) was a German playwright, poet, and director.

breezeblocked

a breezeblock is a cinder block

Bret Ellis

Bret Easton Ellis (born 1965) is an American novelist probably best known for Less Than Zero (1985), about a drug addict who turns to prostitution, and American Psycho (1991), about a serial killer.

breviary

a prayer and hymn book

Brewster's Angle

an angle of incidence at which light with a particular polarization is perfectly transmitted through a surface, with no reflection. Read more [here ]

Brewster's-Angle light

Named for Sir David Brewster (1781-1868), Scottish scientist; the angle at which non-polarized light striking a surface will reflect polarized light. Presumably a desk lamp is positioned at such an angle. For more .

briar pipes

a type of pipe for smoking

bricklayer

The story of the barrel of bricks is thought to have originated in British music halls of the 1920s, and was printed as a story in a 1937 issue of Readers Digest . The story's most famous iterations are probably the speech given by German-British musician and humourist Gerard Hoffnung at the Oxford Union in 1958 (later released as an LP) and the comic song 'The Sick Note', written by Pat Cooksey in 1969.

briers' yeasty musk

The yeasty smell arising from the brier patches.

brig

prison on a Navy ship

Brigham and Women's City of Boston Hospital

a real hospital, now affiliated with Harvard Medical School

Brighton

a section of Boston

Brighton Projects

presumably high-rise, low-income housing in Brighton

brine

salt water

Brinksmanship

According to the Random House Unabridged Dictionary, this is "the technique or practice of maneuvering a dangerous situation to the limits of tolerance or safety in order to secure the greatest advantage, esp. by creating diplomatic crises."

Brioni

a high-fashion clothes company

brisance

the shattering effect of an explosive

Brisbane

the capital of the Australian state of Queensland

brocade

fabric woven with an elaborate design

Brockengespenst

See http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Brocken_spectre.

Brockton

a city in Massachusetts about 25 miles south of Boston

brogue

American slang term for an accent – usually Irish or Scottish – from the Irish word 'bróg', meaning 'shoe'.

Brown

The Browns are the football team of Cleveland.

brownshirts and jackboots

things worn by Nazis; jackboots are combat boots that go to mid-calf

Bruins

mascot of Brown University, though they actually just call themselves the "Bears"

Brutalism, Found Drama

Brutalism may refer to brutalist architecture . Found Drama is the cinematic extension of Found Art .

Brutus

Marcus Junius Brutus (85-42 BC) was the most famous assassin of Julius Caesar (100-44 BC).

Brylcreemed

Used as a verb here, Brylcreem is a brand name of men's hair grooming product.

BTL

the initials of several telecommunications and television companies

Bud

short for Budweiser, a brand name of beer

Bufferin

a brand of aspirin with a protectant for the stomach

Bulat

actually a common Kazakh first name

Bulldog

mascot of Yale University

bundles

heroin

bunk

poor quality, cut, or fake

bunko artists

con artists

Bunsen burner

a laboratory burner invented in part by Robert Wilhelm Eberhard Bunsen (1811-1899), a German chemist.

bunting

loosely woven fabric in a generally half-circle shape; red-white-and-blue ones can be seen hung on podiums, porches, baseball stadiums, etc, especially on the 4th of July and other patriotic holidays

Bunyan

John Bunyan (1628-1688) was an English-Calvinist preacher and writer. You can read Pilgrim's Progress here .

bupkis

Yiddish for "absolutely nothing" (spelled "bupkus" on page 878)

Bupkus

Yiddish: nothing

burg

city/town

burglared

the wanted past participle is either burgled or burglarized

Burma-Shave signs

small sequential road signs used to advertise an American brand of brushless shaving cream from 1925 to 1963; see examples here

burning some k. down

what is k.?? presumably kilometers

burnished

rubbed smooth

burr

here used to mean "irritant"

burrs

rough and prickly seed husks prone to sticking to hair or fur

Burton

Robert Burton (1577-1640) was an English author best known for his Anatomy of Melancholy

bussed

cleaned up

butter and guns

These are the typical goods used in certain economic models because they are non-competing goods. A reference to the choice between military spending and spending on the general welfare.

buttinskis

i.e., the right to butt into line

BYP

Brookline Young People's AA group

Byzantine erotica

The Byzantine Empire was the continuation of the Roman Empire in the Middle Ages. A cursory google search for "Byzantine Erotica" reveals not very much at all. The topic is either as esoteric as it seems or a DFW invention.

Bôf

defined by the Cambridge Online French-English dictionary as an interjection "expressing a lack of interest or enthusiasm"

C knob

the knob for cold water

c'etait la guerre

It was war.

C-II

These drugs are highly addictive. Cocaine is in this class, as it is still used legally in dentistry.

C-notes

hundred dollar bills

c.

abbreviation for circa, Latin for "around," used here in the sense of "approximately"

C. C. Reservoir

presumably "Cleveland Circle Reservoir," though the actual reservoir next to Cleveland Circle is known as the Chestnut Hill Reservoir.

C.F.D.C.

Caffeine-Free Diet Coke

C.T.

Uncle Charles, mentioned previously. See Page 50 .

C.U.S.P.

Stands for Clean United States Party, i.e. Johnny Gentle's pro-hygiene political platform. In reality, though it was created after Infinite Jest was published, there is an organization called CUSP .

c/o

care of, signifying an intermediary responsible for transporting the piece of mail to the final recipient's address

C/W

Country & Western

C17-morphine

regular old morphine, which has the chemical composition C 17 H 19 NO 3

C7

The C7 is a modified version of the American M-16 combat rifle. It's implied here that C7 was some kind of security apparatus, but there is no evidence that such a body existed.

cab of his 4 X 4

A 4 X 4 is a vehicle having 4 wheels, each of which is powered; and the cab is where people sit.

cabbaging

stealing

cableyarrow

Caballero (Spanish for "gentleman") is what he means.

cachinated

misspelling of cachinnated, i.e., laughed loudly

cadences

flows of events

cadge

to obtain by begging

Cafergot

A medication named after its combination of caffeine and ergotamine titrate, the chemical precursor to LSD; used to treat migraine headaches. Read about it here .

café au lait

hot coffee served with an equal amount of hot milk

Caillou Bay

You can see a map of southern Louisiana here .

Cajun

a French-speaking people dwelling in the woods of Louisiana, having emigrated there from French Canada two hundred years ago

calamari

Italian-style squid

calculus

here meaning simply "calculation"

Caldor-brand

a chain of discount department stores in the US Northeast. The chain closed its last store in 1999.

Calli tea

Read about this here .

calliopsis

Another name for Plains correopsis .

callow

immature; inexperienced

calotte

A skullcap, especially one worn by Roman Catholic priests; a skullcap, typically worn by Roman Catholic acolytes

calpac

a high-crowned felt or sheepskin hat worn in Turkey, Iran, and Central Asia

Cambridgeport

an area of Cambridge, Mass.

cammed

equipped with an aftermarket camshaft to increase performance, perhaps here simply meaning custommized

camp

deliberately artificial or vulgar -- sometimes referring specifically to gay humor

Campfire Girls

former name of youth organization when it was just for girls

camphonated

more like "camphorated," i.e., contained camphor

Camus

Albert Camus was a 20th century Algerian-born French author of existentialist texts.

Canadian

i.e., in French; i.e., Québecois French

Canadianism

presumably this is a political movement of some kind, probably based on separation from the U.S.

Canadiens of the N.L. of H.

the Montreal Canadiens, a team in the National Hockey League

Candela

From the International System of Units (SI): The candela is the luminous intensity, in a given direction, of a source that emits monochromatic radiation of frequency 540×10 12 hertz and that has a radiant intensity in that direction of 1/683 watt per steradian (whatever that means).

candelabrum

a holder for more than one candle

candent

glowing with heat

Candida albicans

a fungus associated with yeast infections in humans

canines

the cuspids, also called eye teeth in humans and fangs in many carnivorous mammals; positioned between the incisors and the bicuspids (premolars)

canned laughter

prerecorded laughter used on the soundtracks of some filmed comedies (which are not "filmed before a live studio audience"), but also a reminder of the incident involving the can of macadamia nuts (page 580)

cannoli

an Italian pastry stuffed with sweetened ricotta cheese

cannolis

a type of Italian dessert pastry, stuffed with sweetened ricotta cheese

canopied

framed with curtains

cantankerous

disagreeable, argumentative

canted

set at an oblique angle; this can also mean having rounded corners; sloped at an angle; put in an oblique position

canter

an easy gallop

cantilevered

having a "projecting structure, such as a beam, that is supported at one end and carries a load at the other end or along its length" ( American Heritage Dictionary of the English Language )

canvas restraint-wrap

straitjacket

Cap-Chat

a town in the Gaspé Peninsula

capacious

spacious, i.e., too big for Hal

caparison

an ornamental covering for a horse, or just rich clothing; rich and sumptuous clothing or equipment

Cape

i.e., Cape Cod

Cape Flattery Naval Base

It's not clear whether there is a naval base at Cape Flattery currently, but the town itself is in the state of Washington, about 140 miles west-northwest of Seattle.

capering

To caper is to skip about in a playful manner.

capillary webs

The smallest networks of blood vessels, where arteries turn into veins.

Capriati

Jennifer Marie Capriati (born 1976) was an American pro tennis player, winning three Grand Slam titles.

capricious

subject to acting on a whim

carb

Short for "carburetor," just as the carburetor in an internal combustion engine mixes air with gas to allow combustion, the carburetor on a water pipe allows one to draw air in with marijuana smoke.

carb-caloric

(from page 630) Cranberry juice is higher in carbohydrates than other juices because of the larger amounts of sugar added to sweeten it, cranberries being less naturally sweet than, e.g., oranges or apples.

carbuncular or steatocryptotic

Carbuncular means "pimply," while steatocryptotic refers to a person suffering from steatocryptosis, which is derangement of the sebaceous glands.

carcinogenic

causing cancer

cardiac

i.e., a heart attack

Cardinal Stadium

The Arizona Cardinals now play in the University of Phoenix Stadium.

cardioid

In geometry, a cardioid is a plane curve produced by tracing the path of a chosen point of a circle which rolls around a fixed circle. The cardioid shape of E.T.A. has one cusp, i.e., a point on the curve that is not smooth. The r referred to by the narrator here is the radius of the moving circle.

careered

ran at full speed

Carefree

a brand of sanitary pads

caricaturesque

pertaining to a depiction of someone that exaggerates certain facial or bodily characteristics

caries

tooth decay, leading to a cavity (always used in plural form)

Carmelite

a member of the Order of the Brothers of Our Lady of Mount Carmel, a Catholic order.

carminative

combatting or expelling flatulence; a herb mixture that prevents gastrointestinal pressure and gas

caromed

To carom is to strike and rebound; caromed is the past tense.

caroms

rebounds

carpal neuralgia

nerve pain in the bones of the hand

carpal neuralgia, phospenic migraine, gluteal hyperadiposity, lumbar stressae

hand pain, migraines with flashing lights, fat buttocks, and lower back pain

Carpenters

a 1970s soft rock band shown here

carpopedal

Involving both the hands and feet.

carriage-head bolt

a bolt with a domed head not designed to be driven

Carry Nation

Carrie A. Nation (1846-1911) was an American proponent of prohibition of alcohol.

Cartier and Roberval and Cap Rouge and Champlain

Jacques Cartier (1491-1557) was a French explorer who first mapped the Gulf of Saint Lawrence and who coined the name "Canada." Jean-François de la Roque de Roberval (1500-1560) was a French pirate and first lieutenant general of New France (i.e., French Canada, i.e., Québec). Cap-Rouge is a section of present-day Québec City, where Cartier tried to place his first French settlement. Samuel de Champlain (1567-1635) was the French founder of Québec City

cartographic

having to do with maps

cartridge

See Interlace viewer, above

cast

tinge of color

caster

wheel

castigations

criticisms; reprimands

Castor and Pollux

stars in the constellation Gemini, named for twin sons of Zeus and Leda in Greek mythology

catachresis

misuse of words, as in a mixed metaphor

catadioptric

an optical system that uses combined reflection and refraction; a catadioptric telescope has a large concave mirror to collect and focus light on an optical eyepiece having lenses to provide additional magnification

catalepsy

suspension of sensation, with bodily rigidity

cataract

In the non-ophthalmic sense, this word means "waterfall."; waterfall

catastatic

of or pertaining to the climax of a play, movie, etc

catatonic

relating to catatonia, a neurogenic motor immobility arising from a disturbed mental state (resulting in little or no movement in the sufferer)

catexic

this is likely a misspelling of "cathexic," which means "emotionally charged."

catgut

This is "a strong cord made by twisting the dried intestines of animals, as sheep, used in stringing musical instruments and tennis rackets, for surgical sutures, etc." ( Random House Unabridged Dictionary ).

cathected

emotionally or mentally invested

cathedran

Presumably Wallace means "like a cathedral," but this is not a real word. The proper word would be cathedrarian.

cathexis

defined as the process of investment of mental or emotional energy in a person, object, or idea

caustic

adj., biting, stinging, sarcastic

cavalier

disdainful; unceremonious

cavortings

sexual pursuits

CBC

Canadian Broadcasting Corporation ( Wikipedia )

CBC/PATHÉ

CBC is the Canadian Broadcasting Company. PATHÉ is probably the French entertainment company Pathé Frères (Pathé Brothers).

cc

cubic centimeter, equal to 0.001 liters

cellulitic

Having cellulite, i.e., deposits of subcutaneous fat within fibrous connective tissue (as in the thighs, hips, and buttocks) that give a puckered and dimpled appearance to the skin surface ( Merriam-Webster )

censer

a device for burning incense, especially in religious services

centrifugal

that force in a spinning object that tends to push away objects from the angle of rotation

Cerberus

In Greek mythology, this the three-headed dog that guards the entrance to Hades. President Gentle is mixing his mythological metaphors here: Cerberus's three heads were not horned, as was that of the Minotaur, with its bull's head on the body of a man.

cerebral

oriented toward thinking

cerebral cortex

that part of the brain responsible for higher-order thinking

cerebrate

to think about something

cerise

deep red to purple in color; a vivid purplish red

cervical massage

neck massage to reduce muscle tension

Cesar Romero

Cesar Romero (1907-1994) was a Cuban-American actor and entertainer, best known to a generation of television viewers as the man who played the Joker on the television live-action series of Batman .

cesareans

surgical operations to remove infants from their mothers' wombs, performed when (or before) difficulties obtain during "natural" (vaginal) birth; misspelling of caesareans

Ch. 11 protection

Chapter 11, a section of the bankruptcy code under which one could file for protection from creditors

chagrin

embarrassment at having failed

Chalmette

an eastern suburb of New Orleans

chamois

Pronounced "shammy," this is a cloth or piece of leather used to shine a surface.

Champaign IL

He probably attends the University of Illinois main campus.

Champlain-era

of the era of Samuel de Champlain

Chanel

the fashion house known in long form as the House of Chanel

change their bags

i.e., their colostomy bags

chanties

Alternate spelling for "shanties," i.e., songs (particularly ones sung by seamen).

chanting very softly 'Smoke'

i.e., surreptitiously peddling marijuana

chapeau

hat

Charles

Brandeis University, Harvard University, Boston University, and the Massachusetts Institute of Technology are all located along the charles river

Charles Tavis

I.e., C.T.

Charleston

a dance popular in the 1920s; the dance, not the city; This is the third mention of characters dancing or pretending to dance the Charleston, the others being Steeply at page 94 and the Vaught twins at page 218.

Charlestown

a neighborhood in the northernmost part of Boston, right over the Charles River from downtown

Charlottetown

the capital of the Canadian province of Prince Edward Island

chartreuse

bright yellowish-green

chasm

a gorge or deep cleft in the earth's surface

chassis

the construction forming the sides, top, and back of a piece of equipment

Chaucerian English

You can read an example here .

Cheap-O Records

a reference to Cheapo Records (no hyphen) in Central Square, Cambridge. It was located at 645 Mass Ave when the book was written, but the building has since been demolished. It now resides at 538 Mass Ave. http://www.cheaporecords.com/

cheese-nibbler

i.e., a rat

cheesecloth

a fabric of lightweight cotton threads of open texture

chemical psychosis

Psychosis (called "speed psychosisis") a not uncommon side effect of amphetamine abuse.

chemist at Sandoz Pharm.

This would be Albert Hoffman (born 1906), a Swiss scientist best known for first synthesizing LSD.

cheri

French: my dear

cherry

a term for a virgin

cherub

Often this word is used to denote a baby angel, but the actual connotation of the original Hebrew is of a fearsome warrior angel. A cherub guards the Garden of Eden in Genesis so that Adam and Eve cannot go back in.

chez

a French preposition meaning "at the home of"

chianti

is any wine produced in the Chianti region, in central Tuscany, Italy.

chiaroscuro

Distribution of light and shade in a photo or painting.

Chic-Choc lakes

the Chic-Choc mountains are in the Gaspé Peninsula

chicanery

deception by trickery or sophistry

Chickens Fresh Killed Daily

a reference to the prominent 'Live Poultry Fresh Killed' sign of the Mayflower Poultry Company at 621 Cambridge Street, East Cambridge, about a half a mile from Inman Square.

chickory

usually spelled chicory, is used as a coffee substitute or additive in some places

chiens

French: dogs

chiffon

a lightweight, balanced, plain-woven fabric

chignon

hair tied into a knot worn at the back of the head, similar to a bun.; a roll of hair at the back of the head or nape of the neck

chill dusk

George Eliot (born Mary Anne Evans; 1819-1880), the British novelist, uses the expression in her novel Adam Bede .

Chinkette

another Lenz-P.O.V. ethnic epithet: Chinese

chinks

narrow openings

chintz

printed, glazed fabric, usually of bright colors

chintzy

cheap and low grade

chip

to use enough heroin to stave off withdrawal; a short, high hit

Chit Chat Farms

This is a real detox in Wernersville, Pa., about 70 miles northwest of Philadelphia.

chivalric

considerate and courteous to women

Chock Full O'Nuts

a brand name of coffee

cholera and amoebic-dysentery

Cholera is extreme diarrhea brought on by unsanitary conditions. Amoebic dysentery is also extreme diarrhea, this time brought on by the acquisition of a parasitic infection.

Choosy Mothers

probably taken from the Jif peanut butter commerical slogan: "Choosy Mothers Choose Jif"

chop

helicopter

chordate phylum

the phylum of the animal kingdom containing all animals with spines

Chore Boy

a brand of scrubbing pads . The copper version of these pads can be used as a filter for smoking crack.

Chore-type supplies

e.g., stainless-steel or copper scouring pads now branded as Chore Boy, after some years as Chore Girl; ironically, the pads are often used in homemade crack-cocaine pipes (see note for page 222)

chromotography

Here misspelled, chromatography is "any of various techniques for the separation of complex mixtures that rely on the differential affinities of substances for a gas or liquid mobile medium and for a stationary adsorbing medium through which they pass, such as paper, gelatin, or magnesia" ( American Heritage Dictionary of the English Language ).

chuff

to blow hard and loudly

chuffing

producing or moving with noisy exhaust or exhalations, e.g., a chuffing train

chyme

This is "the semifluid mass into which food is converted by gastric secretion and which passes from the stomach into the small intestine" ( Random House Unabridged Dictionary ).; semi-fluid partially digested food

Chyonskrg Kurgistan

Assuming that (a) the name of the town is spelled correctly, and (b) the country is Kyrgyzstan, I can't find this town on a directory of towns in Kyrgyzstan.

CIA-era military experiments

probably a reference to MKULTRA

Ciao Bello

Italian: Goodbye (common). Literally: "Goodbye, Beautiful."

Cimetidine

actually an antacid―strange that Wallace would make such an error, so perhaps it's deliberate

ciquatoxic

An alternate or mispelling of 'ciguatoxic'. Reef fish can carry ciguatoxins, which cause ciguatera food poisoning [12] in humans who consume the contaminated fish. These toxins may be specific to certain reefs, are concentrated up the food chain and as such are more likely to be present in larger reef fish, and cannot be destroyed by cooking and freezing. For more, see here .

circadian arrhythmia

sleep disturbance

circadian rhythm

Have a look at this chart .

Circe

a goddess from Greek mythology

circumferences

distances around the edge of a circle

circumflex

A circumflex is a diacritical mark, as seen in the French verb être (to be). Presumably, the dean's eyebrows have taken on this shape.

circumoral

surrounding the mouth

circumorals

Muscles around the mouth.

cirrhotic

pertaining to hardening of liver tissue

cirri

plural of cirrus, a type of cloud

CITGO

one of the major oil companies. The neon Citgo sign described here is an iconic landmark in Boston.

civety

civet-like; a civet is a small carnivorous feline mammal that emits a strange smell

clapboard

a long, thin board, thicker along one edge than the other, used in covering the outer walls of buildings ( Random House Unabridged Dictionary )

clapper

little board at the beginning of takes that opens and snaps shut to sync video and audio. It also designates and marks particular scenes and takes

claque

a group of sycophants

claret

red wine

claret-colored

dark purplish red; A deep purplish red. Claret is also the name of a wine that is produced in the Bordeaux region of France and slang for 'blood'. [1]

Clearasil

a brand name of benzoyl peroxide, for acne

CLEMSON

a university in South Carolina

Cleveland Circle

a neighborhood of Boston

Clift

Edward Montgomery Clift (1920-1966) was an American actor.

climacteric

A period of decrease in reproductive capacity; in women, menopause.

Clipper

A clipper in electronics is a way of sort of metering how much electricity, power, data, etc., goes through a circuit. Here its usage would seem more to indicate a computer hacker.

Clipperton même

French: Clipperton himself

cloracne

probably a misspelling of chloracne

CLOSED, ROPAS, and RELACHE

three ways (in the limited linguistic abilities of the sign-printers) of saying the same thing; ropas is Spanish for "clothes" (a pun that does not translate! also note that the Portuguese would be 'roupa') and relâche is French for "closure" (used on theatrical bills to indicate the cancellation of a performance)

cluster migraines

Cluster headaches and migraines are actually two distinct syndromes.

CNS

Central Nervous System; central nervous system

CNS-rendingly

A play on the term 'heart-rending'. CNS is an acronym for central nervous system.

CO

Carbon monoxide, sometimes used from engine exhaust for suicide.; carbon monoxide

co-eval of venereal interface

"Co-eval" can have the more specific meaning of "contemporary," i.e., having the same age (date of origin) or duration, but Kenkle is using periphrasis to say "equivalent of sex."

co-op

a co-operative, i.e., an apartment building that is jointly owned by the tenants

CO2

a misprint, likely, for CO 2, i.e., carbon dioxide

Coatlicue

This is the name of an Aztec goddess, one who gave birth to the moon and stars. The reference here is perhaps to Avril.

coaxial

coaxial cable A type of cable that has an inner conductor surrounded by a tubular insulating layer, surrounded by a tubular conducting shield.

coccyges

plural of coccyx, i.e., the tailbone

coccyx

tailbone

cod

a type of fish

Code-Five

code for "stakeout in progress"

codeine

an opiate used as a painkiler; a habit-forming, Schedule III narcotic

codicil

an addition to a legal will; a legal supplement or appendix

Codinex Plus

a brand name of cough syrup

codpieces

a codpiece is a pouch at the crotch (covering the male genetalia) of tight-fitting breeches, popular during the Renaissance

coeval

contemporaneous or equally old

coffin-corner kicks

Usually refers to a punt inside the opponent's 20 yard line that goes out of bounds and thus cannot be returned, as opposed to inside the 20-yard-line punts that remain in the field of play but are touched (killed) by a downfield runner

cognito

which is to say, in Lenz's case, unsuccessfully incognito

cognomen

a nickname; distinguishing nickname; a descriptive nickname; a nickname

cognoscenti

people having superior knowledge

coheres

becomes logically consistent, i.e. coherent

coiffure

hairdo; hairdo

cojones

Spanish for "testicles"

cold annular fusion

Cold fusion is a low-energy nuclear reaction. That it is annular means it is ring-shaped. Cold fusion is highly controversial. Regular fusion experiments take place in a tokamak, which is shaped like a torus (donut).

collate

collect and combine in proper order

collops

rolls of fat

colloquia

Plural for "colloquium," these are akin to academic conferences, albeit slightly less formal.

Collyrium

Collyrium itself is not a brand name; it's the generic name.

Colonel Shaw and the MA 54th

Robert Gould Shaw was a Bostonian killed in the Civil War while commanding the all-black Massachusetts 54th Regiment. A relief sculpture memorial to him is located on Beacon Street (not Boylston Street) in front of the Massachusetts State House.

color of summer squash

The colors of summer squashes vary, but Wallace probably is implying that Poor Tony looks yellow.

colostomy

a procedure by which feces exit the body via a hole in a person's side into a bag, rather than via the anus; a surgical procedure in which the healthy part of the colon is sutured to an opening in the abdominal wall (for elimination of feces, bypassing the rectum); a bag is attached to the opening to collect the waste products

colposcope

a scope used to examine the internal female reproductive organs

Combat Zone

a former area of Boston known for prostitution and sex shops

Comme on dit

French: Like they say

comme-il-faut

French: As is necessary

commode

toilet

compadre

a close friend or companion, from the Spanish for "godfather"; Spanish term for "friend"

comped by Fila

provided for free (or complimentary)

complicit

involved in a plot or scheme

complicity

the status of being an accomplice in a wrongdoing

compound

i.e., a compound fracture, where the bone protrudes through the skin

compromise Eschaton's map

which here would seem to mean that Lord may just kill Eschaton as a game

Con-Edison

Consolidated Edison, the utilities company serving New York

concentric circles

circles within circles (and more annularity); more specifically circles of different radii but a common center

CONCORD

the capital of New Hampshire

Concord

Concord is about 20 miles northwest of Boston and is the site one of the first battles of the American Revolution.; agreement

condonation

overlooking of an offense

Condé Nast

one of the largest magazine publishers in the country, owned by Advance Publications (the Newhouse family) and founded by Condé Montrose Nast (1873-1942), an American publisher

confabulation

formation of false memories

confected

candied or covered in sugar

confiscated from razzles...

Confiteor

a penitent prayer said by Roman Catholics

confiteor

a prayer of confession of sins

conic sections

These are studied in advanced trigonometry; they are geometric shapes forced by passing a plane through a double-naped cone at different angles and observing the cross-sections, i.e., circles, ellipses (see note supra ), parabolas, and hyperbolas.

connubial

marital

conoid

conic; cone-like

constabulary

a body of peace officers

Constantine

perhaps Constantine I, by tradition first Christian emperor of Rome

Constantinian

Presumably referring to the reign of Constantine "the Great", Byzantine emperor from 306–337 c.e.

constellated

covered, as with stars

constitutionally

meaning "psychologically" (or even "physiologically")

consummate

Highly skilled; perfect.; highly skilled

consummately

perfectly or skillfully

cont. id.

probably "contemporary idiomatic" as spelled out in the previous line

contact-bursts

a type of nuclear strike

continent

able to control his bowels and bladder

continentally ranked

ranking of players in North America, see, e.g., O.N.A.N.C.A.A.

contingent

group of people sharing a common trait within a larger group

not a drug currently marketed in the U.S.

contractured

having shortened muscle tissue

contrite

conundra

insoluble questions; the plural of conundrum is disputed, with the OED apparently preferring conundrums, as with stadiums

something puzzling
