assembly or act of assembling

convolutions

folds on the surface of the brain

convolved

rolled or coiled together.; wound together

convulsive

Experiencing convulsions, violent involuntary physical shaking

convulsively

As if struck by a convulsion; moving suddenly and without coordination.

cook-and-shoot

i.e. cooking and shooting up drugs

cop

obtain drugs; obtain drugs

Copernicanly

Apparently in the manner of Polish astronomer Nicolaus Copernicus (1473-1543), famed for theorizing that the Earth orbits the Sun rather than vice versa, but this raises the question of why or how in the manner of Copernicus. It does not seem that Erdedy has a telescope, but perhaps he is "staring...up her [the veiled girl's] flapping robe" looking for the center of the universe. (my take: Copernicus stared up, in wonder at the beauty of the universe. Likewise for Erdedy)

copless

without policemen

Copley

Copley Square, a neighborhood of Boston

copperheads

coprolaliac

sexual excitement brought on by feces and eating of feces, respectively

cordite

a propellant used in place of gunpowder in firearms; a smokeless explosive used in the place of gunpowder; similar to gunpowder

Cornet

a brass instrument that looks much like a trumpet

cornup3.COM

There is no such Web site.

corona

crown or halo

corporal

to eat away at; to rust

court-shaped

like a tennis court, presumably or like court-shaped wedding rings: straight all the way around the top and bottom edges, and curved/rounded on both the inside and the outside faces.

Isotopes of certain atoms combine with others to form covalent bonds.

not a real entity, but probably here denoting a French-Canadian radio station

crank cocaine

Methamphetamine and cocaine (the use of ether and baking soda implies freebase cocaine and crack cocaine, respectively; both of these freebase products are water insoluble and therefore cannot be introduced to the bloodstream via injection or snorting).

craven

Crawfordsville, Indiana

a town about 45 miles northwest of Indianapolis

creatus

Latin for "creation," the line over the a indicates the vowel is long and pronounced as in "father" rather than in "hate."

White Flag reference to senior AA members, who sit under a picture of crocodiles sunbathing on a riverbank

Crohn's

The disease is named for Burrill Bernard Crohn (1884-1983), American gastroenterologist.

Crohn's Disease

also regional enteritis, an inflammatory disease of the bowels

crook

crop-and-epaulette

crop being a riding crop, this would suggest a certain militaristic disposition

if cocaine is called "Bing," Crosbulation refers to snorting cocaine, referring to the last name of Bing Crosby

a crosier is a type of French roll

Crown Royal in purple bags

Crown Royal is Canadian whisky that comes in a purple cloth bag

crustacean

the branch of animals including lobsters, shrimp, and other similar shellfish

Crétien assassination

This is probably a misspelling of the surname of Joseph Jacques Jean Chrétien (born 1934), Prime Minister of Canada from 1993 to 2003.

Csikzentmihalyi

Mihaly Csikszentmihalyi ( sic ) is a psychologist best known for his concept of "flow", a psychological state where one "is fully immersed in what he or she is doing by a feeling of energized focus, full involvement, and success in the process of the activity", e.g. "being in the zone" while playing sports.

Csíkszentmihályi

The name may be taken from Mihály Csíkszentmihályi (born 1934), a prominent Hungarian-American psychologist. His son Christopher is on the faculty at MIT.

cubed

multiplied by itself twice; taken to the third power

cubist

suggestive of Cubism, the early-20th-century avant-garde ( not après-garde) art movement

cuckolds

men whose wives cheat on them

cuc—

Pemulis is probably about to say "cuckold."

Cuerva

Thrust means "Cuervo," a brand of tequila.

cuffs

rotator cuffs - group of muscles and their tendons that act to stabilize the shoulder.

Cuibono

more properly cui bono, Latin for "who benefits?"

cuirass

a piece of armor covering the heart

Cukor

George Dewey Cukor (1899-1983) was an American film director .

culcate

neologism perhaps stemming off of inculcate, here meaning implanted. Another similar word is "calcate", meaning "To trample or stamp under the heel" (OED). So he might have intended it to mean "stamping".

Cultists in saffron with much percussion

members of the International Society for Krishna Consciousness (Hare Krishna movement) in their distinctive saffron-colored (orange) robes, likely carrying Mridangams and tambourines

Cumberland

This must refer to the Cumberland River, which flows into the Ohio near Paducah, in the western part of Kentucky, close to Joelle's home town of Shiny Prize (see page 237).

cummerbund

the band of fabric worn around the waist with a tuxedo

cumuli

plural of "cumulus," a type of cloud

delays

cuneiform

the writing of ancient Sumer, made by digging a wedge into clay

curriculum vitae

Cushing's Disease

Named for Harvey Williams Cushing (1869-1939), an American neurologist, this disease is an endocrine disorder resulting in rapid weight gain, sweating, thinning of skin, and other negative side effects.

cuticles

dead skin at the bottom of the fingernails

CVS

a large chain of drugstores

cyanosis

blueness of the skin caused by deoxygenated blood

cyanotic

afflicted with bluish discoloration due to a lack of oxygenated blood

cycloid

a curve traced by a point of a circle as it rolls across a straight line demonstrated here

probably a reference to the Anglo-Saxon poet by that name

employing the Cyrillic alphabet, as with Russian, Ukrainian, Serbian, Bulgarian, etc.

cytological

Like microscopic cells; on the other hand, maybe this is a deliberate or accidental misspelling of cetological (related to whales). Hal seems to be imagining himself spitting water like a whale spouting water from its blowhole.

D W Griffith

Film Director whose films include 'Tolerance' and 'Birth of a Nation'; Wikipedia entry

Also called "rushes," these are the pieces of raw film recorded during a single day, including cuts, takes, prints, etc.

short for "dashboard"

a piece of information; usually used in its plural, i.e., data; piece of information, the singular form of the word "data"

Ann B. Davis, who played Alice, the maid; a city in California about 15 miles west of Sacramento

i.e., the Daytona 500, a yearly auto race

dibromododecenyl methylsulfimide

As opposed to de jure, which would mean legally, de facto implies a situation is true even if not legally true.

de moi

French: from me.

removing the muffler from her motorcycle, thus making it extra loud

Deer Island

an island in Boston Harbor, and until 1991 the site of the Suffolk County House of Correction

defacatory

As if eliminating solid bodily waste.

Defarge

Madame Thérèse Defarge is perhaps the principal revolutionary villain in Charles Dickens's 1959 novel A Tale of Two Cities ; she knits into her needlework the names of the royalists and aristocrats who must be condemned to the guillotine to make way for the new republic.

DEFCON

Defense Readiness Condition, i.e., the measure of the activation of the U.S. Armed Forces in reaction to a real or perceived threat. The higher the number, the lower the threat; the numbers as used in Infinite Jest are used incorrectly, i.e., the higher the DEFCON number, the higher the risk.

defib paddles

the paddles used in defibrillation, the application of electric shocks to the heart to re-start it

defile

a line of soldiers; a narrow passage

defiles

narrow passageways

deform

here meaning simply "to spoil"

deft

quick and skillful; dexterous or nimble

The Yankee Conference, by the way, ceased to exist in 1997.

delfts

Delphina

name of a beatified Catholic virgin

Delta-9

Delta-9-tetrahydrocannabinol, the main psychoactive substance found in marijuana

deltoid

Demerol

a brand name of pethidine, a painkiller

demethylated

with a methyl group (CH 3 ) removed. Technically, this is incorrect; to go from codeine (C 18 H 21 NO 3 ) to morphine (C 17 H 19 NO 3 ) requires the removal of a methyl ene group (CH 2 ). The accurate term would be "demethyl en ated."

demurely

in an effectedly modest way

dendriurethane

This substance does not actually exist. An educated guess is that it is a type of polyurethane that comes from trees, dendri being Greek for "tree."; a branching organic compound (carbamate), probably rubbery or at least flexible for construction purposes

Denial is not just a river in Egypt.

DeNiro

Robert Mario De Niro, Jr. (born 1943), is an Academy Award-winning American actor, cast by Martin Scorsese in Mean Streets and several times thereafter.

Dennis Gabor, born Gábor Dénes, was a 20th century Hungarian physicist who invented holography, for which he received the Nobel Prize.

derrick

A derrick is "a jib crane having a boom hinged near the base of the mast so as to rotate about the mast, for moving a load toward or away from the mast by raising or lowering the boom" ( Random House Unabridged Dictionary ).

desBois

the plural of duBois

descants

A descant is an ornamental melody or counterpoint sung or played above a theme.

Desjardins

A fairly common French surname, it may have been inspired here by Gabriel-Alphonse Desjardins (1854-1920), Québecois founder of the Desjardins Group .

DeSotos

a brand of automobile, examples of which can be seen here

dessicated

dried out; dried out; dried up

detritus

debris

deuce

This is the score call when both sides in tennis are tied with a score of 40 or thereafter. The progression is 0 or "love," 15, 30, 40, and "game," but the winner must win the final two points. When each side has won three points, the call is "deuce" rather than 40-all; the next point won creates "ad [advantage] in" if won by the server(s) or "ad out" if won by the opponent(s). If the side with the advantage wins the next point, it wins the game; otherwise the score returns to "deuce." Sets are won by the first side to take six games; but sets must be won by at least two games. (In much match play, best-of-twelve-point tiebreakers are played when the sides are tied at 6-6 games. Thus a set score can be 6-4, 7-5, or 7-6, but never 6-5.) A tennis match is won by the side that takes three out of five sets (more commonly for professional male tennis players) or two of three sets (for women and amateurs).

deuteragonist

the second most important character next to the main character, the protagonist

deviant division

56/17 (see note supra for page 1069)

devroid

devoid

Dewar's

a brand name of whiskey

dewimpled

like defrocked, except for a nun. The Carmelites being a Roman Catholic Order which puts an emphasis on contemplation.

dewlaps

loose flesh as under the jaw of a cow

dewy-eyed

exhibiting childlike simplicity

diabetes mellitus

more commonly known simply as "diabetes"

diabolic

devilishly evil

diagnate

perhaps a combination of "diagonal", referring to Cantor's diagonal proof, and "agnate"

diaphoretic

perspiring

Diaphragm foam

Vaginal Contraceptive Foam

diasporic

scattered; dispersed (from one's homeland)

Dicalced

Apparently there is a misspelling. The correct term would be Discalced Carmelites, which means they go barefoot or wear sandals.

Dick

I'm unable to identify whether this person is real or not.

Dick Cavett and Truman Capote

Richard Alva "Dick" Cavett (born 1936) is an Emmy-award-winning television talk-show host. Truman Capote (1924-1984) was an American writer and novelist, best known for writing In Cold Blood and Breakfast at Tiffany's . Both men were remarkably short.

Dick Willis

There was a spy named Richard Willis (1613-1690) active during the English Civil War (1642-1660). This is also the name of a professional peer of Steeply in the novel, first mentioned earlier.

dickies

As a dickie is designed to give the appearance of wearing a tie, Wallace uses this word here to deal with drugs that mimic the effects of other drugs.

Dickinson's about as Transcendalist as Poe.

which is to say, not at all

dicky

impaired

diction

choice of words

dictum

a maxim or saying

didactic

intended to teach

diem

Latin: day

differentials

first derivatives in calculus

Differentiation

the process by which one determines the first derivative of a mathematical function

diffraction

the bending or stretching of waves, assuming light is a wave and not a particle

diffusion filter

A diffusion filter is a translucent photographic filter used for a special effect. When used in front of the camera lens, a diffusion filter softens subjects and generates a dreamy haze.

Digestive-Flora

bacteria that live in the intestines and aid in digestion

digitate

“having deep radiating divisions” (OED)

diglobular

consisting of two lumps of fat - here it refers to, however, his globe-like head seated atop his globe-like body, as mentioned on the previous page

Dilaudid

brand name for hydromorphone hydrochloride

dilettantes

people who (in this case) play tennis merely for amusement

dilettantish

from "dilettante" - a person who takes up an art, activity, or subject merely for amusement, especially in a desultory or superficial way; dabbler.

dingy

lacking brightness or freshness

dink

a synonym for a drop shot, which in tennis is a light tap just over the net

dinkle

a euphemism for "penis"

diorama

a model representing a scene with three-dimensional figures, either in miniature or as a large-scale museum exhibit.

dioxins

highly toxic by-products of pesticide manufacturing

dip-mil

diplomatic-military

diphthong

In linguistics, a diphthong is a vowel combination involving a smooth transition from one vowel to another in the same syllable. "Splitting the diphthong" in "beautiful" is pronouncing it bee-yoo-ti-ful.; A sound formed by the combination of two vowels in a single syllable, in which the sound begins as one vowel and moves toward another

diphthongs

occurrences of two adjacent vowel sounds in a word, e.g, poor, sour, coin

diplomatic immunity

Diplomats are granted freedom from prosecution under a host country's laws.

dipsoid

alcoholic

dipsomaniacal

Characterized by an uncontrollable urge to consume alcohol, describing James O. Incandenza's father

dire

indicating trouble

directionless in a dark wood

A reference to Dante's "Divine Comedy"'s first Canto of the Inferno.

direly

urgently; desperately

dirigibles

women's dresses with close fitting bodices and full skirts

act of disrespect

Disciplinary Lit.

a joke on the more common interdisciplinary (of or relating to more than one branch of knowledge) academic classes

to confuse or disconcert

discreditated

Presumably he means "discredited."

Rambling in speech.; Digressing from subject to subject:

dissonant

inharmonious with other things (here, aspects of Madame Psychosis's taste)

ditty

a little song

diuresis extremus

Extreme production of urine and, thus, need to urinate. The correct Greek-Latin term should be diuresis extrema, diuresis being a feminine noun.

diurnal

During the day. Opposite of nocturnal.

divans

couches or sofas

diverticulitis

inflammation of the pouches of the colon; a painful disease involving the formation of pouches within the bowel wall

divot

Normally a golf term, a divot is the hole left by the dirt displaced when one strikes a golf ball.

Dixie Baton-Twirling Institute in Oxford MS

Wallace has taken this idea from a short story "Twirling at Ole Miss" by Terry Southern . Oxford, Miss., is the home of "Ole Miss," i.e., the University of Mississippi and is about 60 miles southeast of Memphis, Tenn.

DMSO

dimethylsulfoxide, a common solvent used in many laboratories. It is readily absorbed through the skin, taking with it whatever it has dissolved.

DMT

acronym for [ http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dimethyltryptamine dimethyltryptamine

DMV

Department of Motor Vehicles

DMZ

Most commonly, this acronym stands for "demilitarized zone," as in the area between North and South Korea. Here it is a made-up drug name.

DMZ/M.P.

DMZ is another made-up drug. M.P. refers to its street name, Madame Psychosis.

do-goodnik

a play on no-goodnik, i.e., lowlife, presumably meaning do-gooder

Docksider

a type of boat shoe

Dodge

A reference to Dodge City, Kansas, to "get out of Dodge" is to disappear because of some kind of perceived or real threat.

doffed

doff is to take off or tip in salutation (don off)

dogleg

a route that turns at a sharp angle

dolefully

in a sorrowful manner

DOM or STP

STP stands for "serenity, tranquity, and peace," and it's a pseudonym for DOM, which stands for dimethoxy-4-methylamphetamine.

domestic

a person hired to perform household tasks, e.g., cleaning

domino-mask

This is "a large, hooded cloak with a mask covering the eyes, worn at masquerades" ( Random House Unabridged Dictionary ).

Don

A mafia boss.

Don Ho

Donald Tai Loy Ho (1930-2007) was a Hawaiian musician.

Donegal cap

You can see one here .

Donnay

a brand of tennis racquet

doocy

As in the same Tommy Doocey already introduced; the harelipped pot dealer in the trailer park with the smelly snakes.

dopamine

dopamine is a neurotransmitter. It plays major role in arousal and sexual gratification

dope-slaps

a smack to the back of the head, designed to get attention rather than inflict pain; distinct from more familiar "bitch-slap"

dopesick

in withdrawal from opiates such as heroin

Doric column

columns of buildings built according to the Doric order

dormer

a part of a building containing a vertical window sticking out of a slanted roof

dot-matrix printer

one of the earliest-generation computer printers

doting

adoring

double dutch

a type of rope jumping where two ropes are used

double-fault

two successive faults in serving, resulting in the loss of the point

Doubles the focal-length

Zooms the camera in.

doublets

tight-fitting jackets

dour

sullen or gloomy

DOW

probably the Dow Jones Industrial Average

Dow

a pun on the Chinese word tao, ("the way") and the Dow Jones Industrial Average

Dow turned Grizzly

i.e., a bear (downward-moving) market environment began

Dr. Dentons

a trade name of children's blanket sleeper (pajamas); Gately's are XXL, extra extra large

Dr. Dolores Rusk

Allusion to Vladamir Nabokov's Lolita, a novel about the long-term molestation of a 12-year-old girl named Dolores (also known as Dolly, Lolita, Lola, Lo and L). Phiely's 'disappearance into the Humboldt County hill country' on the previous page is probably a reference to the book's narrator, Humbert Humbert (though Humboldt County is a real place)

draconian

Derived from Draco, the 7th century BC first lawgiver of Athens, the word means unusually harsh or severe.

Draconyl

perhaps a nonce adjective indicating that the carpet is made of Dacron, the synthetic polyester fiber, but could be an invented extension of the trademark, because it appears later on the page as a noun

draw a bead

slang for taking aim at a target with a rifle

drawn

displaying fatigue or illness

Dregs

dirty remainders

Dretske

Perhaps Fred Dretske (born 1932), a philosopher of the mind.

Droll

whimsically comic

droogs

a word from Anthony Burgess's invented Nadsat language from the novel 'A Clockwork Orange'; it means 'friends'

drop-ceiling

a ceiling where, instead of meeting sheetrock at the top of the walls, you reach a series of tiles (often fiberglass-filled) that are hung a few inches below the actual ceiling, sometimes for aesthetic reasons, sometimes to facilitate lighting, etc.

drop-volley

a ball hit just over the net, causing the opponent to rush forward

dross

rubbish

DT

Delirium tremens. A psychotic condition typical of withdrawal in chronic alcoholics, involving tremors, hallucinations, anxiety, and disorientation.

duBois

Fake etymology for "doobie," a term for a marijuana cigarette.

dubs

doubles

duck blind

a shelter for concealing duck hunters

dugout

where the teams during a baseball game sit while not actually playing

DUI

Driving Under the Influence

Dukakis

Michael Stanley Dukakis (born 1933) was governor of Massachusetts (1983-1991) and the 1988 Democratic nominee for President.

Duluth

a town in Minnesota and home to Bob Dylan, on Lake Superior about 150 miles north of the Twin Cities

dum-dums

bullets that mushroom on impact for maximum bodily damage

dumbshow

Here it means sign language or mime, but the term has a longer history in theater, where it refers to a preview of a part of a play done without lines.

dun

grayish-brown; grayish brown; make repeated demands on

dunk-tank

a carnival attraction (see right) in which the participant pays to hurl one or more balls at a target that, if hit, will trigger a mechanism that unseats a victim into a receptacle of water

duplicitous

deceptive in speech

Duquette at M.I.T.

There is no such person at M.I.T.

Dural edema

swelling of the dura mater due to excess liquid

Durban

the second most populous city in S. Africa, on the country's southeast coast

dusky

dark-skinned

Duster

the Plymouth Duster was a sporty compact available from 1970 to 1976; the Plymouth Duster

dustruffle

also known as a bed skirt, a skirt of fabric intended to prevent the accumulation of dust beneath a bed

Dworkinite

The word refers to Andrea Dworkin (1946-2005), an American radical lesbian feminist; Andrea Dworkin was a radical feminist, known for criticism of pornography, which later extended to a denunciation of all heterosexual intercourse which she saw as coercive and degrading to women.

Dymphna

Dymphna was a 7th century Irish saint. Her feast day is May 15. She is the patron saint of mental illness professionals, epileptics, and the mentally ill, among others.

Dynamic Duo

usually refers to Batman and Robin

Dysautonomia

any disease or malfunction of the central nervous system

dysmenorrhea

pre-menstrual syndrome and/or painful periods

dyspeptic

irritable

dysphoria

A mental state of feeling horrible.; an emotional state characterized by anxiety, depression, or unease

dysplasia

abnormal growth of cells or tissue

Dzhugdzhur Range

a mountain range in far east Siberia

déjà vu

From French for "already seen," it's the sense that you're re-experiencing something.

détente

a relaxation of tensions

Dürer's 'The Magnificent Beast'

Albrecht Dürer (1471-1528) was a German painter and mathematician. You can see the work cited here .

E cup

a very large breast size

e-note

electronic note, likely not a literal reference to an actual electronic communication, conceived in the pre-Internet era

E. A. Abbott

Edwin Abbott Abbott (1838-1926) was a British author and theologian best known for having written Flatland, which can be read here . The book tries to dramatize dimensionality by telling the story of shapes that live 2D and their interaction with 1D and 3D shapes. It's very popular with aspiring math-physics-computer-science students.

E. Room

emergency room

E.C.T.

electroconvulsive therapy

E.M.I.T.

enzyme-multiplied immunoassay technique

E.M.I.T. and AbuScreen/RIA

Enzyme Multiplied Immunoassay Technique; Abusecreen is a brand name of drug test, and RIA stands for radioimmunoassay, "a procedure that measures minute amounts of a substance, such as a hormone or drug, by quantitating the binding, or the inhibition of binding, of a radiolabeled substance to an antibody" ( American Heritage Dictionary of the English Language, Fourth Edition ).

E.N.T.

Abbreviation for "ear-nose-throat."

E.N.T. oncologist

ear, nose, and throat; an oncologist is a cancer physician

E.R.

Emergency Room

E.S.T.

Eastern Standard Time

E.W.D. land barge

acronym for "Empire Waste Disposal"; a garbage truck

eagle-, leaf-, and broom-emblemized

presumably the vestigal U.S.A. bald eagle and Canadian maple leaf, so the broom could be the symbol of O.N.A.N.

easement

Literally meaning the use of something legally not one's own, here it's used to mean a new path beaten through a thicket.; An easement is a right to use part of someone else's land for a limited purpose, often a right to cross it on a defined pathway. Thus the Higher Power as a cheese-easement refers to Gately's analogy to a lab rat who's learned one route through a maze to the cheese.; a right of way across a plot of property owned by another

east of Atlantic City, NJ

which would be either in Europe on the Atlantic Ocean somewhere -- or nowhere

Easter Island statue

Easter Island is a Polynesian island in the southeastern Pacific Ocean, at the southeasternmost point of the Polynesian triangle. The island is a special territory of Chile. Easter Island is famous for its monumental statues, called moai, created by the Rapanui people. Wikipedia

eat cheese

be a rat

ebubblient

i.e., "ebullient" (with bubbles)

ebullient

zestfully enthusiastic

ecgonine

an organic chemical found naturally in coca leaves

Echt

German for "bona fide"

eclectic

originating from a diverse variety of sources

econometrics

the application of quantitative and statistical methods to the study of economics

ectopic labor

pregnancy in the fallopian tube

ectoplasm

the supposed emanation of the soul from the body; here used as a metaphor for vomit

edema

swelling due to excess fluid

Edina MN

a suburb of Minneapolis-St. Paul about 3 miles southwest

Edmonton

Presumably Edmonton, Alberta.; the capital of Alberta

EEC

European Economic Community

EEG

electroencephalogram — an array of sensors fitted on the scalp that record electrical activity in the brain

effete

Overrefined.; degenerate or decadent

effluvia

invisible exhalations of noxious vapors

effulgence

shining brilliance

egregulous

Not a real word (possibly egregious(outstandingly bad or shocking) + ridiculous). See the blog post at Infinite Detox .

eidetic

referring to photographic memory

Eightball

an eighth of an ounce of cocaine

Eighty-Proof

40 percent alcohol

Eisenstein and Kurosawa and Michaux

Sergei Mikhailovich Eisenstein (1898-1948) was a Latvian-born Russian-Jewish filmmaker, famous for his film Battleship Potemkin . Akira Kurosawa (1910-1998) was perhaps the most prominent Japanese filmmaker of the twentieth century. Oscar Micheaux (1893-1951) was an African-American filmmaker.

ejaculatory

casting or throwing out

El Al

Israel's national airline

El Con Marriott

"El Con" is short for "El Conquistador," and while there is a Hilton El Conquistador Hotel in Tucson, the Marriot has a different name.

El Greco

El Greco (Spanish for "the Greek") was the byname of Doménicos Theotokópoulos (1541-1614), a Greek-Spanish painter. Presumably a "bad" El Greco, i.e., a bad piece of art by El Greco, would have the characteristics Hal considers in Pemulis's face.

Elder, Elders

James Olds, co-discovered the "pleasure center"

Eldred

This was the last name of the first Eagle Scout, Arthur Rose Eldred (1895-1951).

electric zirconium jewelry

Jewelry made of zircon . Electricity can be applied to a zircon to make a lamp.

electrolysis

the removal of hair roots or small blemishes on the skin by the application of heat using an electric current.

electrolysistic

resulting from electrolysis, the removal of hair using electric shocks

electrostatic

giving off erratic static electricity

elemonade

eliminate

Eliotical

referring to T.S. Eliot, author of The Waste Land

elision

the process of joining together or merging things, especially abstract ideas

elisions and apical lapses

Elisions are the droppings of phonemes from words. Apical refers to sounds made using the tip of the tongue; lapses would be absences of such sounds.

Elizabeth Harper Neeld's Seven Choices: Taking the Steps to New Life After Losing Someone You Love

A real book, it's actually 343 pages. (The 1997 edition is 343 pages, but an earlier publishing may have been 352.)

Elmer's

a brand of glue

EM

probably denoting "electromagnetic"; electromagnetic

Embolism

A sudden blocking of an artery.

embossed

decorated with a raised design

embryoglio

i.e., imbroglio; probably meaning imbroglio : an extremely confused, complicated, or embarrassing situation

emergent

just coming out

Emerson College

a college in Boston

emery board

A disposable nail file.; nail file

emetics

drugs designed to make one vomit

eminence grise

French for "gray eminence," this is a powerful adviser or decision-maker.

Eminent nondomain

"Eminent domain" is the right of the government to seize private property to serve a greater good. This would be the opposite, i.e., the right of the government to divest or cede private property to serve the greater good.

EMP

electromagnetic pulse

empathy

one's ability to feel the emotions of another person

empiricist

describing drivers orienting themselves by experience, rather than paying close attention; 'naively empiricist' probably means that they are reacting to their immediate experience without thinking

emulsion

Emulsion is colloidal suspension of one liquid in another.

En Nebk

a city in Syria, not far from Damascus

enervated

weakened

Enfield

A fictional town just west of Boston, where parts of the real Boston neighborhoods of Brighton and Allston exist in reality. There used to be a real Enfield in western Massachusetts but it was disincorporated in 1938 and flooded by the creation of the Quabbin Reservoir.

enfilade

a word used to denote a type of military gunfire. A formation or position is "in enfilade" if weapons fire can be directed along its length. For instance, a column of marching troops is enfiladed if fired on from the front rather than the side.

enjambment

the breaking of a line at the end of a verse (in a poem, song, etc.)

enkephalin

A type of painkiller

ennui

listlessness or dissatisfaction through a lack of occupation or excitement

ensconce

to establish or settle firmly or comfortably

entomologic

Entomology is the study of insects.

entomological icecubes

fake (plastic) icecubes with insects seemingly frozen inside

entomologist

a person who studies insects scientifically

entr' acte

French: between acts

entr'actes

the periods between dramatic performances

entrepreneurism

usually entrepreneurship

Entrepôt

a port, city, or other center to which goods are brought for import and export, and for collection and distribution.; a place where stolen goods are stored and sold from

entrepôt

French for "warehouse," this is where foreign merchandise can be purchased duty-free; a place for storing and dispensing goods

Enuresis

bed-wetting

EPA

Environmental Protection Agency

epaulets

Military shoulder decorations on clothing.

ephebe

a young man between the ages of 18 and 20 undergoing training, especially for combat; Usually an adolescent male, although sometimes a term for an adolescent of any sex, as here. (Derived from a Greek graduation tradition)

ephebes

An ephebe is an adolescent male.

ephebic

relating to a stage of life commonly known as young adult; no longer a teenager but not quite an adult

epicene

having characteristics of both sexes; androgynous

epidermal

of or pertaining to the outermost layer of skin

epiglottal

having to do with the epiglottis

epigrammatic

of or pertaining to the use of short and pithy statements

epiphanic

adjective form of "epiphany," a moment of sudden and great revelation or realization (Oxford Dictionary of English).

epiphanyish

An epiphany is a divine manifestation, or by extension, a sudden, deep insight.

epithet

an adjective or descriptive phrase expressing a quality characteristic of the person or thing mentioned.

Epsom salts

Magnesium sulfate, used to relieve pain, among other uses.

equanimity

mental or emotional stability

equatorial

lying on the Equator

equivocation

ambiguity

equivocationary

not a real word; but of course equivocate means to deceive, so, perhaps "deceptive"?

Equus Reese

Equus is Latin for "horse."

ergine

Also called LSA, it's found in morning glory seeds

ergo

Latin: therefore

ergotic of St. Anthony

An old name for ergot poisoning is "St. Anthony's fire," which is ergot poisoning. However, given the context, Wallace may be referring here to shingles.

Ergotics

Effects of poisonous fungus that can infect grains. It has convulsive and gangrenous symptoms. Overuse of Methylergometrine and Ergotamine (which is a migraine medication) can also cause the disease.

Erlenmeyer Flasks

Read about them here .T

Ernest Feaster

Possible reference to Ernest Hemingway, "A Moveable Feast".

ersatz

an inferior substitute

erudite

scholarly

erumpent

1. bursting forth. 2. (of fungi or algae) prominent; projecting from or bursting through host tissue.; bursting forth; bursting forth

Erythema

does not appear to be an actual suburb of Tucson. The word means redness of the skin as the result of various causes, including infection and sunburn.

Erythema AZ

not a real town, but erythema is a real disease

Eschaton

The name of the game is based on "eschatology" (from the Greek ἔσχατος, Eschatos meaning "last" and -logy meaning "the study of") which is a part of theology and philosophy concerned with what is believed to be the final events in the history of the world, or the ultimate destiny of humanity, commonly referred to as the end of the world. Wikipedia

Eschatonic

The name of the game is based on the same root as eschatology, i.e., the study of the end of the world.

Escherian

referring to the work of Maurits Cornelis (M.C.) Escher (1898-1972), a Dutch graphic artist famous for his illustrations of repeated patterns and impossible structures. "Escherian signs" would seem to indicate signs that are confusing or impossible to follow.

escudo

Spanish for shield

escutcheon

a shield-shaped emblem

esoteric

understood or recognized by few people

espadrilles

shoes popular in Latin America with rope for soles

EST and Greenwich Mean

Eastern Standard Time and Greenwich Mean Time, the latter of which is determined at the Prime Meridian, or 0º longitude

Estonian

the native population of Estonia

Estuarial crocodile

the estuarine (saltwater) crocodile

Ethel Merman

an American actress, primarily known for her roles in Broadway musicals wikipedia

Ethiopian spear chuckers

Reference to the Second Italo-Ethiopian War, when Mussolini's heavily armed and mechanized Italian invading forces took on Haile Selassi's Army of the Ethiopian Empire. Despite the fact that many of the Abyssinians were equipped with little more than spears or bows they managed to give the Italians a good run for their money, but against tanks and aerial bombardments of mustard gas the result was inevitable.

Etienne Aigner

a fashionable leather goods manufacturer

etiology

the cause of a disease; the cause or source of a medical problem; cause of a disease or condition

Euclid

Euclid of Alexandria was a 4th century BC Greek mathematician and "father of geometry."

Eureka

Ancient Greek for "I've found it," made famous by Archimedes

Eurotrochaic

neologism: Euro[pean] + trochaic; here, describing the alternating two-note sound of a European emergency siren (trochaic being the adjectival form of "trochee," a metrical foot of poetry comprised of two feet, stressed and unstressed)

eustacian-crumbling

The Eustachian tube connects the inner ear to the throat; this compound adjective would mean "deafeningly loud."

Eve Arden

Eve Arden (1908-1990) was an American actress. But Mario seems to be thinking of Elizabeth Arden (1884-1966), who founded a cosmetics company.

Eve Plumb

She played Jan Brady on The Brady Bunch .

Evel Knievel

Robert Craig "Evel" Knievel, Jr. (1938-2007), was an American motorcycle daredevil.

Evensong

the evening prayer of the Episcopal church

Everclear

a brand of pure grain alcohol

Evert

Christine Marie Evert (born 1954) was a former American tennis player with eighteen grand slam wins.

evince

reveal the presence of (a quality or feeling).

ex officio

Latin: by virtue of one's office

excretate

i.e., extricate

exhortation

a speech or discourse that encourages, incites, or earnestly advises

Exocet

a type of missile

exoskeletally

meaning in the manner of a creature with an exoskeleton, which is to say having the structural material on the outside, with insects being a prime example

expatriates

people living outside their countries of origin

expectorants

drugs that induce phlegm-producing coughing

Experialism

apparently another Wallace neologism, presumably the antonym of imperialism, and thus perhaps "empire-dismantling" as opposed to "empire-building"

experialist

Like "imperialist," but rather than incorporating outside things into itself, an experialist entity exports things outside itself that are not wanted; in the case of O.N.A.N., toxic waste.

explicated

analyzed and developed in detail

exploded

shown to be false or unfounded

extant

still existing

Extreme Value Theorem

This is explained here .

extrication

freedom from entanglement

extruding

i.e., exuding

exurbs

towns too far away from cities to be called "suburbs" but not far enough to be rural

eyeshot

Visual play on 'earshot'

EZ-Widers

a brand of cigarette rolling papers

EZC

i.e., "easy see"

f-stop

The ratio of the focal length ( f ) of a lens or lens system to the effective diameter of its aperture " ( American Heritage Dictionary of the English Language, Fourth Edition ).

f-term

i.e., "fag"

F.A.A.

Federal Aviation Administration

F.C.

F.E.C.

F.L.Q.

F.R.G.

Federal Republic of Germany, which is the technical name for Germany today, but referred to West Germany in the days of divided Germany (1945-1989).

F/X

f/x

special effects in film

F16s

American fighter jets

facial affect

Emotions expressed on the face.

Facsmile

probably a misspelling of "facsimile"

factota

plural for factotum, which is a word for a servant or assistant

fairly high-sodium way

i.e., with a grain (or more) of salt

falcate

to curve like a sickle

Fall River

a city in Massachusetts about 50 miles south of Boston

fallow

plowed and harrowed but left unsown for a period in order to restore its fertility as part of a crop rotation or to avoid surplus production

Falls Church VA

a city about ten miles west of Washington, D.C. Also very close to Langley, VA (home of the CIA).

falsetto

a man's voice when he pitches it falsely high to sound like a woman

Falstaff

a brand of beer discontinued in 2005

familiar foil packet

i.e., a condom

fantods

A state of fidgetiness, uneasiness, or unreasonableness; nervous depression or apprehension; "the fidgets;" "the creeps;" "the willies." See online dictionary here

Farberware

a brand name of pots and pans

fast film

maybe he means a fast lens it has a larger max aperture making it able to have a faster shutter speed with less light. Faster shutter speed means the movement will blur less.

fatally pulchritudinous

deadly good-looking

Father & Son Market...Riley's Roast Beef

all of these are references to actual stores and clubs in Allston/Brighton, though many have closed or been renamed and some are on nearby streets and would not be visible to Gately as he drives down Comm. Ave.

Faulknerian

recollecting the style or manner of William Cuthbert Faulkner (1897-1962), American novelist

fauna

wildlife

faute-de-mieux

for lack of something better.

fealty

faithfulness, here to a sports team

feather snake

feather boa - a feathered scarf

febrile

feck

efficacy; force; value.

fedoras

A fedora is a soft felt hat that is creased lengthwise down the crown and pinched in the front on both sides. Similar hats with a C-crown (with an indentation for the head in the top of the crown) are occasionally called fedoras. (see right) Wikipedia

feeling punk

Defined as "weak in spirits or health" in the American Heritage Dictionary of the English Language.

Feenian

possibly "fenian", referring to a breed of horse or to both the Fenian Brotherhood and Irish Republican Brotherhood, two organizations dedicated to the establishment of an independent Irish republic

feinted

acted in a way to cause a diversion

feldspar

a rock-forming mineral

Felicity Zweig

"Felicity" means happiness, while Zweig is German for "stick" or "branch."

felo de se

Latin for "felony against one's self," this is a term for suicide.

femur to tarsus

The femur is the bone running from the hip to the knee — the largest bone in the body. The tarsi (plural of tarsus) are the bones of the foot. In between are the tibia and fibula — the bones of the lower leg — and the patella, or kneecap. All of these were apparently broken.

fence

to sell stolen goods

fencing

to sell stolen goods

fenestrated

Fenestration 1 : the arrangement, proportioning, and design of windows and doors in a building.; having windows

fenestration

the arrangement of windows and doors on the elevations of a building

Ferragamos

an Italian brand of shoes

ferric oxide

i.e., iron oxide, or rust

ferrous

containing iron

festoon

here used to mean decorate ; the noun festoon refers to a garland of flowers, leaves, ribbons, or other objects (as with strung cranberries or popcorn or even paper chains on a Christmas tree), usually suspended in catenary swags

festschrift

In German, a Festschrift is a celebratory monograph dedicated to a person.

feti

plural of fetus

fezzes

Turkish- or Middle-Eastern-style hats (see right); worn by Shriners

FHC

acronym for "fluorohydrocarbon," this is a type of fluroplastic, known to give off poisonous fumes

fiat

official sanction

fiberboard

board made of small fibers of wood, plastic, or some combination of these and other materials

fibrosis

scarring

fictile

capable of being molded

field series generator

probably a shunt generator

fieldstone

a type of construction material

fifth post

You get the picture.

fifth wall

The "fourth wall" is a term used in theater to describe the imaginary wall that separates the stage from the audience. The "fifth wall" could be an extrapolation of this concept, meaning a wall separating an actor from a critic or separating two people sharing the same experience.; The "fourth wall" is a term used in theater to describe the imaginary wall that separates the stage from the audience. The "fifth wall" could be an extrapolation of this concept, meaning a wall separating an actor from a critic, or separating two people sharing the same experience notably when viewing projected or broadcasted media. Or possibly simply a reference to the fact that rooms tend not to have fifth walls, meaning that his face was never there.

fifty kilos

a little over 110 pounds

Filene's

former department store in the Boston area, now owned by Macy's; a Boston-based department store (and chain), defunct since December 2011

filial

pertaining to a son or daughter; pertaining to a son or daughter

filigree

intricate ornamentation usually consisting of twisted metal wire/ribbons on, say, a fence

filigreed

finely and elaborately ornamented work, usually made out of wire

fillip

to smack one's finger against by pressing the finger against the thumb and releasing

fillips

a sharp tap, "made by bending the last joint of a finger against the thumb and suddenly releasing it (so as to propel some small object, or merely as a gesture)" (OED)

film-noir

According to Wikipedia, film noir (French for "dark film") is "a cinematic term used primarily to describe stylish Hollywood crime dramas, particularly those that emphasize moral ambiguity and sexual motivation. Hollywood's classic film noir period is generally regarded as stretching from the early 1940s to the late 1950s."

filmic

having to do with motion pictures

fin

a slang term for a $5 bill

fingerling

something very small

finial

an architectural device used to top a gable

finials

decorative ornaments placed on the apex of roofs

Finlandization

This is defined as "the influence that one powerful country may have on the policies of a smaller neighboring country" and refers to Finland's relations with the USSR following WWII.

finski

undoubtedly a five-dollar bill, from its old nickname fin; slang: $5 bill

fireman's carry

to carry someone by draping them over your shoulder

fireman-carrying

carrying a person over one's shoulder

fish-eye lens

a type of wide-angle lens

fish-in-a-gaff

e.g., fish on a hook

fishtailing

having the back end of one's car spinning

fisticuffery

fist-fighting

Fitviavi

fit via vi is a Latin phrase from Book II of The Aeneid, line 494, that can be translated as “the way is forged by strength” or “Force finds a road.”

fitviavi

apparently a coined word

five m.

almost 16.5 feet

flange

a plate or ring to form a rim at the end of a pipe when fastened to the pipe; a protruding rim, edge, rib, or collar, as on a wheel or a pipe shaft, used to strengthen an object, hold it in place, or attach it to another object

flanges

Orin probably means to say "phalanges."

flask-alkie

i.e., an alcoholic who carries a hip flask containing a small amount (8-12 oz.) of liquor

flats

women's shoes without heels

flatulence

farting

fleen

Thrust's past tense of flee (à la "flown")

Flents

a brand name of earplugs

Flexor carpi ulnaris muscle

Muscle in the side of the forearm, used to twist the hand side to side, thus important when tossing playing cards.

float

i.e., the money keeping them afloat (figuratively)

florid

flowery in style

flounces

strips of decorative material

fluffy cumuli arrayed patternlessly against an overenhanced blue sky, incredibly disorienting ... makes him feel high-altitude and disoriented and sometimes plummeting

this pattern appears on the cover of the book

flummoxed

flummoxing

fluted

fly-by-night

flying sod

He's referring to divots, i.e., bits of the fairway that get torn up when a golf ball is hit.

foamer

fob

foist

to insert deceitfully

foment

To foment is to instigate or stir up but the proper word here would be "ferment"

fools-rush-in

A reference to An Essay on Man, a lengthy poem by Alexander Pope (1688-1744), a British poet of great renown: No Place so Sacred from such Fops is barr'd, Nor is Paul's Church more safe than Paul's Church-yard: Nay, fly to Altars; there they'll talk you dead; For Fools rush in where Angels fear to tread.

foot-treadle

a lever worked by foot

foran

foreign

Ford Mystique

See one here .

Ford's Theater

This is the theater where President Lincoln was assassinated.

Forest Lawn NNY

a town in New York state, on Lake Ontario

formants and fricatives, trochaically stressed

A formant is, according to Wikipedia, "a peak in an acoustic frequency spectrum which results from the resonant frequencies of any acoustic system." A fricative is a phoneme produced by forcing air through tight lips. In English, fricatives are /s/, /z/, /th/, and /zh/. Trochaically means spoken in trochees, or a metrical foot on two syllables with the stress on the first (the word "trochee" is a trochee).

formicating

moving like ants

formication

medical term for the sensation of insects crawling on or under the skin

formulating

forming

Fort Point

a section of Boston named for a colonial-era fort of the same name

four horsemen

as in the Four Horsemen of the Apocalypse from the Book of Revelation

four kilgrams

about 8.8 pounds

four meters

a little over thirteen feet.

four-km.

almost 2.5 miles

Four-odd clicks

Four clicks is four kilometers, or about 2.5 miles.

four-point stances

with both hands and both feet on the ground

Fourier, Gauss, LaPlace, Rickey

Jean Baptiste Joseph Fourier (1768-1830) was a French mathematician and physicist. Johann Carl Friedrich Gauss (1777-1855) was a German mathematician. Pierre-Simon, marquis de Laplace (1749-1827) was a French mathematician and astronomer. Rickey would seem to refer to V. Frederick Rickey, though he is contemporary while the other named men are not.

Fourth- and Eighth-Step

two of the original Twelve Steps of the Alcoholics Anonymous program: 4) "Made a searching and fearless moral inventory of ourselves," and 8) "Made a list of all persons we had harmed, and became willing to make amends to them all"

fractal

A fractal is "a geometrical or physical structure having an irregular or fragmented shape at all scales of measurement between a greatest and smallest scale such that certain mathematical or physical properties of the structure, as the perimeter of a curve or the flow rate in a porous medium, behave as if the dimensions of the structure (fractal dimensions) are greater than the spatial dimensions" ( Random House Unabridged Dictionary ). Wikipedia entry...

fractious

unruly or angry

framed print of Lang directing Metropolis

see photo at left

Franciscan bald spot

The Orders of Friars Minor were known to shave the tops of their heads in medieval and early modern times.

Francophonic

French-speaking

Frankenstein

or, more correctly, Frankenstein's monster

Frankies and Tonies

likely a reference to crooners of the Frank Sinatra and Tony Bennett ilk

Franklin W. Dixon

the pseudonym of the author of the Hardy Boys mysteries

freakas

fracas

Fred MacMurray

Fredrick Martin MacMurray (1908-1991) was an American film and television actor, referenced here for his starring role as the father in the hit television show My Three Sons .

Freddie-Mac

common name for the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Company

Fredericton, N.B.

Fredericton is the capital of the Canadian province of New Brunswick (N.B.) about 175 miles as the crow flies (much longer if you drive it) from Halifax, Nova Scotia, the nearest "big city" in that part of Canada.

freezing point of platinum

If the melting point of platinum is 3214.9 ° F, then at any temperature below this, it will be solid, i.e., frozen.

fremitic

characterized by tremor vibrations in any part of the body

French-curled

You can see French-curled jewelry here .

FRESH-KILLED CHICKEN

see note for page 479

fricatives

consonants produced by forcing air through an occluded passage, e.g., f and s

fridgelettes

small refrigerators ("dorm-sized" in the sense of small enough to fit in a dormitory room, not the size of a dorm)

frieze

a decorative band on a wall or other piece of architecture

fringe-Birchism

Birchism is adherence to the principles of the John Birch Society, an ultra-right-wing political organization

frisson

a sudden sense of excitement

Fritz Lang

Friedrich Christian Anton "Fritz" Lang (1890-1976) was a Viennese-born Austrian-American director. His science fiction film Metropolis (1927) presents a dystopian future where people are oppressed by technology.

from stage right

in the other words, from the left (or "house left," which is equivalent to "stage right")

FROM SYRACUSE TO TICONDEROGA, NY

This line would go right through Adirondack Park in New York.

FROM TICODEROGA, NY TO SALEM, MA

The lower corner of Vermont lies below this line.

Frontenac

probably a reference to the Battle of Fort Frontenac during the French and Indian Wars, where the British defeated the French

frothy biblical saw

a trifling or empty biblical proverb

frustum

A frustum is a truncated cone or pyramid, or specifically "the part of a conical solid left after cutting off a top portion with a plane parallel to the base" ( Random House Unabridged Dictionary ).; This is "the part of a conical solid left after cutting off a top portion with a plane parallel to the base" ( Random House Unabridged Dictionary ).

Ft. Chimo

another name for Kuujjuaq, Québec, in the Arctic Circle

fuchsia

brilliant ("hot") pink, the color of the flower of the same name; hot pink

Fuck the Core

i.e., fuck the (Marine) Corps

fugue-state

According to Wikipedia, a fugue state is "a state of mind characterized by abandonment of personal identity, along with the memories, personality and other identifying characteristics of individuality."

fulcra

plural of "fulcrum"

fulcrum

a support or point of rest

fulgurant

flashing like lightning

fuliginous

smoky or sooty

full-toll

i.e., it takes its full toll on you

fullback

a running back whose primary job is blocking; in the I-formation, the fullback is between the quarterback and the halfback in terms of distance from the line of scrimmage

fuller's earth or sawdust

Fuller's earth is an absorbent clay that is used in talcum powder. Sawdust and chalk (talcum) are used by tennis players to keep their grip dry. [2]

fulvous

in color, yellow-gray to yellowish-brown

fumigated

permeated with gas to kill insects

Function x, exponent n, the derivative's going to be nx + x(n-1)

Permulis appears to have misspoken. The derivative of x to the nth power is n times x to the (n - 1) power, not nx plus x to the (n - 1)th power.

Fundy

probably a reference to the Bay of Fundy

fungoes

In baseball a fungo is a pop fly deliberately hit to train players in fielding. Presumably here, in tennis, these balls are hit in a deliberate place in a deliberate manner to exercise a particular skill.

funiculi

plural of "funiculus," i.e., part of the spinal cord

furcated

branching or forking

furriners

dialect pronunciation of "foreigners"

furtive

shifty or sneaky

futon

a Japanese-style pallet or mattress that can be folded into a sofa or open like a bed; many futons have adjustable frames, but some simply fold up along a wall for seating until unfolded when needed for sleeping

Futurist

referring to Italian Futurism, an art movement on the early 20th century

G. Ford - early G. Bush

Roughly 1974 to 1989.

G. T. Day, M.S.

Geoffrey Day, of Ennet House, who claims to have "manned the helm of a Scholarly Quarterly" at "some jr. college up the Expressway in Medford" (272). Before the author is mentioned, the article is said to have come from "someplace called Bayside Community College up I-93 in Medford." Wild Conceits, the publication, is said to be edited by the author of the article Struck is ripping off.

G.C.

Government of Canada, perhaps. It may also mean some type of transmitter that can interfere with a pacemaker (which Marathe's father has).

G.C./M.S.

Gas Chromatography - Mass Spectrometry, a means of drug detection

G.E.D.

General Equivalency Degree, the equivalent of a US high school diploma, earned by passing a test. The GED is a way for someone who failed to complete high school to earn a high school diploma later in life.

G.F.R. Co.

perhaps Global Food Resources

G.O.P.s

Republicans, G.O.P. standing for "Grand Old Party"

G.S.L.

Guaranteed Student Loan

G.W. Pabst

Georg Wilhelm Pabst (1885-1967) was a Bohemian-born Austrian filmmaker.

Gaelic

i.e., the Irish language

gaffed fish

caught with a very large hook

Gallic

French

galumphers

Galumph is a portmanteau of gallop and triumph. From Lewis Carroll's Jabberwocky

gambrel

here referring to a double-sloping roof, as often seen on barns and some churches

gamma hydroxybutric acid

now more commonly known as GHB

gamma-refractive

Referring to a certain index of refraction, i.e., a measure of how much the speed of light is slowed down under certain conditions.

gander

A gander, as used here, is a look or peek.

gangrenously tight

I.e., so tight as to cause gangrene, i.e., death of tissue due to lack of blood

Gapers' Blocks

traffic delays caused by rubbernecking, i.e., blocking or retarding traffic by stopping to gape at the scene of an accident

Garfield

Garfield is a cat from a daily-syndicated comic strip of the same name. ( Wikipedia ) See right »

Gargantuan

Since PW is an after school program that only charges tuition for those who can afford to pay; it can hardly be called Gargantuan. It calls itself a Tennis Academy on it's website but it can hardly be compared to ETA . The word Gargantuan brings to mind François Rabelais 16th century story of Garganua, a story which can be considered a point-by-point critique of the educational practices of the age and promoting free education. So then PW could be compared to The Abby of Thélème

gargoyle

a small statue of a monster used to adorn churches and other buildings to ward off evil

garish

loud and flashy; crudely colorful

garrulousness

propensity to ramble

Garçon!

French: Boy! (used in reference to the waiter)

gas range

a gas powered oven and stove

gasper

cigarette

Gaspé Peninsula

a region in northern Québec

Gately's Humorous ball and Scalpula socket

referring to the humerus (largest bone of the arm, between the shoulder and elbow) and the ball and socket joint of the shoulder, the blade of which is called the scapula

gauche

from the French for "left" but here meaning "crude" or "socially unacceptable"

Gaudeamus Igitur

Latin: " so let us rejoice", an ancient academic drinking song now popular as a graduation hymn, whose text pokes fun at university life and urges students to enjoy life while they can.

Gaugin

Eugène Henri Paul Gauguin (1848-1903) was a French artist who lived in Tahiti.

Gauguin-colored

Gauloise

a French brand of cigarettes

gauntlet

an attack from all sides

gavel

the type of hammer a judge uses to restore or maintain order

GE/RCA

geatalt

a misprint of gestalt

Geiger counter

a machine used to measure radioactivity

gendarmes

usually denoting the police force of France or a formerly French nation, here simply meaning law enforcement agencies

gender-dysphoric

a person suffering from gender identity disorder

genuflecting

kneeling to the ground on one knee, esp. to convey respect

genuflectory

servilely respectful (to the extent of kneeling before)

George Will

George Frederick Will (born 1941) is a conservative American columnist. Wallace implies that he has had his voicebox removed and now speaks with a prosthetic voicebox.

gerontologic

having to do with the study of old age

gerundives

the verbal adjective or present participle―in English, these end in "ing";

gestalt

Gestalt is "a configuration, pattern, or organized field having specific properties that cannot be derived from the summation of its component parts" ( Random House Unabridged Dictionary ).

ghastlyly

even funnier coming from someone with a first name ending in -ly ; simply ghastly functions as the adverb (rarely) as well as the adjective (could Molly be lalating?); see note for Page 788 supra

GI-X-Ray-Grade Colonic Purgative

the kind of laxatives given to people about to undergo colonoscopies (GI meaning Gastro-intestinal)

gibber

to chatter unintelligibly

gibbous

bulging outwards: the shape of the moon when it is neither full, nor crescent, nor half, i.e., when it is more than half full

gigantism

excessive or abnormally large growth in humans, also giantism; excessive growth

Gila monster

a venomous lizard native to the Southwest U.S. and Mexico, known for its tenacious bite

still not a real player

gloaming

Gloeckner

German for "ringer," taking that in either of the meanings it has in English

glottal

involving the epiglottis in pronunication

glottal stop

An unvoiced consonant made by constricting the vocal tract. It is not present in written English, but is common in speech, particularly regional variants such as cockney, where, for example, it replaces the 't' sound in many words: "better", pronounced "be'er" or "city": "ci'y". It is also commonly heard as the consonant separating the two vowel sounds in "uh-oh".

gluteal

pertaining to the buttocks

gluteal hyperadiposity

excessive fat in the buttocks

glutens

a mixture of wheat proteins

glycemically

in a manner that is motivated or caused by the level of sugar in the blood

glycine

one of the 20 amino acids found in proteins; however, DFW probably meant to say 'glassine bags'

glyph

a symbolic figure that is usually engraved or incised

gnarled

knotty and misshappen

gneiss

a form of metamorphic rock

gnomes

God! Help!

Godbout

Jacques Godbout, a French-Canadian filmmaker and documentarian.

goes tactical

enters the phase of using tactical nuclear weapons

Goncharov's Oblomov

Ivan Alexandrovich Goncharov (1812-1891) was a Russian novelist and author of Oblomov, which can be read here . The book is about a young man too lazy to act or decide; he doesn't leave his bed for the first 150 pages.

gone rye

i.e., gone awry

gonfalonish

resembling a gonfalon

gonions

the outer points on either side of the lower jaw at which the jawbone angles upward

goo

over-the-top sentimentality

Good Morning, Midnight and Maggie: A Girl of the Streets and Giovanni's Room and Under the Volcano

Good Morning, Midnight is a novel by Jean Rhys (1890-1979), born Ella Gwendolen Rees Williams, a Caribbean novelist, on the topic of a woman forced to confront her own loneliness and despair. Maggie: A Girl of the Streets is a novel by Stephen Crane (1871-1900), an American novelist, on the topic of a child prostitute. Giovanni's Room by African-American expatriate author James Arthur Baldwin (1924-1987) is a novel on the topic of a young man coming to terms with his homosexuality. Under the Volcano is a novel by Malcolm Lowry (1909-1957), a British writer, on the topic of alcoholism.

Good prince Hal

Falstaff addresses the future King Henry V in this manner in Act II, scene ii, of I Henry IV .

Although the Filmography says it is UNRELEASED, Hal apparently has a copy in the Viewing Room. Cf. Page 991.

Goodwill

a charity that redistributes donated goods and clothing

gourmand

a food aficionado

gout

a disease characterized by the collection of uric acid in the joints

Governor Claprood

possibly a misspelled Marjorie Clapprood, who was the Democratic nominee for Massachusetts Lieutenant Governor in 1990.

grackles

passernine birds native to North America

gram-negative

This refers to a bacterium that does not show up in a violet stain using Gram's method; in other words, the doctor suspects that Gately has a particularly resistant strain of bacteria within his body, which previous antibiotics given to him have been ineffective in eliminating.

Grand Mall epilepsy

Gately means grand mal .

grange

shorthand for the Granger movement, here used in the generic sense of organizing, as of labor

Granny Smith

a type of sour, green-skinned apple

Grant's Tomb

The trick answer to the question is "no one." As the tomb is above ground, Ulysses S. Grant is technically "entombed" and not "buried." The obvious answer is Grant himself, and, in fact, he and his wife Julia are both entombed there. The General Grant National Memorial overlooks the Hudson River, in Riverside Park in Manhattan (New York).

granulomatous

having masses of ulcerated infections of the skin

gratis

free of charge

greeble

a small piece of detailing added to break up the surface of an object to add visual interest

greebles

Here, Joelle means little wads of paper resulting from worrying the wet tissue. There is another use of greeble, but she is not referring here to background treatments for films. The "little bits of sleepy goo you got in your eyes' corners" (two paragraphs following) are the thin mucous discharges ('eye boogers') known as rheum .

Green Valley AZ

a city in Arizona about 22.5 miles due south of Tucson

green-card Irishman

an Irishman who is a permanent resident non-citizen of the U.S.

Green-Cardless

not having permanent resident status and, thus, an illegal alien

green-gilled

i.e., green about the gills, about to vomit

greensward

stretch of grassy turf

Greg

the eldest son, played by Barry Williams

gregarious

sociable

gregariously

in a sociable manner

Gregg pen

Gregg is a phonetic shorthand writing system for stenographers, devised by John Robert Gregg and first published in 1888. The rights to Gregg shorthand were owned by the Gregg Publishing Company, founded in 1896. The Gregg company licensed pen manufacturers to produce pens to Gregg’s specifications and use the Gregg name; these pens are relatively thin and have very firm fine nibs. Some Gregg pens were fitted with an enameled Gregg emblem inlaid into the end of the cap, as shown at left on a Wahl pen from the late 1920s. here. Read more about Gregg shorthand here and Gregg pens here.

Gregg shorthand

a form of stenography developed in the U.S. in 1888

Gretel the Cross-Sectioned Dairy Cow

Cornell University apparently has a cow whose stomachs you can see in action.

grippe

flu

grouper

a family of fish including sea basses

GTE

General Telephone and Electronics

guano

feces, particularly of birds or bats

guile

insidious cunning

Guillaume DuPlessis

A man by this name was one of the first French Calvinist settlers on the island of St. Kitts in the 17th century.

guilloche

"an ornamental pattern or border, as in architecture, consisting of paired ribbons or lines flowing in interlaced curves around a series of circular voids" ( Random House Unabridged Dictionary ); see below; Hal is referring to an ornamental molding of the kind shown below.; the most annular of the ornamental moldings used in interior decoration (see below)

gulag

a reference to the GULAG prison system of the Soviet Union

By context, it would seem this word is a synonym for aglet .

The Web site is here . Kaiserlautern means something like "Emperor acclamation" in German and is a city in southwest Germany.

Habitant

a French Canadian brand of pea soup

Habitant soupe aux pois

Habitant is Québecois French for "farmer," though it seems like a brand name here. Soupe aux pois is pea soup, very popular in Québec. Habitant is in fact a Canadian brand of soup made by the Campbell Company of Canada.

habitements

a neologism, probably just referring to the habits the nuns wear

hackles

the erectile hairs on the back of a dog which rise up out of fear or aggression

hackysackers

players of a game (hacky sack) where people in a circle kick a small leather bag around to one another (see "game with a small beanbaggy ball" on page 623)

haggard

fatigued and unwell

Hagia Sophia and S. Simeon

Hagia Sophia is a mosque in Istanbul that had been a Byzantine basilica. S. Simeon refers to the ruins of a monastery named for Simeon Stylites .

hagiography

the biography of a saint

Hal

who is clearly not narrating anymore, unless he is speaking of himself in the third person

Halcion (still available in Canada, unbelievably, still)

halcyon

hale

free from disease or infirmity.; healthy

nearly 20 inches; about 1.64 feet; 1.64 feet; about 1.64 feet; about 1.64 feet

half nelson

a wrestling hold with the offensive competitor's arm wrapped under the opponent's arm and over the opponent's neck from behind, allowing an opponent to be immobilized or levered from behind

half consisting of living cells, i.e., half-dead

Haplology

in speech, the elision of one of two consecutive, identical syllables, e.g., "probly" for "probably" (see the Wikipedia entry for further examples, including "haplogy," the kind of in-joke that philologists enjoy)

harelip

vernacular, arguably offensive, term for a cleft lip; also known as cleft lip or cleft palate
