He had the great fatigue...

A less literal translation would be: "He was very tired..."

he thinks a manila folder's a Filipino contortionist

Manila being the capital of the Philippines

he was indeed inebriated...while she...would tomorrow still be hideously and improbably deformed.

Many versions of this witty exchange between Winston Churchill and a woman have been propagated over the the years. It may or may not have actually occurred.

head

bathroom; toilet; bathroom

Head is body.

Incandenza's father is expressing a non-Cartesian point of view. René Descartes (1596-1650), the French polymath, separated the mind ( res cogitans ) from the body ( res extensa ).

Heathkit

The company's Web site is here .

Heavy Water

water in which the hydrogen in the molecules is partly or wholly replaced by the isotope deuterium, used esp. as a moderator in nuclear reactors

Hefenreffer

a misspelling of Haffenreffer, a Boston brewery

Hegel

Georg Wilhelm Friedrich Hegel (1770-1831) was a highly influential German philosopher.

Heideggerian

Martin Heidegger (1889-1976) was a prominent twentieth-century German philosopher and proponent of existentialism.

Heimlich

The Heimlich maneuver, named for contemporary American physician Henry Jay Heimlich, dislodges food from a choking person's trachea by applying sharp pressure to the abdomen.

Heimliched

employed the Heimlich maneuver to forcibly dislodge an obstacle, such as a food particle, that is causing choking

Heineken Maneuver

Gately means "Heimlich Maneuver."

Heisenbergian

Werner Karl Heisenberg (1901-1976) was a German physicist and one of the fathers of quantum mechanics.

Helen and Paris. He of Troy.

Paris, a Trojan prince, kidnapped Helen from Menelaus, precipitating the Trojan War.

Heliotrope

An arrangement of mirrors for reflecting sunlight from a distant point to an observation station.

heliotropes

flowering plants of the genus heliotropium (sample at right), so-named because their blossoms turn toward the sun

hemispasm

spasm on half of the face

hemoptysis

coughing up blood

hemotoxicity

Poisonous blood level.

Hempstead, Long Island

a town in New York about 25 miles into Long Island, about halfway between the North and South shores

Henderson

Florence Henderson, who played Carol Brady

Hennessey

a brand of cognac

hepatitis-G

This disease had been identified the same year that Wallace published Infinite Jest . It's unclear whether he was aware of this.

herbicide

something that kills plants

Hercules

the Greek hero who lost his mind, murdered his family, and was forced to suffer twelve labors as punishment, including calming a three-headed dog, clearing dung from the Augean stables, and stealing apples of infinite joy; compared here to Gately ("head was square"), who lost his mind as an addict and was forced into a twelve-step program, where he had to calm Pat M.'s dogs and clear shit from the Shattuck shelter (he previously stole the master to the Entertainment). Hercules also borrowed Athena's chariot on occasion; Gately borrows Pat M.'s car.

Hermes

the messenger god of Greek mythology

herring

i.e., a red herring—a distraction

Hester Thrale

Hester Thrale was a literary figure of the 18th century. An associate and early biographer of Dr Samuel Johnson, her Anecdotes of the late Samuel Johnson (1786) was criticised by James Boswell as inaccurate. Her connection with the nail-biter and putative borderline personality is unclear.

heuristic

serving to indicate or point out

hex

i.e., hexagonal, having six sides

hiati

the plural of "hiatus"

hick

a person from a rural area

high D

the D (designated D6) that is two octaves above the D above middle C (C4); considered the upper limit of the dramatic soprano range

high-B#

Equivalent to the pitch of C, and vocally, the high C is two octaves above middle C.

high-lipid

high-fat

high-R-waste

probably refers to high radioactivity; Roentgen (R) is a standard for measuring radiation.

high-resin dope

generally high-quality marijuana, containing a high volume of resins where THC in marijuana plants is produced

high-water

pants hemmed too high

highatus

i.e., hiatus

highball

a family of mixed drinks

Higher Power

Most twelve-step drug or alcohol recovery programs teach a belief in God or a "Higher Power" (the latter to soften the blow to atheists).

Hillary R.C.

Hillary Rodham Clinton, the former First Lady, and Secretary of State under President Obama

Hillel

a nationwide (worldwide?) Jewish student union present on several campuses

Himself

Note that Incandenza's father calls his own father by the same nickname as Incandenza's children call him.

Himself's

An Incandenza family nickname for Hal's father, James O. Incandenza; the first reference to James O. Incandenza in the novel

Hindenburg

Named for Paul Ludwig Hans Anton von Beneckendorff und von Hindenburg (1847-1934), the German field marshal, hero of World War I, and last President of the Weimar Republic, the Hindenburg was a hydrogen-filled zeppelin that exploded over Lakehurst, N.J., on May 6, 1937.

Hindi

a national language of India and one of the most widely spoken

hinked

According to the OED, hink as a verb means "to halt" or "to falter." The implication here is that 90 days in jail isn't much to Gately since he'd already served 17 months in another sentence.

hip-flexors

the muscles that move the hip

hip-shot

one hip lower than the other.

hipshot

as if having a dislocated hip

hirsute

hairy; hairy

His Unforced-Error stats look like a decimal-error.

which is to say that the percentage expressed as a a decimal has so many leading zeros that it looks as if someone made a mistake transcribing the number

hoary dramaturgy

According to Wikipedia, dramaturgy is "the art of dramatic composition and the representation of the main elements of drama on the stage." To call it "hoary" would be to imply it's old.

Hobbesianly

in a way suggesting that people are very much in a state of nature, i.e., without rules or laws; derived from English philosopher Thomas Hobbes

hobnail boots

heavy-duty boots with hobnails, short, thick-headed nails used to protect footwear, on the soles to provide durability and traction on unfavorable terrain

hobnailed boots

boots assembled with hobnails

Hoits

i.e., "hurts"

holding his cheek and jaw when he talks like cutout photos of the late J. Benny

Comedian Jack Benny (1894-1974) would often hold his chin with his hand while addressing an audience. See Benny's statue in Cucamonga where he is holding his cheek and jaw [1] .

hole

total outstanding debt

hollandaise

a sauce that is an emulsion of butter and lemon juice using egg yolks; the sauce is usually a light buttery yellow in color

Holographically Mimetic

Approximating reality using holograms.

Homburg

A homburg is a stiff felt hat characterized by a single dent running down the center of the crown and a brim fixed in a tight, upwards curl. It is superficially similar to the trilby or fedora; trilbys and fedoras, however, have soft, "snappable" brims and can have various designs "pinched" into the crown, whereas the shape of a homburg is fixed. (see right) Wikipedia

homburg

a felt hat with a brim meant for a man

homodontic

having teeth of all one type (see endnote 119; in Mario's case, all his teeth are bicuspids, the two-pronged sort normally found between the canines and the molars); having teeth that are all of similar form (see page 316 and endnote 119)

homolosine-cartography

This is map-making based on an equal distribution of land, created by John Paul Goode (1862-1932), an American geographer. Goode did this to replace the Eurocentric Mercator projection .

homuncular

of or pertaining to a diminutive human being

hone

a whetstone used to sharpen blades

hoofer's cane

the cane of a tap dancer (which is what a hoofer is)

hoovered

inhaled

Hopman and van der Meer and Bollettieri

Harry Hopman, Dennis van der Meer, and Nick Bollettieri, highly regarded tennis instructors. Bollettieri and van der Meer each founded tennis boarding schools in the United States.

Horkheimer and Adorno

Max Horkheimer (1895-1973) was a German philosopher and sociologist, a founder and guiding thinker of the Frankfurt School of critical theory. Theodor Ludwig Wiesengrund Adorno (1903-1969) was a German sociologist and fellow member of the Frankfurt School.

hot

i.e., radioactive

hot shot

an injection intended to kill

Hotshots

poisoned heroin so as to be lethal when injected

Houdini

Harry Houdini (born Ehrich Weisz; 1874-1926) was a Jewish-American magician.

Hours

The Liturgy of the Hours is the official set of daily prayers prescribed by the Catholic Church to be recited at the canonical hours by the clergy, religious orders, and laity

hove

past tense of heave; past tense of "heave"

hovers

hangs in air

how 17 can actually go into 56 way more than 3.294 times

This recalls Bette Midler's anecdote (recorded on her 1977 album Live at Last, told while channeling the late Sophie Tucker :

Howitzer

a large piece of artillery

howitzer

a short type of cannon

huaraches

Mexican sandals, the "uppers" of which are made from woven strips of leather

hubris

pride to a fault

hubristic

having exaggerated pride or self-confidence

huge photo album

The book held by the statue reads, "JULY IV MDCCLXXVI [1776]."

hulpil

probably a misspelling of "huipil," a traditional Mayan dress

Human Hatchet

i.e., Axford

Human Immuno-Virus

HIV, i.e., the virus that causes AIDS

Humboldt County

probably the county in far-north California.

Hundt Act

Reed E. Hundt (born 1948) was chairman of the Federal Communications Committee in 1996, when the Telecommunications Act of 1996 was passed. Wallace may be riffing on that, as it appears there was no equivalent legislation in 1966.

hunnerts

i.e., "hundreds of"

Huron

the more common name for the Wyandot Indians

Hurons

More properly called the Wyandot or Wendat, these are an indigenous people of North America originally inhabiting Québec before the French arrived.

Hush Puppy

a brand name of shoes

hydrangea

several species of flowering plants

hydrocephalic

having water on the brain

Hydrocodone

also the active ingredient in Vicodin

hydrophobia

fear of water; a manifestation of the disease rabies

hydroponic

grown in water without soil; grown in water

hyper-v'd

hyperventilated

hyperemic

engorged with blood; an unusual amount of blood in part of the body

hyperfertilized

given too much fertilizer

hyperfloration

Overgrowth of flowers or plants.

hyperfloriated

overdecorated with floral designs

hypertensive

having high blood pressure

hypertonic

having rigid, tense muscles

hypertrophied

Growth of tissue, especially muscle. Although there are many causes, the most common is exercise. (see, contra, atrophied .); Grown exceedingly large.; overgrown anatomically

hypocapnia

Reduced carbon dioxide in the blood as a result of hyperventilation.

hypodermic

injected

hypogonadism

lack of function of the ovaries or testicles

hypomanic

not quite manic, but close

hypophalangial

Wallace neologism describing a smallness or absence of fingers or hands

Hypospectral

a neologism that would mean "below the [visible] spectrum [of light]," i.e., invisible

hypotenuse

the longest arm of a right triangle

hôpital of grave nature

possibly "hospital of (for the) seriously injured (or, in the case of Gertraude, the comatose)

I assume you can Identify.

Joelle is being interviewed by the cross-dressing Steeply.

I don't mind...I could wait forever.

more lyrics from "I Want to Tell You," though not the very next ones

I want to tell you...My head is filled with things to say.

These are the first lines of the Beatles song "I Want to Tell You," written by George Harrison (1943-2001).

I-17/-10

Interstate 17 runs from Phoenix to Interstate 10, which to Flagstaff, Ariz.

I-90

an interstate running from Seattle to Boston, with the Massachusetts section designated the Mass Turnpike

I-93

Interstate 93, which runs from St. Johnsbury, Vt., to the suburbs of Boston; Interstate 93 runs from St. Johnsbury, Vt., to Canton, Mass., just outside Boston.

I-beams

standard construction beams made of metal (see right)

I. M. Pei

Ieoh Ming Pei (born 1917) is a Chinese-born American architect who designed, among other famous buildings, MIT's Green Building .

I.B.E.W.

the I nternational B rotherhood of E lectrical W orkers union (for which Wallace supplies endnote 339 on page 815)

I/O

Input/Output

I/SPN

probably meant to be a follow-up television channel to ESPN

ibogaine

Ibogaine is a naturally occurring psychoactive substance found in Tabernanthe iboga . Ibogaine-containing preparations have a history of medicinal and ritual use within Africa and are controversially used to treat narcotics addiction.

ibuprofen

the generic name for Advil

Icarian

In the manner of Icarus, who flew too close to the sun with wings crafted from feathers and wax by his father Daedalus. The heat from the sun melted the wax, whereupon Icarus fell into the sea and drowned.

ICBM

Intercontinental Ballistic Missile; intercontinental ballistic missile

ICU

Intensive Care Unit

ideation

the act of forming new ideas

ideogram

an idea represented by a shape, e.g., a stop sign, known by its eight-sided configuration; a written note or character that symbolizes an idea without indicating the sounds used to say it.

idiom

a group of words established by usage as having a meaning not deducible from those of the individual words (e.g., rain cats and dogs, see the light ).

idiosyncrasy

a peculiarity of personality

idolatrous

Worships idols instead a God.

Idris Arslanian, new this year, ethnically vague

Idris is an Arabic name, corresponding in the Qur'an to Enoch in the Bible. The last name Arslanian sounds Armenian, though Arslan is a Turkish word for "lion."

idylls

simple and tranquil scenes of nature

igneous

descriptive of molten rock produced by volcanic action, implying that "Green's guilt, pain, fear and self-loathing" are now lava-like in their heat and destructive capabilities

IL NE FAUT PLUS QU'ON PURSUIVE LE BONHEUR

French: It is no longer necessary to pursue happiness. Note: "on", translating as the pronoun "one", is often used in colloquial Québécois to replace "nous" ("we"). Also, "il ne faut pas", translating word-for-word as "it is not necessary", is very often used imperatively to mean "one should/must not" or "do not". So, the line on the cartridge could also translate as "we must stop pursuing happiness".; French: It is no longer necessary to pursue happiness

ill-fated Prozac

Wallace is probably talking about the incidents of "violent suicidal ideation" that were linked with Prozac in its early use. Now it is linked to all SSRIs, though the frequency is very low.

illicit

illegal

IM

intramuscular

imago

psychological term for an idealized image, usually of a parent, formed in childhood and continuing into adulthood subconsciously

Imam'd

Here used as a verb for "to lead," an Imam is a Muslim cleric.

imbibe

1. drink (alcohol). 2. absorb or assimilate (ideas or knowledge). 3. (especially of seeds) absorb (water) into ultramicroscopic spaces or pores.

imbricate

overlapping in sequence

imbricate-sequin dresses

dresses decorated with overlapping sequins

IMBROGLIO

a misunderstanding or disagreement between persons or nations

imperative

a tense of verb implicating a command or directive

imperial

a small pointed beard.; a case for luggage; Imagine a beard like the one shown at right, only blond and with more wax.

implicit

unspoken but implied

impost

something imposed, as a tax or duty; a tax or duty imposed on some one

impotence

a malapropism; he means impetus

imprecated

called down curses upon someone

imprecating

calling down curses on others

imprimatur

sanction or approval; sanction or approval - in the Catholic church an imprimatur is a formal declaration that a work is free of doctrinal or moral error and may be published.

in tandem

together as a unit

in the bag

intoxicated

in toto

Latin: completely

in utero

in the womb

in violent medias res

In medias res is Latin for "in the middle of the thing, meaning, like many epic poems, the work begins in the middle of the story (e.g., the Iliad begins nine years into a ten-year war).

inbent

directed inward

incipient

beginning to develop

incisionish

a neologism meaning "of or like an incision"

incisors

front top teeth

See Chuck Palahniuk's novel Fight Club .

Gately's mental neologism for "rendering incognito," i.e., disguising

incongruous

out of place

incontinent

Having no or insufficient voluntary control over urination or defecation

incubus

a male demon that seduces female humans

inculcate

to teach by repetition

incunabular

early stages of something

Indian-style

in the lotus position of yoga

indicative

According to Merriam-Webster, "indicative" means "of, relating to, or constituting a verb form or set of verb forms that represents the denoted act or state as an objective fact."

Indochina

The colonial name for what is now Vietnam, Laos, and Cambodia.

INDPAK

India and Pakistan

inducement

an incentive

Indy-type

they clear the system very quickly

inebriate

as a noun, a drunkard

inelastic

When used with regard to demand, this term means tending not to change.

ineluct-

ineluctable - not able to be avoided or changed

ineluctable

incapable of being avoided or changed

inertia

resistance of an object to a change in its state of motion or rest.

inexorable

unyielding

inexorably

relentlessly

Infant-depredations

attacks and pillaging by feral infants (see footnote 304, pp. 1055ff, about them)

Infantilist

While the term can mean a type of paraphilia in which one dresses up like a baby, here Hal more likely means a pediatrician that treats patients like babies.

infantophile

one subject to infantophilia (see pedophilia ), but may simply reference the earlier Inner Infant group

INFARCTION

heart attack

Infernatron Viewer

A type of TP (Teleputer) as seen it Year of the Yushityu 2007 Mimetic-Resolution-Cartridge-View-Motherboard-Easy-To-Install-Upgrade For Infernatron/InterLace TP Systems For Home, Office Or Mobile (sic). Interlacing video makes it possible to cut the frame rate in half but can cause problems . The infernatron has to deliver the same "mimetic resolution" as the interlaced model at double the frame rate making it a very advanced television/telephone computer. If it's a portmanteau of infernal and electron that could be making a statement about DFW's TV addiction.

infernous

Lenz is apparently thinking of "infernal"

inflation-generative grammar

i.e. a set of rules to generate phrases of increasing emphasis

inflection

a rise or fall in the sound of a person's voice : a change in the pitch or tone of a person's voice. For grammar: A change in the form of a word that occurs when it has a particular use. “Gone” and “went” are inflections of the verb “go”. The wrong inflections are used in the next sentence.

infraternal

not a real word, but perhaps a Wallace (or Gentle) portmanteau of internal and fraternal (as "within the brotherhood"?)

Infundibular

having the form of a funnel. The infundibular recess alluded to here is a part of the pituitary gland's structure. Cf. "chronosynclastic infundibulum" in Vonnegut's Sirens of Titan, a fictional place were "all the different kinds of truths fit together."

ingenuish

in the manner of an ingenue, an innocent young woman

inguinal

situated in the groin

inguinal canal

a passage in the lower front part of the abdominal wall

inimical

adverse in tendency or effect

injudicious

showing lack of judgment

Inman Square

a square in Cambridge named for colonial merchant Ralph Inman

innerdicted

i.e., interdicted

inscrutable

incomprehensible

insigniated

A neologism, meaning infused with insignia (a distinguishing mark or sign, many graphic logos are insignia).

insipid

without any interesting qualities; without interesting qualities

insouciant

blithely unconcerned

insousistent

insouciant, meaning indifferent

inspissated

thickened by evaporation to become more dense

instantiation

a representation of an idea, here visual

insurmagulate

intensile

interdicted

prohibited with official authority

Interlace viewer

A television-based home entertainment system, ubiquitous in the time the novel is set, which plays copy-protected "cartridges" custom-ordered by viewers, invented by Noreen Lace-Forché

International Affairs and Interdependent Affairs

The first magazine is real; the second is not.

internecine

destructive to both sides (of a conflict, esp. within an organization)

interneural

Referring to Candida albacans, one of the microorganisms that lives in the human mouth and intestines.

inveterate

invoking Camilla, goddess of speed and light step

Camilla of Volsci, a heroine from Roman Mythology, found in Virgil's prose and ancient pottery paintings. Virgil claimed Camilla was so fast that she could run across the ocean without wetting her feet and across fields of grain without bending the grass. [7] To 'invoke' is to petition for help with an incantation. [8]

involuted

complicated; abstruse.; complex, intricate

involutional

iona

Iona is an island off the west coast of Scotland. Gately means iota.

Jesuitical Endeavors

An endeavor is a purposeful undertaking that requires boldness. Jesuitical endeavors are those undertaken as part of a Jesuit ministry.

Jim Troeltsch

The most famous person with this surname is Ernst Troeltsch (1865-1923), a German Protestant theologian and philosopher of religion and history.

Jiminy Cricket

Kaopectate

brand name of parapectolin. A pink, clay-like antidiarrheal; believed to work by adsorbing the bacteria or germ that may be causing the diarrhea.

Kaposi's Sarcoma

a type of viral cancer that causes skin lesions; A tumor caused by Human herpesvirus-8. One of the most common symptoms of AIDS. More here

Karachi

the largest city in Pakistan and capital of its Sindh province

Karlsruhe

a city in Germany about 90 miles south of Frankfurt (Main)

Kastenbaum and Kastenbaum

Robert J. Kastenbaum is another prominent scholar in the field of death and dying. I can't find another person by that name, so perhaps Hal is referring to multiple volumes by the same Kastenbaum.

katexia

Just like when Joelle referred to CA newcomers as "catexic" on pg 707, there's no word "katexia" in any American dictionary, although Freud used "katexis" to refer to the process by means of which libido energy is tied or placed into the mental representation of a personality, idea, or thing." What would make more sense in context is cachexia, the weight loss and muscle atrophy caused by some chronic diseases.

Keds

a brand of sneaker

keel

This word denotes "the principal structural member of a ship, running lengthwise along the center line from bow to stern, to which the frames are attached" ( American Heritage Dictionary of the English Language ). Here it is used in the sense of "on an even keel," i.e., sane.

Keens

wails

keep

i.e., the barkeep

Kemp and Limbaugh

Jack French Kemp, Jr. (1935-2009), was a conservative American politician, former member of the House of Representative, former Secretary for Housing and Urban Development, and 1996 Republican candidate for Vice President.

ken

range of sight or vision

kertwanging

from context, this would seem to be when an opponent is intentionally making bad calls to win points.

Kevlar

a synthetic substance used in, among other things, bulletproof vests

Kevlon

Possibly a portmanteau-word combining Kevlar and Teflon, meaning a substance that is tough and slippery ( Urbandictionary.com ).

kg.s.cm.

kilograms per square centimeter, as a measurement of pressure, like pounds per square inch; could just be a reference to kilogram-second-centimeter, or a form of the metric system (though the metric systems usually have 'second' last - as in CGS [centimeter-gram-second] or MKS [meter-kilogram-second]), though 'two sticks of TNT' doesn't really imply a system of units.

kibbitzing

looking on and offering unwelcome advice

kibitzing

chatting or conversing, or offering unwanted comment

kick serve

a serve in tennis with so much spin that the ball bounces high and to the left (if right-handed) or right (if left-handed) of the receiver

Kierkegaard

Søren Aabye Kierkegaard was a 19th century Danish philosopher and one of the progenitors of existential philosophy

Kierkegaard and Regina

Regina Olsen was the short-term fiancée of Kierkegaard.

kif

Arabic for marijuana in leaf form, as opposed to hashish

kill it just by touching

When a player on the punter's team touches the ball while it is still in the field of play, the play is whistled "dead" and the opposing team takes possession at that point

Kimberly-Clark

Depend's parent corporation also Kleenex's

kinesthetic

regarding the sensation of movement in the muscles, tendons, joints, etc.

Kinski as Paganini

Klaus Kinski (1926-1991), Danzig-born German-American actor, played Niccolò Paganini (1782-1840), the Italian violinist and composer, in his final film, Kinski Paganini .

kippers

cured herring

which is to say, if you can't take the heat, stay out of the kitchen

Kodachrome

kohl

Kools

a brand of menthol cigarettes

Korean Police Action of the U.N.

This is a reference to the Korean War, which involved military support from United Nations member nations (in defense of South Korea from the invading North). The war actually lasted three full years.

Korean-War-vintage

The Korean War (1950–53) was a military conflict between the Republic of Korea, supported by the United Nations, and the Democratic People's Republic of Korea and People's Republic of China, with air support from the Soviet Union.

Kornspan

German: corn chip ["Korn" means corn or grain, "Span" means chip or flake, but "Kornspan" makes no sense in German]

kosher

Here Gately means "OK," whereas this literally, in Yiddish, refers to food "prepared according to Jewish Law."

Kruger Abstraction Scale

There's apparently no such thing.

Kryptonite

a Kryptonite lock, named for the Kryptonite of Superman fame (and implying that not even Superman could steal whatever was secured with it)

kudzu

a type of climbing vine now prevalent in the U.S. South. It was introduced in the 30s and 40s and is now viewed as an invasive nuisance.

kwai9

quinine

kyphotic

having abnormal curvature of the spine

kyphotic and lordotic

Kyphotic means having abnormal rear curvature of the spine (i.e., hunchbacked), while lordotic having abnormal forward curvature of the spine.

Kübler-Ross, Hinton

Elisabeth Kübler-Ross, M.D. (1926-2004) was a Swiss-born American psychiatrist and specialist on death and dying. John Hinton is a British contemporary expert in the field.

L'Hôpital

Guillaume François Antoine, Marquis de l'Hôpital (1661-1704), was a French mathematician.

L'Islet County

A county of Québec at the northern end of the Appalachian Mountains.

L-Dopa

abbreviation for levadopa a chemical precursor to dopamine, adrenaline, and other neurotransmitters

L.A.S. tradition

Liberal Arts and Sciences

L.M.P.

Latrodectus Mactans Productions

L.T.I.

Long-term institution (glossed in note 365).

La Honda CA

a tiny town in San Mateo County, California

labile

unstable

Labrador

the mainland part of the Canadian province of Newfoundland

labrynth

This is the mythological spelling of "labyrinth," meaning generically a maze, but more specifically denoting the maze built by Daedalus of ancient Greek myth.

Lac de Deux Montaignes

French: Lake of Two Mountains — near Montreal

lachrymucus

mucus flowing as a result of crying; rheum

Lacoste

a French apparel company, known for producing Izod

lacteal

milky

lacuna

a missing part

laddered

having a run (in a stocking)

lager

a type of beer, medium in darkness

laissez-faire

French for "let do," or, more idiomatically, "leave alone," this is a term usually applied to conservative economics but here generally gives a sense of not caring very much.

lalating

anybody's guess, although perhaps similar to ululating, as suggested by Amy Batchelor in one of her interesting Thoughts in Random Patterns (8 August 2005)

lalations

misspelling of "lallations," i.e., baby-talk

Lamb's Breath cannabis

a type of potent marijuana

laminating

sealing in plastic

lampblack

A pigment taken from oil resin, football players apply it below their eyes to reduce glare off their cheekbones from the sun or stadium lighting.

lamé

an ornamental fabric incorporating threads of gold or silver

Lancaster NH

a city about twenty miles west of Berlin, N.H.

Lancelot and what's-her-name

Guinevere

Lancôme

one of France's largest cosmetics manufacturers

Langesque

in the style of Fritz Lang

Langley

the town in Virginia where the CIA is headquartered

languid

lacking spirit or energy

languor

feeling of exhaustion and relaxation; the state or feeling, often pleasant, of tiredness or inertia

lantern jaw

a mandible that protrudes beyond the maxilla, or one that is long and thin

lap-dissolves

According to Wikipedia, a lap dissolve "is a technical term in film editing, most often used in the United States, applying to the process whereby the fading last shot of a preceding scene is superimposed over the emerging first shot (fade in) of the next scene..."

lapidary

"Marked by conciseness, precision, or refinement of expression: lapidary prose" ( thefreedictionary.com ). The OED defines it as “Characteristic of or suitable for monumental inscriptions”. The original meaning refers to the cutting and polishing of precious stones. Wallace favored this word to describe well-wrought prose, and used it often himself in interviews and readings.

lapped

a reference to track and field, in which a runner is so far ahead of another runner on a circular court that he has "lapped" him, i.e., is now a lap ahead of him

lapsarian

Pertaining generally to the Fall of Man from innocence (into sexual awareness) and specifically to Adam and Eve's lapse from God's favor after disobediently partaking from the Tree of the Knowledge of Good and Evil (Genesis 2:8 through 3:24); see the usages below on page 713 of lapse and pre-saved .

lardy

fat

largesse

genorosity of spirit or attitude

Largest Whole Prime On The FM Band

109 is a prime number, i.e., divisible only by itself and by 1. Actually the highest number you can get on FM is 108.

LaRoucheishly

a reference to Lyndon Hermyle LaRouche, Jr. (born 1922), a political extremist and cult leader

larval

immature in its kind

laryngeally fissured

having ridges like the human larynx

larynx

voice box

lascivious

appealing to sexual tastes

lassitude

weariness of body

latency

i.e., sexual latency, the period Freud posited during which male sexuality is dormant

lateral

sideways

Latinate

deriving from Latin; suggestive in style of the ancient Romans

latissimal

referring to the lattissimus dorsi muscles

Latrodectus Mactans

Latin name for the Black Widow spider

lattice

This is "a structure of crossed wooden or metal strips usually arranged to form a diagonal pattern of open spaces between the strips" ( Random House Unabridged Dictionary ).

Lay

non-professional

lazarettes and oubliettes

A lazarette is a hospital that treats infectious diseases, while an oubliette is a dungeon accessible only by trapdoor.

leaf-cutter-ant

a type of North American ant

Leap like a knight of faith

A reference to Soren Kierkegaard's knight of faith. Kierkegaard, a theologian and philosopher, didn't think there could be any logical justification for believing in God. Instead the believer is required to take a leap of faith, so called because he (the believer) has no evidence for his convictions and thus must always, on some rational level, doubt them. In fact to Kierkegaard doubt defines faith, because if there were no doubt no leap of faith would be required in the first place, much like it doesn't require a leap of faith for you to believe you're actually reading this wikipedia entry right now, or that I'm not an alien sub rosa manipulating your mind for my own purposes.

leatherette

imitation leather

Leavenworth

the U.S. Disciplinary Barracks at Leavenworth, Kan.

Lebensgefährtins

Wallace's endnote 31(p. 994) claims this "means technically 'soulmate' or 'spouse'", but a more accurate translation would be 'life partner'. NB: 'Lebensgefährtin' is the feminine form of the noun. NB2: Schtitt's use of '-s' to indicate plural is incorrect for 'real' German (the correct form being Lebensgefährtinnen ); it is difficult to claim whether or not it is intentional on Wallace's part.

Lechmere's in Cambridgeside

Lechmere's was an electronics and appliance chain that folded in 1997. Its flagship store was located in the CambridgeSide Galleria mall in East Cambridge.

lecithin

a mixture of fats found in milk and other foods

lee

away from the wind

lee side

nautical term meaning the side facing away from the wind

left cross

According to a boxing Web site, "the right cross is thrown in a straight line to the target and comes back in a straight line to the chin." The left cross is delivered with left hand.

left-eye-nystagmic

Troeltsch's left eye is nystagmic. Nystagmia is an involuntary eye-movement characterised by the combination of a smooth pursuit, which usually acts to take the eye off the point of regard, interspersed with the saccadic movement that serves to bring the eye back on target.

Legal Seafood up in Brookline

Legal Sea Foods, a chain that got its start in Inman Square, has a restaurant at 43 Boylston St., at the border of Brookline and within five miles of ETA.

legation

a diplomatic office lower than an embassy

legless on shots alone

very drunk to the point of not being able to walk well

Leith

A homonym of Lethe, the name of the river in Greek mythology whose water, if drunk, will erase one's memory. In keeping with the optics theme, Emmett Leith was an inventor in the field of holography. Walt Disney, of course, was a well known film producer and director.

lemma

a proven statement used as a step in a mathematical proof

Lend-Lease

a program between the beginning of World War II and U.S. entry after the bombing of Pearl Harbor whereby the U.S. government provided materiel to Britain (and later the Soviets) in return for military bases

lending weight to another cliché

presumably E.M. Security is "never there when you need them."

Lenglen, Rosewall

Suzanne Rachel Flore Lenglen (1899-1938) was a French tennis player who won thirty-one Grand Slams. Kenneth Robert ("Ken") Rosewall (born 1934) was an Australian tennis player with three Grand Slam wins.

lentissimo

a musical term that is Italian for "very, very slowly"

Lenz

Very old-fashion German for "springtime". But also a family name, e.g. from the 19th century playwright J. M. R. Lenz :

leonine

lion-like; resembling a lion

leptosomatic

Having a slender, frail build.

les bâtiments sanctifíes

French: the holy buildings

les salles de danser

French: dancing rooms

LeSabre

the Buick LeSabre

Lesotho

a kingdom of southern Africa, existing as an enclave entirely within the Republic of South Africa

let

a play in tennis that calls for a replaying

leukodermatic

probably referring to leukoderma, having patches of skin that are missing pigment

levantine

from the Near East, particularly Syria, Lebanon, Palestine, or Israel, i.e., the Levant

Levesque-Parti-and-Bloc Québecois and Fronte de la Libération Nationale

René Lévesque (1922-1987) was a Québecois government minister and founder of the Parti Québécois . Bloc Québécois promotes sovereignty for Québec while the Parti promotes independence. The Fronte mentioned above is probably a misnomer or early form of the FLQ .

Levi #501

once-popular button-fly jeans manufactured by Levi Strauss

Levirates

men required to marry their brothers' widows

lexical prodigy

A child who is exceptionally talented with words.

libations

alcoholic drinks

Liberal KS

To be exact, it's three miles via Route 83 to the Oklahoma border.

Libertine Statue

I.e., the Statue of Liberty, though calling it this implies sexual promiscuity, even if she is wearing a diaper

libido

sex drive

Librium

Brand name of chlordiazepoxide, the oldest benzodiazepine and used for cocaine and alcohol withdrawal.; Chlordiazepoxide (Librium) Treats anxiety, symptoms of alcohol withdrawal, and tremor. This medicine is a benzodiazepine .

LIBSYR

Libya and Syria

like one of Bacon's popes

Francis Bacon (1909-1992) was an Irish artist. His portrait of Pope Innocent X can be seen to the right.

limbic system

a complex system within the brain ; the most primitive portion of the mammalian brain, associated with emotions

limned

To limn means to describe or delineate

Linda McCartney

Linda Louise, Lady McCartney (1941-1998) was an American photographer and wife of Beatle Paul McCartney (born 1943).

Lindisfarne Gospels

Richly decorated illuminated manuscipt ofthe Gospels, believed to have been produced around 700 AD in a monastery near Lindisfarne, Northumberland, UK. Some carpet pages from the Lindisfarne Gospels can be seen here .

lineskers

lines of powdered cocaine assembled for snorting

lingual tendinitis

this would mean inflammation of the tendon of the tongue, but the tongue and mouth lack tendons

liniment

a liquid or lotion, especially one made with oil, for rubbing on the body to relieve pain.; a liquid preparation rubbed into the skin or gums as a counterirritant, rubefacient, anodyne, or cleansing agent

linotype

short form name for a linotype machine

lintel

a horizontal piece of architecture supporting the weight above a window or door

liposuction

a surgical procedure whereby fat is literally sucked out of the body

lissome

agile; nimble; supple

listing to port

a nautical term meaning "leaning leftward"

lit

landed

litany

a prolonged or tedious account

lithe

slim and gracefully flexible

lithium

used to treat bipolar disorder

lithium-anodized

Anodizing is the process of making something electrically passive via electrolytic chemical deposition, or oxidation of the surface layer. Presumably lithium-anodized implies this process is done with the alkali metal lithium .

Lithonate

A brand name of lithium.

litigatory

having to do with legal proceedings

lividity

the change of color in skin brought on by livor mortis, an after-death phenomenon when blood settles in the body at low points of gravity; brightness of color

loafer one

presumably first step of the day, meaning Lenz never leaves Ennet House until after sunset

loafers

shoes that slip on, rather than tie with laces

loamy

consisting of rich, arable soil

locusts

Given the noise they're making, Wallace is probably referring to cicadas .

locutions

Sayings; phrases.

Logan

the major airport of Boston

lolled

dropped

Lombardy

a region of northern Italy with its capital at Milan

long white FDR-style filter

Franklin Delano Roosevelt, the 32nd President of the United States. He often used a cigarette holder as seen in the photo on the right.

longshoremen

Dock workers who load and unload ships.

loo

British colloquialism for toilet; the British word for "bathroom"

loogy

term for a glob of phlegm

look as if butter wouldn't melt

Look as if butter wouldn't melt in his mouth Appear gentle or innocent while typically being the opposite. - OED

look into my eyes: no new enhancements

Cf. George H. W. Bush saying "Read my lips: no new taxes" during his 1988 election campaign (See Wikipedia ).

Lopate

The name is perhaps taken from Philip Lopate (born 1943), an American film critic.

loquacious

very talkative

loquacity

talkativeness

Lord's Prayer

from Matthew 20:9-13

Lorimar's Dynasty

Lorimar was a production company and Dynasty a prime-time soap opera that aired in the 1980s.

Lou Gehrig's

the more common name for amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, which the famous New York Yankee suffered from

loupes

eyepiece magnifying glasses used by jewellers

Louth in Lenster

Louth is about 50 miles north-northwest of Dublin. Leinster (note spelling) is one of the four traditional provinces of Ireland, the others being Connaught, Ulster, and Munster. There are not officially used as Ulster is divided between the Republic of Ireland and the U.K. since 1922.

louvered

with angled slats

Love Boat

actually commonly used as a nickname for marijuana laced with PCP

LOVE CANAL

an area near Buffalo, N.Y., famous for its high amount of toxic waste and the effects it had on the residents there

low 10's C

10º C is equal to 50º Fahrenheit.

low exposure

maybe he means short exposure. The fast lens would allow for a faster shutter speed and the diffusion filter would blur things out. Pemulis's idea can be understood but he seems confused about film/photography in general.

low-lipid

i.e., low-fat

low-pH chemist

i.e., he worked with acids

lox

possibly abbreviated form of lummox ("clumsy or stupid person") as neither "smoked salmon" or "liquid oxygen" fit

lozenges

diamond-shaped objects

LTIs

Long-Term Illnesses

lucidity

mental clarity

Lucille Duquette

Molly is lying about Joelle's real name, but this name means something like "Light of the Collection."

Lucite

A brand name of polymethyl methacrylate, a kind of safety glass similar to polycarbonate.

Ludditism

Named for Ned Ludd (born Ned Ludlam), the Luddites were 19th century opposers of the Industrial Revolution.; a philosophy that is strongly against advances in technology, named for Ned Ludd

Luger

a German brand of handgun

lumbar stressae

back stress

lume

a short term for the luminous phosphorescent glowing solution applied on watch dials

lume nacreous

pearly light

lumiphobia

probably fear of light, although the proper term is "photophobia"

lumpen

marginalized; uneducated and/or unenlightened; disenfranchised

lurid

gruesome or shocking

Luther's 16th-century shoes, awaiting epiphany

Martin Luther (1483-1546), German father of the Reformation, was a notorious sufferer of constipation.

lycanthropically

in a way suggesting a werewolf

Lyle

The Sweat Guru

Lynch

David Keith Lynch (born 1946) is an American filmmaker. David Lynch and Kyle MacLachlan worked together on the movies "Dune" (1984), "Blue Velvet" (1986), and the TV series Twin Peaks (1990-1991).

Lysergics

Lysergic acid diethylamide - LSD

Léaud as Doinel

Jean-Pierre Léaud (born 1944), a French actor, played the fictional character Antoine Doinel in five films .

m'épouse au future

French: future spouse

M. Café-brand Automatic Café-au-Lait maker

half coffee and half milk in a large cup, as drunk in France. M. Café as in 'Mr. Coffee".

M. Chang

Michael Chang (born 1972) is an American former, but still-living, professional tennis player. Wallace misguessed Chang's early demise.

M. Hamilton as Oz's West Witch

Referring to The Wizard of Oz, the Wicked Witch of the West (and East) was played by Margaret Hamilton .

M. Kemp

as in Monsieur Kemp, i.e., Jack Kemp, implying he was assassinated with a bomb in his house

M./Mlle.

French: Monsieur/Mademoiselle, i.e., Mr./Ms., used because of Steeply's disguise

M.A.O.-inhibiting

monoamine oxidase inhibitor, a chemical in potent antidepressants.

M.B.A.

Master's of Business Administration

M.B.R.O.

M etro- B oston R ecovery O ptions

M.D.C.

Massachusetts Department of Corrections; Metropolitan District Commission, a former Massachusetts state agency that was responsible for maintenance of public parks and roads in the Metropolitan Boston area

M.I.T.-crested

see right

M.M.

Michael Matthew

M.M.P.I.

Minnesota Multiphasic Personality Inventory, a commonly administered psychological test designed to give an overview of personality, neuroses, etc.; Minnesota Multiphasic Personality Inventory: a common mental health personality test

M.O.

Modus operandi, a Latin phrase meaning the way in which a criminal operates out of habit

M.P.

military policeman

M.S.

multiple sclerosis

M.S.T.

Mountain Standard Time

Macdonald Chair

possibly named for Dwight Macdonald (1906-1982), American writer, editor, and social critic.

Mace

a brand name of pepper spray

mace

a medieval weapon, basically consisting of a stick with a ball covered with spikes at the end

machete

a large cleaver-like cutting tool

machine-language

a coding system for computers that requires no compiling before running

macramé

a type of fabric-making done by knotting rather than knitting

macrobiotic

regarding a diet designed largely of whole grains and beans, designed to prolong life

macrocartographic

immense and involved with maps

Mad Stork

the nickname for former NFL linebacker Ted Hendricks

Madame Psychosis

not just a byname for DMZ, but also a radio show host

Madame Psychosis is in charge.

This is the first time Joelle has been positively ID'ed as M.P. (She is referred to as "a.k.a. Madame P." much earlier on page 225)

Maddox OH

doesn't appear to be a real place

Made Guys

members of the Mafia in full standing

Madison Avenue

the street in New York famous for its advertising firms

madonnas

statues of the Virgin Mary

mafficking

boisterous celebration

mafun ho

i.e., mother-fucking whore

magical thinking

the correlation of actions and events in the absence of scientific proof

magiscule

A misspelling of "majuscule," meaning a capital letter.

magisculed

typo or intentional misspelling of majuscule, an initial capital letter, often large-type to introduce a section of written material; Wallace's use of the noun in a verb form is likely a neologism (especially if the alternate spelling is retained)

magnaminously

a (probably deliberate) misspelling of "magnanimously," i.e., generously

magneto

a small generator using a permanent magnet to produce high-voltage pulses

magnitron

a misspelling of "magnetron," which is "a two-element vacuum tube in which the flow of electrons is under the influence of an external magnetic field, used to generate extremely short radio waves" ( Random House Unabridged Dictionary ).

mahogany Christian object

i.e., the aforementioned crucifix

main

here meaning "physical strength"

majestic ambers and purple fruits

words, slightly jumbled, from "America, the Beautiful"

Major Burns

a "villain" character played by Larry Linville

Makavajev

Born in 1932, Dusan Makavejev (probably misspelled) is a Yugoslavian-born film director.

malcathected

attached to emotionally in a negative way

Malden

a northern suburb of Boston, about 7 miles north of the city

malefic

producing evil; having a bad influence

malentendu

mishearing

malevolent

evil; intending harm

malice

desire to do harm

malleolus

a bony lump on the side of the ankle

Malone

John C. Malone (born 1941), now CEO of Liberty Media

malt liquor

a high-alcohol-content variety of beer

mammarial

resembling or having to do with breasts

manacles

handcuffs

Mandelbrotian

Referring to Benoît B. Mandelbrot (born 1924), French-American-Jewish mathematician.

mandible

jawbone

Manitol

a misspelling of mannitol

Mannington

a flooring company

mano-à-tête

combination of "mano-a-mano" (Spanish: hand to hand) and "tête-à-tête" (French: head-to-head)

mansard

This is "a hip roof, each face of which has a steeper lower part and a shallower upper part" ( Random House Unabridged Dictionary ).

mantis

the praying mantis

map

face

maple leaf

the national emblem of Canada

maraschino

a marasca cherry

Marblehead

A town in Essex County, Mass., home to a yachting resort. It's about 15 miles northeast of the city on the water.

Margaret Thatcher

Margaret Hilda Thatcher, Baroness Thatcher (born 1925), was Prime Minister of the U.K. from 1979 to 1990.

Marin-Amat Syndrome

This is involuntary closure on one eye, named for Manuel Marin Amat, an early 20th century Spanish ophthalmologist.

Marino 350

Not a camera but a case from Massachusetts in 1966. Plaintiff wanted a private drive on his land to be denied to defendant so that defendant could no longer reach his own property. The defendant won.

Marino lamps

shorthand for a San Marino floor lamp

Marlborough Street

Marlborough Street runs through the Back Bay area of Boston.

maroon

i.e., a moron; a cartoonish pronunciation ( à la Bugs Bunny) of "moron;" (see note for page 302 supra )

marquees

the lighted signs on which theaters announce what is playing

Marseillese

more properly Marseillaise, i.e., from Marseilles, France

Marsh or Swamp

The principal male characters in M*A*S*H lived in the same tent, which they called "the Swamp."

Marshall Plan

the plan to rebuild Germany after WWII

martial

war-like

martial at ease

a military stance with feet shoulder's width apart and hands clasped behind the back

martinet

a strict disciplinarian

masochistic

tending to enjoy pain to the point of sexual response; cf. sadistic, tending to derive sexual pleasure from the infliction of pain on another

Mass Comm. graduate student

Mass Communications? This is unclear. The uppercase M and C suggest it is intended to be the name of a college, though the absence of a period after 'Mass' suggests the word 'mass'.

Mass Rehab

Massachusetts Rehabilitation Commission

Massachussets Institute of Technology was defensive in bed

Maybe "in bed with the Department of Defense"?

mastication

chewing

matins and vespers

two of the nine prayer services a day in Catholic abbeys and monasteries; essentially, the daybreak and twilight services, respectively

matte

as an adjective, having a dull or lusterless finish

matteing

(Also matting . In film (or photography), this means combining multiple images into one final image, i.e., compositing .

mattes

This is shorthand for a matte shot, which is "a shot in which parts of the background and sometimes the foreground are masked so that a different background, foreground, image, etc., can be substituted during printing" ( Random House Unabridged Dictionary ).

maunder

to talk incoherently or aimlessly

maundering

talking in a rambling, foolish way

Maury Linville

Steeply is misremembering Larry Linville.

mauve

a moderate grey-violet to red-purple color

maw

mouth

maxillofacial

pertaining to or affecting the jaws and face; relating to the jaw and face

Maxwell House

a brand of coffee

may the road rise up to meet you...

part of an old Irish blessing

Maya Deren

Born Eleanora Derenkowsky, Maya Deren (1917-1961) was a Ukrainian-born American director [1] .

mayhi

Orin seems to be using this term as a plural of "mayhem."

McDonald's House

a reference to Ronald McDonald House Charities, which provides housing for the parents of children undergoing intensive medical care

McEnroe-Esconja

John Patrick McEnroe, Jr. (born 1959), was a professional tennis player from 1974 to 1992, with seven Grand Slam wins. Esconja appears to be a made-up name.

McGee-like chaos

An overflowing closet was a running gag on the old-time radio show Fibber McGee and Molly .

McGruff

McGruff the Crime Dog is an anthropomorphic cartoon bloodhound created for the National Crime Prevention Council for use by American police in building crime awareness among children. ( Wikipedia )

MCI-Walpole

This is the Massachusetts Correction Institute at Walpole, about 25 miles southwest of Boston.

MCI/Billerica

the M assachusetts C orrectional I nstitution in Billerica, a town about 20 miles northwest of Boston

McLachlin

a misspelling of Kyle MacLachlan (born 1959), an American actor whose second film was Blue Velvet

McLean Hospital

a real psychiatric hospital in Belmont, Mass., about eight miles west-northwest of Boston

me droogies

Struck is speaking in Nadsat, the language of Anthony Burgess's novel A Clockwork Orange, which is based on Russian. Droogies is Nadsat for "friends."

meal

ground grain

Mean-Value Theorem for Integrals

Learn it here . It should be noted that Wallace does not actually explain the theorem.

meatus

a natural bodily opening; a passage or opening leading to the interior of the body.

MED.COM

not a real Web site

medials

i.e., medians

medical attaches

Here, a medical attache is a specialist who assists a wealthy or powerful person's personal physician.

medulla

literally that part of the brain responsible for autonomic functions like heartbeat, organ activity, etc.

Medusoid

looking like a gorgon

Meech Lake

a lake in Gatineau Park, near Chelsea, Québec

megagram

a million grams, or slightly over 2,200 pounds

megahertz

a measurement of cycles per second

megaspansules

a combination of mega + span + capsule, these would be large, time-released capsules

Mein kinder

German: "My children". But wrong grammar! "Mein" is singular, "kinder" is plural. "My children" would be "Meine Kinder"

Men's Sanity in Corporate Sterno

Mens sana in corpore sano (a healthy mind in a healthy body) is a Latin quotation, often translated as, "A sound mind in a healthy body

mendacious

untruthful

mendaciously

in a manner of one who is lying

Menelaus was husband, him of Sparta

Menelaus, King of Sparta, was the husband of Helen. Agamemnon was the King of Argos and Menelaus's brother.

meninges

the tissues that encase the brain

meniscus

a lens with a crescent-shaped section

Mennonite

an Anabaptist denomination named for Menno Simons (1496-1561), a Frisian religious leader

mens-sana pedagogy

"healthy-mind" teaching

menses

menstruation

mentation

mental activity

Mephistophelan

referring to Mephistopheles, the devil character in Goethe's Faust and Marlowe's Doctor Faustus, to whom Faust sells his soul

mercantile counterpart at the Rolling Hills Academy

a student at Rolling Hills who fulfills at his school much the same role that Pemulis fulfills at E.T.A.

mercenary

paid soldiers

Mercier Dam

You can read more about it here .

mercuric

employing the element mercury

mercuric red

red as the color made by MercuroChrome

merde

French for "shit"

Merry Widow

a woman's undergarment consisting of a strapless bra and short corset

mescal

an alcoholic beverage distilled from a cactus

mescaline

Mescaline is the active ingredient in peyote .

mesmerized

hypnotized

mesomorphic

having a muscular, husky body type

mesquite

the mesquite plant; a spiny shrub with bean pods

Met State

Metropolitan State Hospital; a defunct public mental health facility in Waltham, MA. It was operating during Wallace's stay at nearby McLean Hospital but closed before Infinite Jest 's publication.

meta-disease

a disease syndrome, or a disease that itself causes other diseases

metadecision

a decision about a previous decision

metal-pedalled

i.e., "with the pedal to the metal," i.e., at top speed

metallurgy

the making and conducting of alloys

metastasizes

spreads like cancer

metastisate

He means "metastasize."

metatheoretical

regarding a theory devised to analyze a previous theory

methadoan

Methadone - used to help ease off a heroin addiction

methadone

a drug used to wean heroin addicts off that drug and onto methadone, which is equally addictive but produces no "high"

methamphetamine hydrochloride

As the endnote on p. 983 tells us, this the chemical name for crystal meth. Calling to mind that Infinite Jest was published in 1996, don't think crystal meth is a new phenomenon.

methedrine

the brand name of methamphetamine

Methoxy

5-methoxy-diisopropyltryptamine often termed Foxy Methoxy or just Foxy, is a psychedelic tryptamine.

methoxy-psychedelic

probably referring to MMDA

methoxylated

Addition of a methoxy group. Wikipedia redirects here or "methoxylation."

METHUEN

a city of Massachusetts about 30 miles north of Boston

metronome

a time-keeping device for musicians, typically a pendulum-like machine that clicks to provide meter

MF

Millennial Fizzy

MGM

Militant Grammarians of Massachusetts

miasma

a noxious atmosphere

Michael Pemulis, ..., clear his throat deeply

this grammatical error appears shortly after a discussion of a class on grammar

micological

probably a misspelling of mycological, meaning having to do with the study of fungi

micro-econometrist

An econometrist is an economist who uses statistical methods. A microeconomist is an economist who studies a smaller level of economics, i.e., firms and businesses rather than nations or international business.

microbiotic

probably an intentional misspelling of macrobiotic; a macrobiotic diet primarily consists of whole grains, beans, and vegetables based on the Taoist principles of yin and yang

microcephalic

having a tiny head; possessing an abnormally small head

micronized

reduced in particle size to only a few microns (millionths of a meter) in diameter

micturate

urinate

Micturation

urination

midbrain

another name for the mesencephalon

Middlesex County

a county comprising most of the suburbs northwest and west of Boston

mien

appearance

MiG25s

Russian aircraft

mild sedatives

Quaaludes are more like a sledgehammer to the head than a "mild sedative."

Mile-High

The stadium in which the Denver Broncos played until 2001.

Miles Penn

a combination of the names of two early British settlers of America: William Penn and Miles Standish (1584-1656), the military commander of Plymouth colony who traveled to Massachusetts on the Mayflower .

MILKEN

Michael Robert Milken (born 1946) is a former stockbroker who served several years in prison for securities fraud.

Millbrook NY

a town in New York state, about 90 miles north of New York City

Millon's

the Millon Clinical Multiaxial Inventory-III, another psych inventory

mimesis

in art, the imitative representation of nature or human behavior; i.e., the radio was broadcasting nothing but audio static, or "snow"

mimetic

used here, meaning as close to reality as possible

Minister of Environment and Resource-Development Enterprises

The initials spell merde, which is French for "shit."

minor-D

Musical works written in the key of D Minor tend to carry an ominous tone. See A Fugue in D Minor .

minotaurs

Daedalus built his famous maze to house the Minotaur, a monster that was half man and half bull and the product of sexual congress between Europa, queen of Crete, and Zeus in the form of a bull.

Minsk

the capital of Belarus

Minuteman

a type of missile

Mirandized

read his or her rights, from the Supreme Court case Miranda v. Arizona (1965)

Miriam Prickett

...and this.

miscegenation

interbreeding between different races

misnomer

a misapplied name or designation

misprision

contempt against the government or courts; however, it can also mean, in a non-legal sense, misunderstanding, which may be the meaning here (for example, Gately confusing "epilepsy" with "Epi-Lady")

MK-Ultra

an actual CIA mind-control experiment starting in the 1950s and continuing well into the 1960s and possibly 70s

MLB

Major League Baseball

Mlle. Luria P----

This would very likely be the "Swiss" Girl Orin is sleeping with.

MMDA, DMA, DMMM, 2CB, para-DOT I-VI

You can read about MMDA here, DMA here, 2CB here, DOT here (apparently). DMMM appears to be made up.

mnemonic

having to do with memory

mnemonic brown-out

a sort of memory lapse short of a blackout

mobilely upward

that is to say, upwardly mobile

modem

used as a verb, communicating with the office via modem, an early but ubiquitous tool for transmitting data between servers and client/servers.; An acronym for modulation-demodulation, it is a data-transfer device.

Modus Tollens

a Latin logical term, meaning, roughly, "the means of denying"

mogulette

a minor mogul, or perhaps a female mogul

moguls

a bumps on a ski slope formed by the repeated turns of skiers over the same path; bumps of the kind often seen in snow on ski slopes

mokus

1) Loneliness or depression. Oddly, this term could not be found in a U.S. dictionary, but is referred to in the OED as "US slang." 2) More often spelled as "mocus," common American 12-Step term for a hazy, unfocused state of mind, especially in early sobriety. Said to come from "mind out of focus." Mokus is also Hungarian for squirrel, raising the possibility of a pun on "feeling squirrelly."

moll

the girlfriend of a criminal

mollified

softened in feeling and temper

Molson

a Canadian brand of beer

Moment magazine

This is a Jewish-interest magazine .

Mondragonoid

Avril Incandenza's maiden name is revealed to be Mondragon. Also refers to Mondragón, the Spanish name for the Basque town of Arrasate, best known as the home of the Mondragón Cooperative Corporation the world's largest worker cooperative. Note the similarity of the Basque Country and Quebec as presented in IJ.

Mondrian

Pieter Cornelis (Piet) Mondrian (1872-1944) was a Dutch painter. His work often featured a gridwork of black squares and rectangles, as seen right, which could be read as an urban map.

moniker

nickname

monilial

relating to a fungus of the genus Candida

monilial sinusitis

Inflammation of the nasal sinus caused by fungus of the genus Monila .

Monogram

a design consisting of two or more alphabetic letters combined or interlaced

monograph

a scholarly study on a particular subject, usually published as a book

monomitotic

"Mitosis" is cell division, and Wallace is playing with words again: "monomitosis" could be the one-time-only splitting of a cell; in this case, the "cell" is a group of insurgents rather than the biological unit, and "monomitotic" might imply that once it splits (i.e., separates to accomplish its targeted task), it dissolves or disbands.

Monostat

brand name of a treatment for vaginal yeast infections

montage

a film sequence in which a period of time is quickly covered with short (a few seconds) scenes, usually underscored with music

Montague Grammar

Named for Richard Merett Montague (1930-1971), an American logician, this is an approach to semantics that suggests that the semantics of natural languages is essentially the same as those of formal languages, such as logic or computer programming.

Montague Semantics

This is a form of natural language semantics .

Montcerf, Québec

a city of Québec about 82.5 miles due north of Ottawa

Montclair NJ

a suburb about twenty miles west-northwest of New York City

Montego

either the Austin Montego or the Mercury Montego

Montesian

also the name of a lake in Wisconsin

MONTPELIER

the capital of Vermont

Montreal

A French-speaking city in the Canadian province of Quebec.

Montreal Tulip Fest

The Canadian Tulip Festival actually takes place in Ottawa, Ontario, and Gatineau, Quebec, which border each other.

moon

to spend time idly

moonballed

Here used as a past-tense verb, a moonball is a very high lob.

moppetish

resembling a small, sweet and endearing child

mordant

very like sardonic, indeed incisively so; may or may not involve irony (i.e., mordancy is not necessarily sarcasm)

mordantly

in a caustic manner.

more like refracted

Refraction occurs when light slows down when it enters a new medium. The change of speed also causes a change in direction of travel. Although light travels at a constant speed in a vacuum, it travels more slowly in matter.

morendo

a musical term meaning "a gradual decrescendo at the end of a strain or cadence" ( Webster's Revised Unabridged Dictionary ), from the Italian for "dying"

moribund

In terminal decline; lacking vitality or vigor; nearing death or in a terminal decline [11]

morose

gloomy

morphic

probably short for "metamorphic," a type of rock

Morris Code

a misstatement of Morse Code

Morris Mini

another name for the Morris Minor a British car made from 1948–71.

mortification

extreme embarrassment

mortified

having undergone mortification of the flesh, i.e., abuse of the body by oneself as a form of penance

Motley

incongruously varied in character or appearance

Motrinish

I.e., like Motrin, the original brand name of ibuprofen

mottle

Spots of color.

mottled

marked with irregular patches or smears of color

Mount Auburn

probably the Mount Auburn Club in Watertown, Mass.

Mount Auburn Cemetery

the first landscaped cemetery in the U.S.

Mountain comes to Mohammed

Mountie

a member of the Royal Canadian Mounted Police, their equivalent of the FBI

Moët

Mr. Howell

Mr. Rogers

The Reverend Frederick McFeely "Fred" Rogers (1928-2003) was an American minister and children's television show host.

Hal's mother is named for the first time.

mucoid dessicators

drugs that dry up phlegm

mucosa

An absorptive/secretive tissue layer in the body; here, in Troeltsch's throat or nose

mucronate

having a projecting point; having abruptly projecting points; having an abruptly projecting point, as a feather or leaf.

Mud-Bug

a Southern term for a crawfish

a type of drink

mufflered

wearing scarves

mufti

civilian clothes; civilian dress; also a name for a type of Muslim scholar

mullah

a title of respect for one educated in Islamic law

multivalent

Mumkinsky

Funny that Steeply explains it as a pet name here, but everywhere else calls her "Mummykins"

mumus

the plural of what is actually muumuu, a long, formless, loose-hanging dress

municipal fluoridation

the addition of fluoride to public drinking- (tap-)water supplies to reduce tooth decay among the population; home filtration systems (such as Brita manufactures) can remove the flouride and thus eliminate the benefit

murated

a rarely used English word (found in OED ) meaning "surrounded by walls", from French: 'mur' = wall; Walled. From the Latin murare - to wall off.

Murder-2

second-degree murder, or murder without premeditation

Murnau in Méliès's fiberglass lap

Friedrich Wilhelm Murnau (1888-1931) was a German expressionist filmmaker who later worked in Hollywood. He made the classic vampire film "Nosferatu" (1922). Marie-Georges-Jean Méliès (1861-1938) was a French filmmaker, famous for the 1902 silent "A Trip to the Moon" (featured in Martin Scorsese's 2011 film "Hugo" ).

Muscimol

(also known as agarin or pantherine) is the principal psychoactive constituent of Amanita muscaria and related species of mushroom.

Muscimole

another mushroom-based hallucinogen, like psilocybin

mush

a cornmeal porridge, similar to grits but thicker

mushrooms or X

psilocybin mushrooms or MDMA (called ecstasy)

muskie

short for "muskellunge," a type of fish

muttonchops

very thick sideburns

Muzak

generic elevator-type music

muzzle

the barrel of a gun

mycological

Mydol

A misspelling of Midol .

mylar

a brand name of PET film

myopic

near-sighted

myriadly

countlessly

myristicin

Found in the essential oil of nutmeg. In addition to a semi-conscious state, myristicin also has been known to induce psychoactive effects such as visual distortions.

mysticetously

in the manner of a baleen whale

mythopoeia

the creating of a myth

mâché

French for "chewed" indicating here bits and pieces of the material. e.g., papier mâché

Médenine Tunisia

a city in the far south of Tunisia

möbiusizing

a neologism for taking on the shape of a Möbius strip

n'est ce―

Marathe trails off in the middle of n'est ce pas? (French: isn't it?)

National Cranio-Facial Pain Foundation

presumably fictitious, although there is a Craniofacial Pain Center in Boise, Idaho; where Schacht interns, Page 267

National-Socialist-Bundtism

The National Socialists were the Nazis, and bund is German for bunch, but it's unclear why Wallace uses Bundtism with the t rather than simply Bundism . This could refer to something like the German-American Bund of Fritz Julius Kuhn .

NATO

North Atlantic Treaty Organization

nauseous

Correctly used here. This word means "tending to cause nausea." If one has nausea, they are "nauseated."

nave

the part of the church with the pews on either side, facing the altar but not on the altar

naïf

a naive male

ne pas à la mode

neat bourbon

something that turns a liquid into a spray

necrosis

a term for death of bodily tissue

necrotic

dead

needly sound

dot-matrix printers are very loud. A dot-matrix printer produces characters by means of fine wires that impact the printer paper and an inked ribbon. DFW is referring to these wires (needles) which make a distinctive and rather unpleasant sound.

NeGram

a brand name of nalidixic acid, used to treat urinary tract infections

Nehru jacket

A collarless jacket named for Jawaharlal Nehru (1889-1964), first Prime Minister of India and father of Indira Gandhi. Nehru jackets were popular among hippies in the B.S. 1960s

Nein?

German: No?

Nelson Eddy

Nelson Ackerman Eddy (1901-1967) was an American singer and movie star . As far as what he looked like, see right.

neo-Georgian

modern-day architecture that approximates that of the Georgian period, from 1714 (accession of George I of the U.K.) to 1830 (death of George III); a revival of Georgian architecture or style

neologism

a newly coined word

Neonatal

of or relating to newborn children.

neorealist

adhering to Italian neorealism

nephritis

inflammation of the kidneys

Neponset

a neighborhood of Boston

nepotistic

relating to the practice of favoring relatives or friends

neurasthenic

regarding a syndrome of anxiety, fatigue, pain, etc., caused by exhaustion of the central nervous system; suffering from nervous exhaustion (with no apparent physical cause); a person suffering from a condition that is characterized especially by physical and mental exhaustion believed to result from psychological factors. (similar to chronic fatigue syndrome); chronically fatigued and weak

neuroform

Neuroform is actually the brand-name of a type of stent.

castrated

neutron

A subatomic particle with no charge.

New Bedford

a city of Massachusetts, about 50 miles south of Boston

a city about 50 miles southwest of Baton Rouge

When this term is used w/r/t Himself's work, it is probably referring to French New Wave, although there were several other "New Waves" in film.

In AA, medals, or chips, are awarded to commemorate certain lengths of sobriety

Ninth Step

The ninth of the original Twelve Steps of Alcoholics Anonymous is, "Made direct amends to such people wherever possible, except when to do so would injure them or others."

drink of alcohol

No cathode gun. No phosphenic screen.

A cathode gun is an electron gun used in a cathode ray tube. "Phosphenic" refers to phosphenes .

no-load funds

mutual funds in which shares are sold without a commission or sales charge

a boy who has a wet dream

Nodular leprosy with leonine facies

a form of leprosy that generates lesions made of nodes and that produces lion-like facial expressions (i.e., "leonine facies")

Noh-style

in the style of Noh (alternative romanization: "Nou"), which is the highly stylized, elaborately costumed classical drama of Japan

Nom

Gately means "Norm," as in the Cheers character "Norm Peterson" played by George Wendt; "Nom" is how a North Shore native such as Gately might pronounce the name.

nomonous

i.e., anonymous

non sequiturs

From the Latin for "it does not follow," a non sequitur is a statement with no connection to what comes before or what follows it.

nonarchaic

still in use, as distinct from those dictionary words considered archaic and not part of the modern language

nonchalant

coolly unconcerned

nongarish

Not garish, i.e., not excessively ornate.

Nordicular

i.e., Nordic, which is to say blond-haired and blue-eyed

Norfolk County

a county of Massachusetts bordering Rhode Island to the southwest

nostrums

patent medicines, i.e., quack medicines

not that much unlike Alyosha and Ivan's conversations in the good old Brothers K.

The Brother's Karamazov is a novel by Fyodor Mikhailovich Dostoevsky (1821-1881). Ivan and Alyosha, main characters in the novel, are siblings. Alyosha has a faith in God that manifests in a love of mankind and Ivan is a rationalist who is burdened by his inability or unwillingness to believe in a God that could preside over an unjust world. In the novel the brothers, Ivan and Alyosha, discuss their opposing beliefs.

notions

miscellaneous small, useful items

NOTRE RAI PAYS

perhaps idiomatic French (literally "our spoke [ or ray] country") for "our home away from home," indicating Québec's colonial status with respect to motherland France; potentially meant to be translated as "our shining land".

Nous v. La Plupart Toujours

French: Us versus the majority always

novenas

In Roman Catholicism, a novena is a devotion or set of prayers said over nine days.

novitiate

in the beginning period of something; a novice of a religious order

novocaine

a topical anesthetic typically used for dental procedures

Noxzema

a skin cleaner marketed by Procter & Gamble; A brand of skin cleanser

Attached to a drug name, this means it contains Naloxone.

descriptive of a bandage that closes a wound and keeps it from air

Ocean Spray

octogenarian

in one's eighties

odd-numbered game

Changes are after odd-numbered games because in tennis, a set is won by the first player to reach six, if ahead by two games. If the score were 4-4, the player with his back to the sun, for example, would have the advantage for two games if changes were after even-numbered games.

OED

The abbreviation for "Oxford English Dictionary."

oeuvre

body of work

offal

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Offal Internal organs and entrails of butchered animals.

ohm

unit of electrical resistance

Oiler

The former football team of Houston, now the Tennessee Titans.

Old Sod

A term for the "old country" among U.S. immigrants of Irish origin.

old super 8

They had a slow frame rate. Aperture is relative to shutter speed. The person speaking here seems very confused about everything they're saying.

olfactory hallucinations

hallucinations wherein one smells things that aren't there

olla

a pot for making stew, or stew itself

olla podrida

a type of stew popular in Spain (and the pot in which it is prepared and served)

Ollster

a nickname for Oliver, like "Ollie"

Ololiuqui or datura's scopolamine, or Fluothane, or Bufotenine (a.k.a. 'Jackie-O.'), or Ebene

Ololiuqui is a type of morning glory plants, the seeds of which are known to be hallucinogenic. Datura's scopolamine is another name for hyoscine . Fluothane is an inhaled general anesthetic. Bufotenine is an alternate spelling of bufotenin and is the active ingredient in the skin of toads that cause hallucinations when licked. (I have no idea why it's called "Jackie-O.") Ebene is a South American tree that yields a hallucinogen used in rituals.

omnissent

Orin means "omniscient."

On ne parle d'Anglais ici.

French: English is not spoken here

ON PARLE LE PORTUGAIS ICI

furthest up front, as in military formation

a physician who treats cancer

opaque

Opheliac

opine

to state one's opinion

opportunity-cost

In economics, this is what one loses in income, pleasure, etc., from engaging in another activity rather than the one that would have paid said income, pleasure, etc. Wallace (or Pemulis) is using the term incorrectly.

optative

Expressing a wish or choice.

oral labia

the lips of the mouth

oral-lyrologist

likely refers to someone who plays a jew's-harp as evidenced by references to theory of oral lyres on page 30, and as it is a musical instrument similar to a lyre, but played orally.

Orangemen

the Syracuse football team's name

orchasm

i.e., orgasm; an interesting gaffe considering it incorporates "chasm," meaning "abyss"

Order but not the same Family

Like "phylum," these are also taxonomical terms. Human beings are Homo sapiens, with Homo being the genus and sapiens being the species. Dogs and cats are in the same order: Carnivora (meat-eaters); but they are in different families: Dogs are in Canidae and cats in Felidae . However, the hyena, which resembles a dog, is actually in the Felidae family. Q.e.d.

ordinational

i.e., ordinal, or increasing by number

ordnance

explosives

Oreida

Or "Ore-Ida", maker of potato products and originator of Tater Tots; Thrust may be thinking "iota" at the same time

orevwar

i.e., au revoir, the French for "goodbye"

organic-coke

an oxymoronic term, since cocaine is a chemical

organopsychedelic

An organic molecule which, when ingested, produces a psychedelic effect.

Hal's older brother and the middle name of Hal & Orin's father, James O. Incandenza, literally "a tree" or "pale."
