outside linebacker

a defensive player who plays a few yards behind the line of scrimmage and behind one end of the defensive line or the other (as opposed to inside or middle linebackers, who are behind the center of the line)

Oven-toughened

metal and glass can be strengthened though a process known as tempering (cycles of extreme heating and cooling that alter the chemical structure of the material)

over-ebullient

excessively cheerful

overcognitive

thinking too much

ovoid

egg-shaped

own marijuana

To physically possess marijuana.

Oxbridge Quadrivium-Trivium

Oxbridge refers to the two oldest colleges in the U.K., Oxford and Cambridge. The Quadrivium are the four academic subjects of arithmetic, geometry, music and astronomy. The Trivium are three disciplines, i.e., grammar, logic, and rhetoric.

oxfords

formal shoes with laces

Oxycodone-nalaxone

Oxycodone also the active ingredient in Oxycontin. Naloxone blocks (partially, one must guess) the effects of opioids, probably to reduce abuse potential.

p-dope

heavily cut heroin

P.B.

perhaps "pulsed beam" or maybe just an inadvertent transposition of B.P. in reference to the same lights mentioned on p. 666

P.D.

public defender

P.E.

Physical Education; Physical Education, i.e., gym class

P.E.T.A.

People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals

P.E.T.s

P.E.T. is the acronym for positron emission tomography, a kind of medical imaging technique; these are more commonly called PET scans

P.M.

Prime Minister (of Canada)

p.m.

per minute

P.M.U.K.

Prime Minister of the United Kingdom

P.O.

philharmonic orchestra

P.O.W.ish

greedily, in the manner of p risoners o f w ar

P.Q.s

members of the Parti Québecois

P.T.A.s

Parent-Teacher Associations

P.T.s

Physical Therapists

PAC

Political Action Committee

Pac 10

The Pacific 10 athletic conference, the other members of which are: Arizona State Univ., Univ. of California at Berkeley, Univ. of Oregon, Oregon State Univ., Stanford Univ., UCLA, USC, Univ. of Washington, and Washington State Univ.

packy

short for "package store," a Massachusetts euphemism for "liquor store"

PACs

Political Action Committees

Paducah

a city in Kentucky about 175 miles southeast of St. Louis, Mo.

paisley

a popular design originating in Scotland

Paliacci

a misspelling of Pagliacci ( Clowns ), an opera by Ruggero Leoncavallo (1857-1919), an Italian composer

palisades

fences

pallor

an unhealthy pale appearance.

palmate

having four or more leaves emanating from a single point

Palmer Academy

There is a Palmer Academy in Florida, but it's in Haines City, sixty miles east of Tampa.

panagoraphobia

fear of going outside (agoraphobia) in any place (pan-)

pancreatitis

inflammation of the pancreas

pandemic

an epidemic that spreads through human populations across a large region (for example a continent), or even worldwide

Pandora's box of worms

a mixed metaphor of "Pandora's box" and "can of worms," neither of which can be shut again once they're opened

Panglossian

Pangloss is a comically optimistic character in Voltaire's Candide, who believes himself and his fellows to be living in "the best of all possible worlds."

panic-attack

another term for an anxiety attack

panoply

a wide-ranging array of things

pantalone

a stock mime character, often the butt of jokes

pap

something lacking true value or substance

Pap smears

screenings for female reproductive cancers, named for Georgios N. Papanikolaou (1883-1962), a Greek oncologist

papoose

While the word technically means "baby," Gately's usage is probably closer to that explained here .

paps

breasts or nipples

papular

having papules, i.e., inflamed, raised elevations on the skin not filled with pus

papuled, the macular, the albinic

Papules are inflammatory elevations of the skin. Macular means having opaque spots on the cornea. Albinic is having no melanin.

Parabnormal

another good one

parabola

a curve; more precisely a conic section formed by cutting a cone with a plane, where the plane is parallel to a line running along the cone's side from the vertex (point) to the circular base; see right

parabolic dusting of snow

and snow swirling in funnels and eddies Hal (or Wallace) is on a kind of annular jag with all this talk of ellipses, conic sections, parabolas, funnels and eddies, and even the guilloche pattern.

Parade Rest

a relaxed military stance with the feet shoulder's width apart and hands clasped behind the back

parallax

This is "the difference between the view of an object as seen through the picture-taking lens of a camera and the view as seen through a separate viewfinder" ( Random House Unabridged Dictionary ).

parallaxing

The noun parallax is a visual term; the nonce participle "parallaxing" used to describe noises here, may be Lenz's way of referring to the Doppler effect, analogous only in terms of issues of positional perspective, of the viewer of an object at some distance in the case of parallex and the hearer of a moving noisemaker (such as the siren on a speeding ambulance) in the case of the Doppler shift .

paralytic thought-helix

Paralytic would imply that this "thought-helix" stops everything else both physical and mental in Hal's actions/thoughts. A helix is a spiral, so a thought-helix is a thought-spiral, which goes on and on but never really gets anywhere.

Parapectolin

a mixture of kaolinite and pectin, used to treat diarrhea

parasolled

having an umbrella on or in it

parfait

a tall glass filled with ice cream

parget

plaster used for covering walls

pargeting

A form of plasterwork shown to the right.

parietal

referring to the parietal lobe of the brain, responsible for sensory memory and response

parietooccipital

referring to both the parietal lobe of the brain, as well as the occipital lobe, which is where vision is processed

Parizeau

This is probably Jacques Parizeau (born 1930), a former Premier of Québec and proponent of Québecois sovereignty.

parley

to hold a discussion

parliamentary wigs

Canadian MPs don't wear wigs, though barristers (lawyers) and judges do.

Parnate

A brand name of tranylcypromine, a monoamine oxidase inhibitor (MAOI) antidepressant that is among the oldest class of antidepressants and that have a load of serious side effects. Usually used as a last resort.

parodic

having the qualities of a parody

parodically

in a sarcastic or mocking way

parotitic

having the mumps

paroxysmic

characteristic of an outburst of violent emotion

parping

According to the OED, a parp is a honking sound; parping is defined as causing something (as a car horn) to parp.

parquet

An in-laid wood pattern, often a block-pattern, typically in flooring. Also, in France, the branch of the law that deals with the persecution of crime.; wooden mosaic flooring

Partridge Family

the band featured on the television series of the same name

Partridge, KS

A town in Kansas about 55 miles north-northwest of Wichita

parturient

about to give birth

Party-Size Cubelets

miniature ice cubes

PAs

public-address sytems

pases

This is the plural of pase, a Spanish word used in bullfighting to denote the movement of the matador's cape in drawing in the bull.

pass

here used to mean "place"

Passaic NJ

near Montclair, Passaic is another western suburb of New York

passed

in tennis, a passing shot is a shot which travels out of the opponents reach, typically occurring when the opponent is running to or has reached the net

passé

out of style

pastiche

describing a work that imitates the style of another work, artist, movement or period

Pat Cash

Patrick Hart "Pat" Cash (born 1965) was an Australian pro tennis player, winning Wimbledon in 1987.

patellar tendon

the tendon connecting the patella (kneecap) to the tibia (shinbone)

pathogenic

capable of producing disease

pathos

a quality that evokes pity

patissiers

French: pastry chefs

patrician

aristocratic

patricidal

having a tendency to kill one's father

Patridge KS

a city in Kansas about 60 miles northwest of Wichita

paucity

scarcity

Paul Harvey

Paul Harvey (1918-2009) was an American radio broadcaster known for his platitudes.

Pawtucket

a town in Rhode Island 5 miles north-northeast of Providence

pay it forward

thus the title of this movie

payloader

a, usually wheeled, heavy machine used to move or load construction materials similar to a bulldozer

payloaders

a type of construction equipment

PCs

Personal Computers

Peano, Leibniz, Hilbert

Giuseppe Peano (1858-1932) was an Italian mathematician. Gottfried Wilhelm Leibniz (1646-1716) was a German polymath and one of the creators of calculus. David Hilbert (1862-1943) was a German mathematician.

peasant skirt

a long, flowing skirt usually featuring bands of embroidery

pebbled glass

a drinking glass having a rough surface

pectorals

chest muscles

pedagogical

Having to do with teaching.

pedalferrous

pedalfer is a soil type composed of aluminum and iron oxides. http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pedalfer apparently a neologism, the word would mean "of or pertaining to foot metal," i.e., fast driving

pejorative

derogatory, disparaging (Hal indicating that the phrase "my reputation preceded me" is generally used in a pejorative sense); meant to offend or belittle

Pen Registers

an electronic device that records the phone numbers of outgoing calls on a particular line

Penal Matron

in other words, a female prison warden

penchant

a predilection

pendular 180-arc of Orin's leg

meaning Orin's leg moves the full length of half a circle around the center that is his hip, in a motion similar to that of a pendulum

penitent

showing regret for having done wrong; repentant

Penn Station

the chief national train station in New York, at 34th Street and Eighth Avenue; a terminal for both Amtrak and the Long Island Rail Road (LIRR)

pennon

a pennant or flag or banner

pentazocine

a synethetic opioid painkiller

penultimate

next to the last; next-to-last; second to last

penumbra

a shadowy, gray area

Peoria IL

a city around 160 miles southwest of Chicago

Pepperdine

a university in Malibu, Calif.; a private university near Malibu, California

per diem

Latin: per day

perambulation

walking

perfidy

treachery

perforce

by force of circumstance

Perfunctory

(of an action or gesture) carried out with a minimum of effort or reflection.

perfunctory

performed with minimal effort or care, done just out of routine or duty

pericardium

the membrane surrounding the heart

pericardium-piercer

heart-breaker

perimeter

the oustide edge of something

Peripatetic

walking around

peripatetic

walking around

periphery

fringe; outer boundary; an external boundary

peristyle

a colonnade surrounding an open space, or the space so encircled

peritonitis

inflammation of the serous membrane lining the abdomenal cavity

perk

i.e., perquisite, a special benefit

Permettez Nous Partir, Permettez Nous Être.

French: Allow us to leave, allow us to be.

permutations

arrangements of the same items in different sequences

pernicious

subtly harmful; harmful

pernt

point

pernts

points

peronic or teratoidal

Peronic probably means having a bent penis (from Peyronies disease), while teratoidal means malformed.

peroxide

hydrogen peroxide (H 2 O 2 ), used as a bleach and whitener

Perseus

the Greek hero who beheaded Medusa (cf. The Medusa v. The Odalisque ), using the head to kill others; compared here to the A.F.R. ("the legs ... were amputated") which steals the Entertainment and uses it to kill others

persona

a fictional identity created for a person, narrator in a book, etc.

personnel works

(personal works) - personal equipment for injecting drugs

perspicacity

keenness of perception

perspicuous

clearly expressed; clearly expressed

Perth Amboy NJ

a town in northern NJ, about 30 miles southwest of New York

pertussive

accompanied by coughing

pertussives

cough suppressants

Pet-Rockish

inane, like the fad phenomenon of the small stones marketed as live "pets," requiring care and feeding, in the silly '70s

petaled ass

(peddled ass) prostituted himself

Peter

the middle son, played by Christopher Knight

Peterson's The Cage

"The Cage", a 28-minute surrealistic film from 1947, directed by Sidney Peterson

Peterson's The Lead Shoes

An 18-minute film by Sidney Peterson (1949), preceded by Michael Powell and Emeric Pressburger's great The Red Shoes (1948) with Moira Shearer. (Cf. the color in the title of the fictitious monograph in endnote 81.)

Peterson/Broughton and Dali/Buñuel

Sidney Peterson and James Broughton collaborated on The Potted Psalm (1946), an experimental film.

petrification

the process of turning into stone

petrochemical

a chemical derived from petroleum or natural gas

Petropolis Kahn

Petropolis is Greek for "city of stone" or "city of Peter." Petrópolis is a city in Brazil near Rio de Janeiro. A treaty was signed there on November 11, 1903, ending hostilities between Bolivia and Brazil.

petulant

unreasonably irritable

Phalanx

From the Ancient Greek military formation comprising a group of soldiers standing closely together, meaning a close-knit organized group moving forward.

phallocentric

biased from a male point of view

phalloneurotic

a portmanteau of phallus and neurotic, probably intended to mean a mental disorder involving obsession with one's penis, or perhaps with penis more generally; uncertain as to which "phalloneurotic" New Yorker this refers

phalluctomy

Neologism probably referring to the removal of the penis

phantasms

apparitions or specters

phantom pains

refers to pain common in amputees - also can refer to sensations that the amputated limb is still existent, and painful

phasece

neologism; presumably a back-formation to a plural noun from the adjective 'phasic,' which in medical parlance means "Of the activity of excitable cells or tissues: discontinuous; irregular; not tonic" (OED). "Pulmonary phasece" would be heart palpitations.

phenols

another name for carbolic acid

phenylkylamine

Possibly a made-up substance, similar to synthetic substance, phenylalkylamine, and the psychotropic alkylamines

Pheromonic Musk

a scent designed to emit pheromones, or a chemical that attracts the opposite sex

Phielyism

this is in reference to coach R. Bill ('Touchy') Phiely on the previous page

philatelic forceps, a loupe

Philatelic refers to stamp collecting. A loupe is used primarily by a jeweler to view flaws in diamonds.

philately

stamp collecting

Philip Glass

Philip Glass (born 1937) is an American music composer and pianist. His music is repetitive and minimalist.

Philo IL

town about 150 miles south-southwest of Chicago

Philology

The study of literature or language.

phobophobia

fear of fear

phocomelic

having extremely short limbs

Phoenician

Orin uses it to mean a native of Phoenix, but the Phoenicians were actually an ancient culture who founded the city of Carthage.

phonetic perspective

Judging from the way the words sound when spoken.

phosphenes

light sensations in the eyes when light is physically absent

phosphenic migraine

the phenomenon of seeing lights accompanying a migraine

photic

having to do with light

photosynthesizing

turning light into energy, as plants do

phrenologically malformed

malformed in the shape of the skull

phylacteryish

Remove "-ish" and you have the English word for tefillin .

phylogenic

regarding the evolution of an organism; From phylogeny, the study of changes and developments in organisms' lineages. Phylogenetic is the more common adjectival form.

phylum

A taxonomical term just below Kingdom (in humans, Animal), the phylum of mammals is Chordata, which means they have a spinal cord.

Physical Modality

Modality, in linguistics, refers to sign theory. Physical modality would, therefore, be either how a physical thing is represented by a sign or how any idea is represented by something physical.

piamater

actually two words: Pia mater

pica

craving to eat things that are not foods, occasionally occurring in pregnant women ( Wikipedia )

picayune

small or trifling; trivial

picric

Picric acid is an explosive, so the word "picric" w/r/t clouds probably implies an explosive (or about to explode) quality. It is also a toxic yellow.

piebald

having patches of different colors; having patches of black and white

Pierre Trudeau

Joseph Philippe Pierre Yves Elliott Trudeau (commonly called Pierre-Elliot Trudeau; 1919-2000) was the Prime Minister of Canada for most of the 1970s and from 1980 to 1984.

Pillsbury Doughboy

"The Pillsbury Doughboy" is a small anthropoid character apparently made out of dough. ( Wikipedia )

Pilotone blooper

Pilotone is an old brand of film equipment, and a blooper is, according to the Random House Unabridged Dictionary, "a receiving set that generates from its antenna radio-frequency signals that interfere with other nearby receivers."

pince-nez

From the French for "pinch-nose," these are glasses without temples to go over the ears.

pincer movement

a military maneuver whereby an enemy is attacked not from the front, but at both sides or flanks

pinion

v. tr., "To restrain or immobilize (a person) by binding the arms" ( thefreedictionary.com )

Pink2

Footnote 95 (to p. 284) reads "Pink being Microsoft Inc.'s first post-Windows DOS, quickly upgraded to Pink2 when InterLace took everything 100 % interactive and digital; by Y.D.A.U. it's kind of a dinosaur, but it's still the only DOS that'll run a MathpakVEndStat tree without having to stop and recompile every few seconds."

pinwheel-eyed

Gately is thinking of the spiraling eyes often seen in hypnotized or narcotized cartoon characters, a convention much like that of indicating a dead cartoon character with small crosses in the place of the eyes.

piping

This is a tubular band of ornamental material; Nodie is probably a brand name.

pique

resentment; feeling of resentment

Pir Valayat

Pir Vilayat Inayat Khan (1916-2004) was a British-born Sufi.

pirouette

a spin, in ballet terminology

pirouetting

Whirling on the toes.

pissboys

people who administer urine drug tests

Pisser

remarkable, alternatively, disappointing

pistil

that part of a flower that is analogous to the female reproductive organs

piteously

pitifully

pithed

having had a needle stuck into the base of the skull to sever or destroy the brainstem

pitons

spikes used by mountain climbers for support

Pityriasis Rosea

a skin disease marked by patches of pink, oval rash

pixel-free

smooth and not pixelated

pizzicato

the musical effect of the plucking of strings on a classical instrument

Pizzitola

probably a reference to the Pizzitola Sports Center in Providence, R.I.

pièce

as in "pièce de resistance," the punchline or main point

placative

intending to pacify or calm

placenta

the tissue that nourishes a fetus and makes up the afterbirth

Plains of Abraham

a reference to the Battle of the Plains of Abraham, part of the French and Indian Wars, which ended in a decisive British victory of the French

plaintiffly

Lenz means "plaintively."

plangent

Loud and resounding.

plasm

synonym of plasma, i.e., a state of matter most similar to gas; probably used here in the sense of a dense gas

Plasma spheres

another name for a plasma lamp

plasticene

misspelling of Plasticine, a brand name of plastic used for making molds

plastron

Definitions include: 1. the starched front of a shirt; 2. a large pad worn by a fencer to protect the chest; and 3. The part of a tortoise's shell that covers the underside. Mario wears an apparatus something like a tortoise's shell that fits around his deformed torso and allows him to carry his camera equipment in the pack on his back.

plateaux

the proper French plural of "plateau," rather than "plateaus"

Plc

public limited company

plestor

Another name for a pleximeter .

pleurisy

inflammation of the pleurae, the membranes surrounding the lungs

plexus

an intricate network, no doubt a reference to the solar plexus, a blow to which results in having "one's wind knocked out" because it temporarily causes the diaphragm not to function

pliability

the ability to be easily bent

Pliscu Romania

There doesn't seem to be a real city by this name either, though pliscu seems to be a word pertaining to the nose.

plosivity

Referring to a plosive or linguistic stop, i.e., a sound in a language characterized by the stopping of the breath: examples include not only the phonemes /p/ and /b/, but /t/, /d/, etc. .

pluck

courage or resolution in the face of difficulty; resourceful daring in the face of great difficulty

plucky

having or showing courage and spirit in trying circumstances

plum

an excellent or desirable thing

plumb

adj., straight or true; in line with; exactly

plume

here, a stream of water resembling a feather

plura

a misspelling (likely) of "pleura," which is a thin membrane enclosing the lungs

plutonium-239

a fissile isotope of plutonium

plywood

material made of thin layers of wood glued together

Pléaide Classics

better known as Bibliothèque de la Pléaide

PMA

acronym for paramethoxyamphetamine

pneumatic

1.using air pressure to move or work 2.filled with air 3.of a woman : having a body with full, pleasing curves mirriam-webster

podiatric

having to do with the foot

Point Shirley

a neighborhood on Deer Island, south of Winthrop, Massachusetts, in the Massachusetts Bay east of Boston

pointers

a breed of hunting dog; A pointer is a breed of hunting dog

poison sumac

a tall shrub containing urushiol, which causes a rash similar to poison ivy

Pokie

apparently a childhood nickname for Joelle

polybutylene

This is polymerized butlyene .

Polycleitos

more commonly Polykleitos, a Greek sculptor of the fifth century BC most commonly known for his canonical sculpture Doryphoros (see right)

polyresin

a resin compound used to make figurines, among other things

polyslyable

not a word. polysyllabic means consisting of several, especially four or more, syllables, as a word.

polysterene

styrofoam

Pomade

a substance men used to use to style their hair

pomander

This is "a mixture of aromatic substances, often in the form of a ball, formerly carried on the person as a supposed guard against infection but now placed in closets, dressers, etc." ( Random House Unabridged Dictionary ).

Pompano Beach

a town in Florida about 10 miles north of Fort Lauderdale

ponce

an effeminate man

ponderous

awkward or unwieldy

Pons and abducent

The Pons is a structure on the brain stem, while the abducens nerve is a nerve in the muscles of the eye.

poofta

i.e., a poofter, a vulgar term for a male homosexual

Pooh-wear

Children's clothing bearing Winnie-the-Pooh cartoon images or graphics, presumably pajamas in this instance

Poor Richard

the putative author of a famous almanac published (from 1732 to 1758) by Benjamin Franklin

pop

Midwesterners in the U.S. use this word to denote what others call "soda," i.e., Coca-Cola, 7-Up, etc. See also "tonic," p. 478.

Popogatapec

probably a reference to Popocatépetl an active volcano, located in Central Mexico

poppy-seed bagel

conventional wisdom has it that eating such bagels could cause one to test positive for opiates

porcine

like a swine

pores

i.e., pores over books, reads them carefully

port or starboard

left or right

Port Washington

There are three cities by this name in the U.S.: In New York, Wisconsin, and Ohio.

Port Washington Academy

PW in Long Island is the largest indoor tennis facility on the east coast. It's also a nonprofit and looks small Compared to ETA/IMG

portcullis

This is "a strong grating, as of iron, made to slide along vertical grooves at the sides of a gateway of a fortified place and let down to prevent passage" ( Random House Unabridged Dictionary ).

portents

omens

Porter Square, Cambridge

a neighborhood of Cambridge bordering on Somerville, about a mile from Tufts University, which is on the Somerville/Medford border

Portsmouth OH

a town about 90 miles due south of Columbus, Ohio

Posener

There is no such person at Brandeis.

Positron-Emission Topography

According to Wikipedia, this is "a nuclear medicine medical imaging technique that produces a three-dimensional image or map of functional processes in the body." [Except that the third word should be Tomography. Is this a typo, or something significant?]

positrons

the sub-atomic particles that are the opposite of electrons

Possession With Intent

i.e., with intent to distribute

Post-Coital Vestibulitis

Vestibulitis is inflammation of the vestibule, or vaginal opening, and thus a woman's affliction, although the related (but rare) pudendal neuralgia can occur in men; the more common symptom of the latter is pain when sitting.

Post-Fourier Transformations

Named for Jean Baptiste Joseph Fourier (1768-1830), a French mathematician, a Fourier transformation is "a certain linear operator that maps functions to other functions" (Wikipedia). Post-Fourier would refer to those transformations that came after Fourier.

post-Gödelian

Coming after Kurt Gödel (1906-1978), Austrian-American mathematician and philosopher.

post-latency

after the latency period that Freud posited in his four-stage theory of psychosexual development in children

post-Marxist

an adherent school of thought that encompasses the arts as well as politics

post-mortem

Latin: after death

post-Perot

i.e., after the immediate era of Texan H. Ross Perot, founder of Electronic Data Systems and twice an indepedent U.S. presidential candidate (in 1992 and in 1996, as the leader of his Reform Party)

post-prandial

Following a meal.; after a meal

post-prandially

after eating a meal

post-Windows DOS

A DOS is a Disk Operating System, the programming by which a computer runs other programs. Microsoft has not issued a new DOS after Windows as of 2016 and claims they never will.

Powell's Peeping Tom

Michael Latham Powell (1905-1990) was a British filmmaker, and Peeping Tom was one of his films.

power forward

the one of the two forwards in basketball who more often will drive to the net

PowerBook

an Apple brand of laptop computer, preceding the MacBook

practicum

the student-teaching portion of a teaching education

prandial

(for) eating

pratfall

a fall on one's rear

pre-British-takeover Québecois

The British took over Quebec on September 8, 1760.

pre-infarcted

an infarct is when a piece of organ tissue, usually in the brain or heart (stroke or heart attack, respectively), is deprived of oxygen for a period of time because of a blockage or thrombosis, and either dies or is significantly weakened

pre-Method actor

He was an actor before the dawn of the Method .

pre-metric

in the alternate timeline of Infinite Jest, it's obvious that U.S. Customary systems of measurement are finally abandoned, at some point (perhaps during Reconfiguration), for the global standard of the Metric System ( ed. : optimism on Wallace's part, one might say) - the weights the M.P. used were marked with U.S. "pounds" (lbs) instead of Metric kilograms (kg).

pre-Oedipal

occurring prior to the Oedipus complex typically experienced from ages 3-6

precipice

a cliff with a vertical face; steep rock face or cliff

precipitant

sudden, hasty, or rash

precipitate

product of precipitation

pregnable

open to attack; capable of being won by force

pregnancy by rain

referring to Zeus's seduction of Danae

pregnant

teeming or fertile

Preludin

Preludin is also an appetite suppressant and amphetamine with much more abuse and addiction potential.

premie

born prematurely

Premium

high-octane gasoline

prenatal dentition

growth of teeth before birth

prenominate

named beforehand; aforementioned

Preparation H

a brand-name ointment for hemorrhoids

presaging

an indication or warning of a future occurrence

presbyopic

Literally "old-eyed," this is the inability to focus one's eyes as one grows older

prescient

having previous knowledge

Prescriptive Grammar

This term describes a school of thought that there are rules of grammar that should be obeyed and taught. Wallace wrote at length about the thorny questions surrounding this subject in the famous essay, "Tense Present: Democracy, English, and the Wars over Usage," which can be found at http://www.harpers.org/archive/2001/04/0070913

President

here referring to Franklin Roosevelt

President's Physical Fitness Test

You can read about this program here .

Presque Isle ME

a city of Maine about 20 miles west of the border with New Brunswick, Canada

Pressburger

Until the city was renamed Bratislava (currently the capital of Slovakia), a person from that Pressburg was called a Pressburger.

preternatural

out of the ordinary course or nature

Prettiest G.O.A.T.

Though G.O.A.T. stands here for "Girl Of All Time," it's an oxymoron, because "goat" is a slang term for an ugly person.

prevarication

avoiding the truth by not directly answering a question

preverbally

before speaking

Priapism

an erection that won't go away

priapism

persistent, usually painful erection of the penis, especially as a consequence of disease and not related to sexual arousal

priapistic

having priapisms, or painful, long-lasting erections

priapistic-entertainment cartridge

priapistic: Persistent, usually painful erection of the penis, especially as a consequence of disease and not related to sexual arousal.

prickets

sharp metal points on which to stick candles

pride

family of lions

prima facie

Latin: at first sight

Primestar

a direct broadcast satellite network active in the 1990s

Prince Albert in a can

An old phone gag explained in the Wikipedia entry for the popular pipe tobacco sold in the distinctive red tin can with its portrait of Prince Albert (later King Edward VII) on its obverse side.

Prince Valiantish haircut

Prince Valiant in the Days of King Arthur, or simply Prince Valiant, is a comic strip created by Hal Foster, which began running in 1937. Prince Valiant's haircut is a pageboy with long tresses in back, as seen at right.

princess-and-pea

a reference to the fairy tale "The Princess and the Pea," wherein despite several mattresses, a princess can still feel a single pea below her

Principles of Psychology and the Gifford Lectures on Natural Philosophy

" William James’s Gifford Lectures of 1901–1902 have been heralded by some as the greatest lectures ever to be presented in the series and perhaps the most seminal of his works (alongside The Principles of Psychology). Published initially in 1902, The Varieties of Religious Experience: A Study in Human Nature has stood the test of time and been republished thirty-six times."

pro bono

without pay

pro forma

as a routine, formality

pro-bonoing

providing free of charge

probability waves for subhadronics

Probability waves are a concept in quantum physics that expresses the probability that "a particle or particles in a particular state will be measured to have a given position and momentum" (Wikipedia). Subhadronic refers to a particle smaller than a hadron .

Probie

probation officer

probity

integrity; integrity or honesty

proclavity

Gately means "proclivity"

product

as opposed to the torch it currently holds

Professor H. Bloom

Harold Bloom (born 1930) is a prominent American literary critic.

profligate

recklessly extravagant; extravagant; wasteful

prognathous

having one's lower jaw project beyond the upper part of one's face

Projectile-incontinence

inability to hold owns bowels to the extent that feces shoot out of the anus

prolix

extended to a great, unneedy length; extended to great, unnecessary, or tedious length; long and wordy.; tediously long or wordy

Promethean

suggestive of Prometheus, probably in the sense of bold and defiant

promoted

i.e., stolen

promulgated

make widely known

pronator teres

a muscle of the forearm

propinquous

Probably what's intended is "propinquitous," meaning "proximal" or "nearby."

propitiate

to win or reclaim favor with

propitiating

appeasing

proprietary

Usually referring to an owner, here it refers to feeling as if one has a sense of ownership.

proprioception

the sense of the relative position of neighbouring parts of the body. ( Wikipedia )

prorector

See prorector . Possibly an originally German term. Also see prorector index entry .

prorectors

members of a management body of a university, each managing his/her specific area

prosfeces

i.e., prostheses

prostrate

lying flat on the ground (or, here, a bed)

proto-Fascist

Wallace really means "quasi-Fascist" rather than "proto-Fascist"; it's not as if the rules of AA are the harbinger of Fascism to come.

protozoan

a single-celled organism

Provincial

Switzerland does not have provinces; it has cantons.

Provincial Autoroute 55

Quebec north-south highway that runs from Shawinigan to Stanstead at the US border, where it connects with...

proviso

a clause, usually in a document, making a stipulation or qualification

Provo UT

a city about 45 miles south of Salt Lake City

prurient

causing lust; inordinately interested in matters of sex; lascivious

Pruritis

very bad itching

Prussian

here used to mean "very strict"

psoriatic

this is in reference to psoriasis, a skin condition that produces whitish, scale-like scabs of dead skin; the paint is flaking or peeling

psychodysleptic

Inducing a delusional mental state; hallucinatory.

psychomotor seizure

a seizure characterized by psychic manifestation, and an older name for a complex motor seizure

psychosensory

... psychosensory would be more nearly precise, as it would apply to sensory stimulation, not necessarily sexual.

psychosensual

Whereas psychosensual would have a more sexual connotation...

psychosphere

sort of a synonym for collective consciousness

puce

dark or brownish purple

puerile

pugnacious

Puker

a punitive run designed to make one vomit

pulchritudinous

pules

pungently

in a way that sharply affects the organs of sense

pupil and iris

The pupil is the black circle at the center of the eye, while the iris is the colored part (blue, green, brown).

puppet-à-clef

A roman à clef is a novel based on a true story with the actual names of characters changed (similarly for film à clef). So, the puppet show has changed the names of the Clipperton story.

purgatorial

Serving to purify of sin; expiatory.

Purity Supreme Market

A New England supermarket chain that ceased operations in 1997 after being bought by a competitor.

purling

flowing or rippling

purloined

stolen

purple

????

Purple-Hearted

A soldier receives a Purple Heart when s/he is wounded

purposive

serving some purpose

purview

scope of vision

putative

supposed; supposed

putrid

decomposing or rotten

PVC pipe cleaner

A product for preparing PVC to be chemically bonded. Usually mixtures of organic solvents, such as Acetone, Cyclohexanone, Methyl Ethyl Ketone and Tetrahydrofuran, e.g. this bad boy

PX

with a pharmaceutical as part of the name, it means it contains pentazocine

Pyrex

a brand name of heat-resistant glass

pyrotechnic

explosive, like fireworks ("pyrotechnic glandular atmosphere" must imply an orgasmic situation)

Pépé or Bébé

apparently the name of the dog that Lenz just killed

Q-dopa

not a real neurotransmitter

Q.v.

abbreviation for the Latin quod vide, meaning "which see"; Latin abbreviation for quod vide ("which see"), used to direct a reader elsewhere in a book. Here we are directed to...

Qal'at Si'man

Qantas

an airline serving Australia and New Zealand

qua

From the Latin ablative case of the word for "who," this word means "in the character or capacity of."; in the capacity or character of

Quaalude

quaaludes

capsules or caplets of Methaqualone, a sedative often used recreationally

queer a square beef

French: something

quiche

a baked flan or tart with a savory filling thickened with eggs

quick-bit

Wallace neologism for "bitten to the quick", as in nails gnawed down to where they emerged from the fingertips

quiescent

still or at rest

Quik

a powder mix used to make chocolate milk

quincunx

The arrangement of five units in the pattern corresponding to the five-spot on dice (see right).

Quincy Market

a shopping area in downtown Boston. Like the nearby suburb, Quincy is pronounced "Quinzy."

quixotic

impulsive or rashly unpredictable

Quo Vadis

Latin: Where are you going? Famously asked of Jesus by Peter when the former was on his way to be crucified. See here. Also a novel and film by that name were made.

WHAT?

quoins

Quonsets

quorum

the required minimum number of people required to carry forth a particular task; the minimal number of people required to be present, usually within an organization (in this case, The Tunnel Club), for an official piece of business to occur

R.E.M. and Pearl Jam

R.E.M.'s lead singer, Michael Stipe, was famous for his unintelligible lyrics until around 1987's Document . Pearl Jam's vocalist, Eddie Vedder, is as cryptic now as he was fifteen years ago, when they released their first record.

R.H.I. literal P.

R ank H as I ts literal P riveleges (see R.H.I.P. on page 627)

R.H.I.P.

Rank Has Its Privileges

R.I.S.C.

reduced instruction set computer, i.e., a computer that takes a limited set of commands

rack

bed (perhaps a bunk, here)

racy mosaics

Referring to aforementioned Byzantine Erotica. Mosaics are detailed pictures created with very small pieces of stone.

Radarange

The name of the original microwave oven by Amana

Radcliffe's Bunting Institute

Radcliffe is the women's college at Harvard University. According to the Harvard Web site, "The Bunting Institute is a mutidisciplinary center for women scholars, writers, artists, and activists of demonstrated achievement and promise. Each year, approximately 40 women pursue projects that make significant contributions to their fields, working in a community that fosters interdisciplinary discourse, and creative and intellectual leadership. Some describe their experience as "the Bunting transformation."

Rader

If the name is pronounced with a "long a," as in the Oakland football team, a famous person with this last name was Erich Johann Albert Raeder (1876-1960), a World War II-era German grand admiral, sentenced to life at Nuremberg but served only nine years.

radial nerve

a nerve running from above the shoulder (in the neck) down the length of the arm

radically -ectomied

-having to do with body-part removal (think radical mastectomy)

radon

a chemical element that contaminates homes in gaseous form

Rafferty

Terrence Rafferty was a film critic for the New Yorker magazine.

Raggedy Andy

a popular doll seen here

Ragheads

derogatory term for people who wear keffiyehs or turbans

raglan

having sleeves that go in one piece to the neckline

raisin jack

an alcoholic drink fermented from raisins, commonly made in prisons

raison

raison d'être - reason or justification for existence

raison d'être

French: reason for being; French: reason for being

rakish

jaunty or dashing

Ralston

breakfast cereal

RAM

Random Access Memory

Ram Das

A reference to Baba Ram Dass (born 1931 as Richard Alpert), an American-Jewish spiritual leader, author of Be Here Now, and large influence on Pete Townshend .

Ramparts and Commonweal

Ramparts was a magazine founded for a Catholic leadership but eventually found its niche with the New Left. Commonweal was and still is a publication by and for lay Catholics.

rancid-cinnamon smell

possibly the odor of the stink bug (see right); ironically, cinnamon itself can be used to dispel rancid odors; or, more likely, at least a way of covering up the odor of drugs, see, e.g., footnote 324, page 1067, where Permulis uses cayenne pepper to a similar purpose.

Randolph Tennis Center

The Randolph Tennis Center is a real place, near Tucson, Ariz. and the main campus of the University of Arizona.

rank amateurs

complete/total amateurs

rankness

the quality of being offensive

Rantoul IL

a town 125 miles south-southwest of Chicago

rapacial

i.e., rapacious

rapacious

Aggressively greedy.; ravenous

rape by fowl

and Zeus's seduction of Leda

raptly

with intense attention to

rarified

a misspelling of "rarefied," meaning "esoteric"

rasa the tabula

This is a playful inversion of tabula rasa, Latin for "blank state" and used in the philosophy of John Locke (1632-1704). The sense here is to clean the slate.

rattan

material taken from the rattan plant, a climbing palm with very long stems

ravacious

This would seem to be a cross between "ravenous" and "rapacious."

ravening

voracious

Raytheon

a major American defense contractor

RCA-Victorish

The image can be seen to the right.

RCC

Roman Catholic Church

re-gerrymandered

To gerrymander is to divide an area into electoral districts favorable to one party over another.

reading his hours

The Liturgy of the Hours is the set of daily prayers prescribed by the Catholic Church as part of the canonical obligation of those ordained as deacons. The prayers take place throughout the day: Matins or Vigils, during the night; Lauds or Dawn Prayer; Prime or Early Morning Prayer; Terce or Mid-Morning Prayer; Sext or Midday Prayer; None or Mid-Afternoon Prayer; Vespers or Evening Prayer; Compline or Night prayer.

reagent

a substance used to produce other substances

real filmic McCoy

an interpolation of "filmic" (cinematic) into the familar expression "real McCoy," signifying authenticity

real-French

as opposed to Québecois French

rear-mount engine

the classic Volkswagen bugs have rear-mounted engines ( https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Volkswagen_Beetle ). The "New Beetle" has a front engine: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Volkswagen_New_Beetle

Rebel Yell

a battle cry used by Confederate soldiers during the American Civil War

recalcitrant

hard to deal with or manage

recapitulating

summarizing

recesstacle

apparently a combination of "recess" and "receptacle"

recidivism

the state of falling back into a life of crime

recompile

Some programs needed to be "compiled" before they run, depending on the computer language in which they're written. Recompiling would be compiling over again.

recondite

Esoteric, arcane.; dealing with complex subject matter.

rectum

the very end of the large intestine

Rectus Bulbi

short name for the superior rectus muscle

recumbency

here used to mean someone lying down (i.e., Hal); perhaps a chaise longue

recumbent

reclining

recursive

repetitive; repeating in a self similar manner. Recursion is a favorite technique of computer programmers and mathematicians; a recursive function is one that is called within its own definition. For a fun demonstration of recursion, try googling it

recurving

i.e., recurring

Red Sox of Rice and Lynn

Jim Rice (1974-1989) and Fred Lynn (1974-1980) both played in the 1975 World Series.

REDCHI

The People's Republic of China

redemised

"Demise" is a legal term meaning to convey or lease land. Redemised title would normally refer to an interest returned to the original owner, as in a sale and lease-back, but may here just refer to a second transfer of title, or regifting as we say at Christmas time.

redemisement

see discussion of "redemised" at page 319

Redi-Whip

actually Reddi-wip, a brand name of pressurized whipped cream in a can

redolent

exuding fragrance (in this case, apparently an unpleasant one); extremely fragrant

redoubted

formidable

reductia ad absurdum

If, as it appears, Geoffrey wants to pluralize reductio ad absurdum, (Latin: argument to absurdity) he wants reductiones. reductio ad absurdum is a common form of argument which seeks to demonstrate that a statement is true by showing that a false, untenable, or absurd result follows from its denial.

reductive statistics

Wallace is talking either about the process in statistics of reducing variables or Schtitt's use of statistics being reductive, i.e., being simplistic

reek

to smell very badly

Reflective vs. Reflexive Systems

These are two systems of cognition, the latter is associative, rapid in processing, and subconscious, while the former is rule-based and thus slower.

refracted

bent or twisted by a change in medium. An optics term, so this is an oblique reference to filming.

refraction

here referring to the splitting of white light into a spectrum of color

regentrifying

Lenz means "regenerating" rather than "refurbishing (again)"

reglets

narrow, flat moldings

regressed

applied statistical analysis

regrettably fatal technical interview

an interrogation accompanied by torture resulting in the interviewee's death

regrout

replace the grout (construction material used to seal the gaps between tiles)

regs

regulations

reguiles

i.e., regales (and simultaneously beguiles)

rejoinder

sharp, witty response

REM

Rapid Eye Movement

remanded

placed into custody

Remington-hung

Hal is referring to the fact that the office he's in is decorated with art by Frederic Remington (1861-1909), an American painter whose work can be seen online here .

remonstrances

acts of protest

remora

a fish that attaches itself to sharks for easier travel

renal calculus

renumeration

Context indicates that the word should be remuneration .

repast

meal

replete

full

repose

rest

requisite

essential or necessary

reseau

a reference grid of fine lines forming uniform squares on a photographic plate or print, used to aid in measurement

residency

A stage of specialized medical training in a hospital after graduation from medical school.

respire

to breathe

respiritic

presumably having to do with breathing

restenosis

stenosis is an abnormal narrowing of blood vessels; restenosis is a recurrence of stenosis; recurrence of stenosis, i.e., narrowing of blood vessels

restenotic

refers to restenosis, or the re-narrowing of blood vessels after initial stenosis

retardate

more often used as a noun, offensively referring to a retarded person

retentive

here short for "anal-retentive"

reticence

reluctance; reluctance

reticent

tending to keep one's thoughts to oneself

reticulate

netted; adj., resembling a net or network (Merriam-Webster)

retinue

A group of advisers accompanying an important person; an entourage.; a body of attendants to a powerful person; a group of attendants, advisers, etc.

retrograde

moving backward

retrogradism

This neologism would seem to have the sense of the study or condition of moving backward.

retromandibular

behind the lower jaw

retsin

'Retsyn' is the supposed active ingredient in Certs breath mints

reveille

the trumpet call played in the morning to awaken sleeping soldiers

Revelation of John

the last book of the New Testament

revenant

a person who returns, may refer to an undead (see below p263); one who returns after death or a long absence

Revere

another Massachusetts town, about five miles northeast of Boston, on the Bay; named for Paul Revere

Revere Holding

a jail, obviously -- probably the jail for Revere, Mass., just north of Boston

Reynolds Wrap

a brand name of aluminum foil

rhapsodize

speak in an extravagantly elegant manner

rheostat

This is "an adjustable resistor so constructed that its resistance may be changed without opening the circuit in which it is connected, thereby controlling the current in the circuit" ( Random House Unabridged Dictionary ).; another name for a "variable resistor," which is something that alters the value of a circuit without interrupting it--in this case, this is in reference to a light switch with a dial, which allows for dimming the lights

rheostats

continuously variable electronic resistors

rheumy

watery and unhealthy; full of thin mucous

rhinophyma

a red nose caused by amassing of granulomas there

Rhinoplasty

nose job

rhinorrhagia

bleeding from the nose

rhinoviri

Wallace's plural for rhinovirus, one of dozens of variations of the virus that causes the common cold, also rhinoviruses

rhynophemic

a misspelled reference to rhinophyma, the reddening of the nose common to alcoholics

Ribot

Théodule-Armand Ribot (1839-1916) was a French pre-Freudian psychologist.

riches nouveaux

French: new riches; here an inversion of nouveaux riches, i.e., "newly rich"

RICO

An acronym for the Racketeer Influenced and Corrupt Organizations Act, a statute used primarily to charge organized crime figures in criminal conspiracies.

rictal

showing the expanse of an open mouth

rictus

A gaping grimace.

rife

abounding

riffling

turning pages quickly

right dihedral triangle

a right triangle is one whose largest angle is 90º. Dihedral means "having two sides."

RIJID-brand male hairspray

appears to be a fictional brand of hairspray

rimed

covered with frost

Rindge and Latin School

Cambridge Rindge and Latin School - the only public high school in Cambridge MA.

Rindge-Latin Remedial

A dig at Cambridge Rindge & Latin, Cambridge, MA's public high school

Rise Over Run

The slope ( m ) of a line, expressed as its "rise" (variance along the y axis) divided by its run (variance along the x axis); equivalent in calculus to the first derivative.

Rita Hayworth

The era of Rita Hayworth would be the '30s and '40s.

Riverside Hamlet

The Riverside Shakespeare is one of the better-known editions of Shakespeare's work. Note that Hal, who is based on the character Hamlet, is reading Hamlet .

rivet

a type of pin or bolt; DFW is likely playing off the phrase "dead as a doornail" here

robber-baron

Wikipedia defines robber-barons as "businessmen and bankers who dominated their respective industries and amassed huge personal fortunes, typically as a direct result of pursuing various allegedly anti-competitive or unfair business practices."

Robert McCloskey

Robert McCloskey (1914-2003) was an American author and illustrator of children's books.

rock and bob Hasidically

A Hasid or Chasid is an Orthodox Jew who wears sidelogs, dark clothes, etc. The bobbing is a nod to what Hasidim (and some Jews of other traditions) do when praying or studying religious texts.

Rockette

Named for the Rockefeller family and nearby Rockefeller Center, the Rockettes are the Radio City Music Hall-based dancers famous for high kicks.

rococo

ornate or florid in speech

rodential

like a rodent

rodneys

obviously some kind of impulse buy: cigarettes

Roentgens

The roentgen (R) is a unit of measurement for ionizing radiation and uses the units charge divided by unit weight (C/kg). The preferred scientific unit is the gray (Gy), a unit of absorbed dose (of radiation).

Rog and Wilc,O.

"Roger Wilco, Orin" - Roger Wilco is a radio communication meaning Roger - "I received your message./" and Wilco - "I will comply."

roil

To move about in whirling manner.

roiling

in a state of turbulence or agitation

roll

rob

Rolling Thunder's big-bellied Berthas

Rolling Thunder was the bombing campaign on North Vietnam carried out by South Vietnam and the U.S. military between 1965 and 1968. A Bertha is probably just a really big gun, like the famous Big Bertha used by Germany during WWI. More likely Bertha is referring here to large bombs dropped during the Rolling Thunder campaign, though B52s capable of dropping really large bombs were used much more extensively later - in the escalation into Cambodia for example

ROM

Read-Only Memory

ROM-drives

ROM is an acronym for "Read Only Memory", a class of computer data storage. In the real world, best known in the name of the non-music version of Compact Discs (CD-ROM). CD-ROMs were becoming a popular way to distribute software (and pre-Internet computerized encyclopedias and atlases) when Infinite Jest was written, and even then it was predicted that DVD-ROMs or some other video/data disk would eventually supplant them. In more technical contexts, ROM refers to a specific variety of computer chips, but since Hal is talking about "drives", it seems likely that he means something more like a CD.

rondelling

To rondel (more properly, roundel) is to dance in a circle

ROPAS

Portuguese: CLOTHES

rosin

another spelling of "resin," this resin being used to provide a better grip in weightlifting

rostral lamina

in biology, a beaklike or snoutlike (rostral) layer of tissue (lamina)

rostrum

a pulpit or platform for speaking

Rotarians

members of Rotary International

rotary

a traffic circle or, in the U.K., a roundabout

rotator cuff

the group of muscles and tendons that stabilize the shoulder

ROTC

Reserve Officer Training Corps, which recruits future officers in the U.S. Armed Forces from universities

rote

repetition

Rototiller

a brand name of rotary tiller

Rototrembling

A Wallace neologism (and portmanteaux) to describe the effects (shaking hands) of prolonged operation of a Rototiller

rough-trade

homosexual prostitution - trading sexual activity for money or drugs, frequently associated with violence FreeDictionary

round-robins

This is a type of tournament in which each player plays every other player once, the winner being the person/team/etc. with the most wins. Compare this to a single-elimination tournament like the NCAA Men's Basketball Tournament.

Route 1

U.S. 1 runs from Fort Kent, Maine, at the Canadian border, down to Key West, Florida, largely hugging the Atlantic coast

Route 27

a Massachusetts highway running from Route 106 in Kingston to Route 4 in Chelsmfold

Route 45

U.S. Route 45 runs from US-98 in Mobile, Ala., to I-43/I-94 in Milwaukee. It passes through Kentucky.

Roxbury

The city asserts that this neighborhood "serves as the heart of Black culture in Boston."

Roxbury and Mattapan

In fact, the Orange line continues through Roxbury to terminate at Forest Hills (on the south end of the line); the Red line goes to Mattapan (via transfer at Ashmont). Some branches of the Green line have stops in Brighton, the stand-in for Enfield in the novel.

Royal Victoria

The Royal Victoria College was a women's college created as part of McGill University in Montreal, Quebec.

Royal Victoria College of McGill University

now an all-women's residence at McGill University in Montreal.

rpm

revolutions per minute

Rt. 85

Arizona State Route 85 connects Interstate 10 to the Mexican border near Lukesville, Ariz.

Rte. 3

highway running southeast from Boston along the South Shore toward Cape Cod

Rte. 9

a Massachusetts highway running from US-20 in Pittsfield (western Massachusetts) to Route 28 in Boston

rub

obstacle or impediment

Rub' al Khali

Arabic for Empty Quarter, another name for the Arabian Desert.

Rube-Goldbergesque

needlessly convoluted, like one of the machines for which Jewish-American cartoonist Reuben Garret Lucius "Rube" Goldberg (1883-1970) was famous

Rubensian

The word more often used is "Rubenesque," but this refers to the women in paintings by Peter Paul Rubens (1577-1640), the Flemish artist. His women were usually voluptuous, not to say plump.

Rubensophile

See above, Rubensian.

Rubikular

referring to Rubik's cube

ruddled

reddened

Rue Sherbrooke

a road in Montreal

rugby-scrum

a way of restarting a game of rugby after a point has been scored

Rumford, ME

Rumford is in Maine, less than 50 miles due east of Berlin, N.H.

Ruminative

In the manner of thinking deeply about something.

Rush L.

Rush Limbaugh, the conservative host of a popular political radio talk-show

russet

yellowish- or reddish-brown

Rutherford Keck and Crosby Baum

These both seem to be invented people.... Continuing with the optics theme, Keck is a major observatory on the big island of Hawaii. Rutherford could refer to a British nuclear physicist who pioneered an erroneous model of the atom and discovered the concept of radioactive half-life.

rutilant

gleaming red

rutting

heat, i.e., sexual excitement

rye

whiskey made from rye grain

Ryle's Jazz Club

a reference to Ryles Jazz Club (no apostrophe) in Inman Square, Cambridge, at 212 Hampshire Street.

Rémy-Martin, a brand of cognac

s-boarded

S. Johnson

S.A.C.

Strategic Air Command.; Strategic Air Command

S.O.P.

Social Security Insurance

S.T.

Special Teams

saccharin

A play on words. "Saccharin" is the artificial sweetener in Sweet & Low (coffee is being discussed); "saccharine" means "overly sweet."

saccharine

sickeningly sweet

SACPOP

Strike Against Civilian Population

sacristy

an anteroom or outbuilding of a church, used to store vestments, serving implements for communion, etc.

sacrosanct

inviolable

saddle-noses

noses having a collapsed nasal bridge

sado-periodontal

Periodontology is the dental speciality concerned with the supporting structures of the teeth - gums, alveolar bone, periodontal ligament, etc. Sado-periodontal, then refers to sadistic treatment involving the gums, most likely.

Safeway

a chain of supermarkets

Sagan

Carl Edward Sagan (1934-1996) was an American astronomer and host of a television show called Cosmos .

saguaro

a type of cactus

saguaro cactus

a large, tree-sized species of cactus native to the Sonoran Desert

Sakhalin

a Russian island in the Pacific Ocean

salaam

Arabic for "peace," here meaning a deep bow

SALEM MA

a city 15 miles up the coast from Boston

Salem State U.

There is a Salem State College, but not a university.

Salic law

The Salic Law was a legal code of medieval Central Europe. The phrase is sometimes used simply to refer to its best-known tenet: agnatic succession, or the inheritance of the throne only by male heirs.

salience

pronounced feature

sallet

a type of helmet, the forerunner of the modern combat helmets; a light helmet, usually with a visor

sally

a clever remark

Sally Jessy Raphael M.S.W.

Sally Jessy Raphael (born Sally Lowenthal, 1938) is an American talk-show host. She does not hold an M.S.W., i.e., a Master's of Social Work

saltire

the Cross of St. Andrew

saltpeter

potassium nitrate or nitre, an ingredient in gunpowder, it was (is) commonly believed to be used in food fed to prisoners and even military enlistees (or other predominantly male populations, such as boys' schools and Boy Scout troops) to curb libido; there is no evidence that it causes erectile dysfunction, but large amounts can have dangerous (poisonous) side effects

Saluki

a breed of dog

Samizdat

From the Russian verb "to publish on one's own" or "to self-publish." Originally used to denote underground publications in the Soviet Union, now used more generally for dissident activity [1]

sampler

a piece of cloth embroidered with stitches, sometimes incorporating platitudes

Samuel Johnson

Samuel Johnson, LL.D. (1709-1784), was a British poet, essayist, novelist, literary critic, and lexicographer.

Sancta Something

perhaps a reference to the Sancta Sanctorum, a famous Italian side chapel

Sanger-Brown's ataxia

another name for Marie's ataxia

sangfroid

From French for "cold blood," this word means "coolness," as in composure under pressure; coolness of the blood (from French); cool composure in trying or dangerous circumstances

Sanguine

optimistic or positive, especially in an apparently bad or difficult situation.

Sans-Christe

French: Without Christ

sap

a bludgeon or club

Sapphic

i.e., lesbian, the reference being to Sappho, the ancient Greek poet from Lesbos

Saprogenic

of or pertaining to putrefaction or rotting

saprogenic

causing or caused by putrefaction or decay

sarcoma'd of Kaposi

Karposi's sarcoma is a usually benign skin cancer common in elderly Mediterranean men that has become the most easily identifiable visible symptom of AIDS.

sarcophagally

in a way suggesting a coffin

sarcophagus

coffin

sardonic

mockingly derisive; not quite the same as sarcastic, which more often involves irony: a sarcastic remark may say one thing but mean the opposite, whereas a sardonic comment may simply be scornful without indirection

sartorially

with regard to dress

Saudi

Of Saudi Arabia.

Saugus

a suburb about 10 miles north of Boston

Saugus MA

a suburb of Boston about ten miles north of the city

saurian

lizard-like (especially, here, with respect to the skin)

saurian- and equine-looking

looking like a lizard or horse, respectively

sausage-analog

something similar in appearance to a breakfast sausage link, but perhaps made of textured vegetable protein rather than pork or other meat

Sauvignon

one of two types of wine made from two related sorts of grapes

savant

a savant is a person of learning, particularly specialized knowledge of a particular field. This definition: "Mentally handicapped but brilliant in one specific way." refers to an "idiot savant"

Saxonic

deriving from Old English

scab

a derogatory word for a worker who replaces a union worker on strike

scabrous

having a rough surface because of minute points or projections

scat-piles

piles of feces

scenario

"Scenarios" is the correct plural.

Schacht heard that joke down at the Cranial place

"Schacht interns twice a week for a root-specialist over at the National Cranio-Facial Pain Foundation", Cf. Page 267

schelpp

to move laboriously or clumsily

schemata

diagrams or plans

schizogenic

produced or formed by fission

schizoid

here meaning "erratic"

schlepping

carrying something awkwardly or slowly

schmaltz

rendered chicken fat, used in cooking by Jews who keep kosher (among others), who cannot use lard or other rendered pork fat; in this context, it means sentimental or corny music

Schmeisser GBF

Schmeisser doesn't appear to be a gun manufacturer anymore, but it was in Germany until the fall of the Third Reich. GBF may stand for "German Battle Force."

schnauzer

a breed of dog notable for its beard-like facial hair

Schwulst

The only Schwulst I can find is Lance Schwulst, who is probably not the person referred to.

Scleredema adultorum

a disease characterized by non-pitting induration of the skin

Scooter Puppies

This is likely a term that DFW coined, although Spin magazine used it in a blurb in 1996. I suspect that they were inspired by DFW.  ?? Spin does provide one of the reviews in the front of the 2006 edition.

scooters

apparently a slang term for "dollars"

scopophile

someone who derives pleasure (usually sexual) from looking at something

scopophiliac

An individual affected with the desire to look at sexually stimulating scenes especially as a substitute for actual sexual participation. From the translation of the Freudian notion of Schaulust, "pleasure in looking," in the sense of both seeing and being seen, as well as "curiosity." Freud distinguished between two frequently encountered forms of this partial drive: one active, "voyeurism," and the other passive, "exhibitionism," neither of which he would necessarily rank among perversions. [cf. scopophobic (p.226) & scopophilia (p.832)]

Scopophiliacal

Scopophilia is deriving pleasure from looking. As an expression of sexuality, it refers to sexual pleasure derived from looking at erotic objects: erotic photographs, pornography, naked bodies, etc.

Scopophobic

Of scopophobia; the fear of being seen or stared at.

scopophobic

scopophobia is the morbid fear of being seen or stared at by others

Scorcese

Martin Scorsese (b. 1942), American film director.

Scottsdale

a suburb about 19 miles east-northeast of Phoenix

scourged

afflicted with great suffering. also, beaten with a whip

scratch golfer

one with a handicap of zero

screaming meemies

used to describe anxiety or aprehension (i.e., the "heebie-jeebies" or the "willies"); originally a nickname for a type of German rocket used in WWII, which emitted a high-pitched noise as it flew. ( Wikipedia )

screwdrivers

vodka and orange juice

screwed

i.e., left the room

scrimmage

the scrimmage line, i.e., where the offense currently has the ball

scrip

paper money

scrofulodermic

suffering from cutaneous tuberculosis

Scrofulous

Morally degenerate; corrupt.

scrotum-tightening

An epithet first used by James Joyce in Chapter 1 of his 1922 novel Ulysses . Buck Mulligan is gazing at the Dublin Bay: "--God, he said quietly. Isn't the sea what Algy calls it: a grey sweet mother? The snotgreen sea. The scrotumtightening sea. Epi oinopa ponton. Ah, Dedalus, the Greeks. I must teach you. You must read them in the original. Thalatta! Thalatta! She is our great sweet mother. Come and look." ( Epi oinopa ponton is Homer's famous descriptor for the Aegean Sea from The Odyssey : the wine-dark sea.)

scruff

nape of the neck

scuttlebutt

gossip, rumor

scuttly

scampering

seagrass

seaweed that grows in shallow beds

Seal

the Great Seal of the U.S.

Secyotty!

"Security!" screamed by a drunk

sedentary

involving much sitting

Sedulous

(of a person or action) showing dedication and diligence. "he watched himself with the most sedulous care"

sedulous

diligent or attentive

segue

a smooth transition from one thing to another

Seldane

a brand-name of non-drowsy antihistamine

self-mimetic

imitating one's self

self-regulations

an allusion to a similar deliberately ludicrous list in Chapter 3 of the book Alcoholics Anonymous, read aloud at the start of many AA meetings

selvage

the finished edge of a piece of fabric, so done to prevent fraying; the edge of woven fabric finished so as to prevent raveling, often in a narrow tape effect, different from the body of the fabric.; the edge of a fabric

semicolonized

converted from a comma to a semicolon; otherwise, it's a comma splice

seminal

(of a work, event, moment, or figure) strongly influencing later developments.

semion

A semion is technically part of an anyon, the latter of which is defined in the OED as "a particle having characteristics intermediate between those of fermions and bosons in two-dimensional space." However, it seems Wallace uses the word as a form closer to "semiotics." A later search reveals that semion is Greek for "sign."

semitic ideograms

Semitic languages actually tend to be written uses alphabets, where a symbol denotes a phoneme, rather than in ideograms, like Chinese and Korean are. The oldest alphabet is the Phoenician, which was Semitic.0

Senegal

another nation in west Africa

sephenoid

a misspelling for sphenoid, "a winged bone at the base of the cranium." Merriam-Webster Online. 25 May 2009

sepia

dark brown, as in the pigment used to make very early photographs

septuagenarian

in one's seventies

septuagenaric

in one's seventies

septum

more specifically, the nasal septum; the cartilage separating the nostrils

seraglio

the living quarters of a Turkish harem

seraphic

like an angel

Serenity Prayer

"God grant me the serenity to accept the things I cannot change, the courage to change the things I can, and the wisdom to know the difference."

an officer appointed to keep order; a figurative for addiction, as introduced around page 463

serial

following a fixed series of actions

Sermonette

a short sermon

serodermatotic

suffering from serodermatosis, a skin disease with serous effusion into the skin

serpentine

snake-like

serrated

having a jagged edge

serration

notches in the edges

Seventh Day Adventist

a Protestant denomination marked (in its name) by the fact that they observe their sabbath on Saturday, i.e., the "seventh day"

seventh sense

implying that Gately also possesses the sixth sense (i.e., extrasensory perception or at least uncommonly keen intuition), and suggests an ability to recognize that someone else is under the influence (although some of the first five could probably tell him that)

Seventh-Day Adventists

a Protestant sect of Christianity marked by its observance of the weekly sabbath on Saturdays

severe and somewhat lesbianic haircut

a "butch" cut (see right)

señorio

i.e., scenario

shako

tall, cylindrical military cap, usually with a visor and sometimes tapered at the top

shale

the most common sedimentary rock

shamanistic fiat

A shaman is a priest or religious official, usually of an indigenous religion. A fiat is an order, based on the Latin for the imperative form of the verb "to be."

Shane

a reference to a popular western film

shank

part of the leg between the knee and ankle

shaving upward

the wrong way

Shawshine River

also known as the Shawsheen

She

i.e., Joelle

Shedd Spread

a brand of margarine

shelf

a projecting ridge on a mountain

shell-game

a con game, similar to three-card Monte, in which the sucker attempts to predict under which of three inverted shells (or other containers) a single smaller object resides after the operator has quickly and repeatedly shuffled them

Sherman statutes

a reference to the anti-trust act introduced by Sen. John Sherman of Ohio (1823-1900)

Shetland

a Shetland pony, giving some idea how big the dog is

Shi'ite Moslems

Muslims who believe that Ali was the rightful successor to the Prophet Muhammad

shiatsu

a type of Asian massage

shibboleths

A shibboleth is any language usage indicative of one's social or regional origin, or more broadly, any practice that identifies members of a group. (See Judges 12:4-6 and the Wikipedia entry .)

shifted antigens

An antigenic shift generally refers to the medical term that explains how two strains of the influenza virus join together to form a new subtype and, in turn, become more virulent. The new subtype has a mixture of the antigens from the originals. An antigen is the substance that stimulates the immune system. [3]

shillelagh

an Irish hand weapon

shiners

black eyes

Shining Path

Maoist guerrilla group in Peru ( Wikipedia )

shinola

a now-defunct brand of mid-20th century shoe polish, preserved in the expression, "You don't know shit from Shinola."

Shiny Prize, Kentucky

not a real town

shit-can

get rid of

shiv

an improvised prison weapon used for stabbing

shiva

the Jewish ritual of mourning for seven days, tearing one's clothes, sitting on the floor, covering mirrors, etc.

Shoats

young pigs

shock

insufficient blood flow to the body's organs and tissues, often following an injury but sometimes following an emotional shock

Short Beach CT

a suburb of New Haven, Conn., about seven miles to the southeast

Shrangi-la

Lenz means Shangri-La, the utopia of the novel Lost Horizon by James Hilton (1900-1954), a British author.

Shriners

members of the Ancient Arabic Order of the Nobles of the Mystic Shrine

SHUCO-MIST M.P.S.

Shuco-Mist Medical Pressure Systems (mentioned on page 198) is perhaps the fictional manufacturer a brand of nebulizer (actually spelled "Schuco Mist") for use by asthma patients.

shunpike

a side road to avoid taking a turnpike, in this case, the Mass Turnpike (I-90).

shunt

To shove.

Shylock

He means "Sherlock." Shylock is the Jewish "villain" in Shakespeare's The Merchant of Venice.

hissing sound

sidecar

a passenger car for a motorcycle, usually to the right side of the cycle driver

sidled

walked in a timid or furtive manner

sienna

yellowish- to reddish-brown

sienna-glazed

glazed with an earth-based pigment

Sierpinski gasket

Wacław Franciszek Sierpiński (1882-1969) was a Polish mathematician and one of the innovators of set theory. The Sierpinski gasket is a fractal, also called the Sierpinski triangle. See picture at right.

Sierra Leone

a country of West Africa

sigmoid

the sigmoid colon is the part of the large intestine closest to the rectum

Sikorski-sized

helicopter-sized; the Sikorsky R-4 was the first mass-produced helicopter

silk-analog

molecularly similar to silk

silt

Sino-temporal-endorsement

Chinese-style-time-sponsorship; a reference to China's use of animal signs to date the years (Year of the Dog, Pig, Rat, etc.); the obvious inspiration or model for Subsidized Time .

Sinse

Short for sin semilla, Spanish for "without seeds," it's a type of marijuana.

sinsemilla

Sir Herbert Tree

Sir Herbert Beerbohm Tree (1852-1917) was a British actor and manager. You can hear his performances of Hamlet here .

siren

a reference to the Sirens of Greek mythology

Sitney and Schneewind's Dictionary of Environmental Sciences

There is no such book, but the name Schneewind is German for "snow wind." There are two contemporary academics with those surnames, though they are not scientists: P. Adams Sitney (b. 1944) is a scholar of avant-garde film; J.B. Schneewind (b. 1930) is a philosopher and an authority on Kant and the history of ethics

Six Flags Over the Poconos

Six Flags is a chain of amusement parks. There is not currently one in the Pocono Mountains.

the short name for the Philadelphia 76ers

slingshot dragster

Slobodan

Endnote 221 tells us that this student is Latvian, but this is a Slavic name, and Letts are not Slavs. A quarter of the population of Latvia are ethnically Russian, however.

sloe

likely refers to a type of North American plum tree, which can produce dark purple, yellow, or red fruit, depending on the sub-type of tree

snafus

plural of "snafu," a military acronym for "situation normal: all fucked up"

snaggle-toothed

having a broken or projecting tooth

snifter

a piece of glass stemware with a wide bottom that narrows at the top, for drinking brandy; the "one-handed" variety can be easily palmed with two fingers astride the stem

snorkels

tubes for breathing

Snuff

ground tobacco, which is inhaled rather than smoked or chewed

snuff-white

Snuff is grayish to yellowish brown in color; snuff-white must be that color, but lighter.

snuffle

to sniff as in trying to detect something

sociosis

a neurosis that has to do with one's ability to deal with society

Socratic method

a technique of teaching by asking students questions, attributed to Socrates' pedagogy in ancient Greece

sodding

a pejorative intensifier, chiefly British in usage

sodium light

There are two kinds of sodium lights: Low Pressure (LPS) and High Pressure (HPS). These lamps are mostly used for street lighting as well as industrial uses. The lamp works by creating an electric arc through vaporized sodium metal.

soft rock's grim dental association

which is to say, it's the kind of music you'd hear in a dentist's office

sojourn

not a synonym for "journey," as Lenz is using it, but rather a term meaning a stay in a place for a prolonged period

Sol Hoopi Players

Solomon Ho'opi'i Ka'ai'ai (1902-1953) was another famous Hawaiian musician.

solander

a case for maps or plates made to look like a book

solar plexus

a complex of nerves in the abdomen. Taking blows to the solar plexus refers to the sensation of "having the wind knocked out of you", as the solar plexus is involved in the autonomic activity of respiration.

Solecism

nonstandard or incorrect grammatical usage

solecism

nonstandard or ungrammatical usage

solenoid

a current-carrying coil of wire

solicitous

concerned

soliloquized

spoken to oneself

Solipsism

a kind of narcissism based on the idea that one's own mind is all one can ever truly know to exist

solvent

i.e., financially solvent

somatic

of or relating to the body, esp. as distinct from the mind.

sombrero w/ balls

a sombrero with little balls hanging from it's edge

some Catholic statue

The statue described strongly appears to be Bernini's The Ecstasy of St Theresa . This statue is also referred to by name at endnote 24, page 988 in the synopsis of James Incandenza's film Pre-Nuptial Agreement of Heaven and Hell.

sotto

Italian for "below." Particularly when used in the phrase, "sotto voce," it means speaking in a low voice, under one's breath.; i.e., sotto voce meaning in a very quiet voice

sousaphone

a tuba developed by John Philip Sousa (1854-1932), American composer, for easier carrying with a marching band

South Atlantic

South Atlantic Ocean. The Atlantic Ocean is bounded by the east coasts of the Americas and the west coasts of Eurasia and Africa. The area of the Ocean below the equator is referred to as the South Atlantic Ocean.

South-Central L.A.

An area of Los Angeles known for extreme crime and violence.

SOUTHAF

This is the Union of South Africa, which was formed in 1910 as a British colony and tried to annex Lesotho to it. Because of the imposition of apartheid laws in S. Africa, the annexation failed.

Southern Comfort

an orange-flavored whiskey

Southpaw

Special Teams

These are the squads responsible in football for tactics that are neither offensive or defensive, e.g., returning kick-offs, kicking field goals or extra points, and, of course, punting.

watching

an optical instrument used to measure properties of light over a specific portion of the electromagnetic spectrum; an optical instrument used to conduct spectroscopic analysis on matter to determine its constituent elements

Another neologism, presumably meaning having characteristics of both a sphere and cube -- a three-dimension "squircle".

sphincter

Any muscle in ring form, here it means the anus, which has failed Lucien by allowing him to soil himself

spic

Lenz's derogatory term for Hispanic or Latino

spider angiomas

a type of benign swelling of the blood vessels just beneath the skin's surface, often containing a central red spot and reddish extensions which radiate outwards like a spider's web

Spielberg's old computer-enhanced celluloid dinosaur things

Steven Spielberg directed "Jurassic Park" (1993) and its sequel "The Lost World" (1997); it's unclear, of course, whether Wallace could have anticipated "Jurassic Park III" (2001), for which Spielberg was executive producer. (He is taking the same role on "Jurassic Park IV," announced for 2014.)

spinal camel-straw

the proverbial straw that broke the camel's back(bone)

steeple

spiritually necrotic

Necrosis usually refers to the localized death of cells within healthy tissue. To be spiritually necrotic is akin to having a dead spirit in an otherwise healthy body.

Spiro Agnew

Spiro Theodore Agnew (1918-1996) was vice president of the U.S. under Richard Nixon until forced to resign after pleading no contest to charges of charges of tax evasion and money laundering.

St-Rémi-d'Amherst

a town in Québec about 80 miles northwest of Montreal

St. Columbkill

a place name here, named for an actual Irish saint. There is a real Roman Catholic parish in Brighton called St. Columbkille.; this is actually spelled "St. Columbkille," one of the many names of St. Columba, who was also called "Colum Cille," meaning "dove of the church," and was one of the "Twelve Apostles of Ireland" who converted the native Irish - St. Columbkille Parish is a real Parish in Brighton, MA, as end note 348 mentions, the website of which is here .

St. Elizabeth's Hospital

St. Elizabeth's Medical Center is a real hospital in Brighton. Its Web site is here .

St. Jean-Baptiste Day

another name for la fête nationale du Québec

St. John's Seminary

an actual institution in Brighton

St. Pamphile

This is a town close to Québec City; Pamphile is St. Pamphilus .

St. Vitus's dance

a nickname for the disease chorea

staccato

in music, notes that are sounded in a detached and distinct manner; in music, notes sounded in a detached manner

stadia

plural of "stadium"

StairMaster

a brand name of exercise machines

stalactite

the kind of V-shaped rock formation in caves that grows from the ceiling down; cf. stalagmite, which grows from the floor of the cave upward

Stan Brakhage and Hollis Frampton

Stan Brakhage (1933-2003) and Hollis Frampton (1936-1984) were American avant-garde filmmakers.

Stan Smith

Born in 1946, Smith is a retired professional tennis player, having won Wimbledon and the U.S. Open once each.

Stanford-Binet

a type of IQ test

star-fated

as opposed to star-crossed, i.e., predestined for disaster, as Romeo and Juliet

starboard list

Employing the nautical term for "right" (starboard), the woman referred to tends to move right as she tries to move forward.

i.e., stark naked

stasis

stelliform
