stenographer-cum-jeune-fille-de-Vendredi

secretary who takes diction AND devoted assistant. Jeune-fille-de-Vendredi is French for "young girl Friday." "Man Friday" (or "girl Friday") is a term that means a very competent and loyal servant or assistant, and originates from the Friday of Robinson Crusoe .

stepped on

cut, as in weakened the potency of a drug by adding another substance

sterabolic anoids

stereotaxy

also known as "stereotaxis," this is three-dimensional brain imaging

stern

Sterno

a brand of denatured and jellied alcohol used for cooking, as well as drinking by many street alcoholics

sterno

a fuel made from denatured and jellied alcohol burned directly from the can

Stetson w/ feather

Stetson hats or Stetsons refers to the brand of hat manufactered by the John B. Stetson Company of St. Joseph, Missouri. The word 'Stetson' is sometimes used as a genericized term for a cowboy hat. Although the Stetson company makes other styles of brimmed hat, the Stetson name has become synonymous with a style it pioneered, featuring a high crown and wide brim, popularly known as a Cowboy hat. Wikipedia

stevedore

a person who loads and unloads cargo from boats

A styptic is a chemical that stops bleeding.

commonplace

Stockhausen

German for "stick houses"; not really: "-hausen" functions like "-burg" or "-stadt" – in town names, meaning "town" – as in "Oberhausen" or "Bad Ricklinghausen"; could be a nod to Karlheinz Stockhausen (1928-2007) a German composer, widely acknowledged by critics as one of the most important but also controversial composers of the twentieth and early twenty-first centuries. Another critic calls him "one of the great visionaries of 20th-century music" (Hewett 2007). He is known for his ground-breaking work in electronic music, aleatory (controlled chance) in serial composition, and musical spatialization. Wikipedia

Stolichnaya

a Russian brand of vodka

stolid

unemotional or impassive

Store 24

A New England chain of convenience stores that often include both self-service gasoline and a deli, the website of which is here .

Storrow 500

a local nickname for Storrow Drive in Boston

strabismic

having improperly aligned eyes; squinty or improperly aligned eyes

strabysmic

cross-eyed

straw boater

a type of hat (a "boater") made of straw

straw-and-camel

i.e., the straw that broke the camel's back

street-canny

streetwise

stretto

section at the end of a fugue in which successive introductions of the theme follow at shorter intervals than before, increasing the sense of excitement.

striated

marked with stripes or streaks; striped

strip-mining

According to Wikipedia, "Strip mining is the practice of mining a seam of mineral by first removing a long strip of overlying soil and rock." The implication here seems to be simply that Ingersoll is picking rather deeply.

striped lie a flea

maybe meaning horizontally striped (?) like the overlapping scales on the body of a flea

stucco

Read about it here .

stupor

state of near-unconsciousness

sty

alternate spelling of stye

styptic

contracting tissue

sub rosa

Latin: below the rose, meaning hidden or secretly

sub-rosa

From the Latin "under the rose," this word means secretly held.; The Latin phrase sub rosa means "under the rose" and is used in English to denote secrecy or confidentiality; secret

sub-table

under the table, i.e., off the books so that taxes don't have to be paid

subaltern

a subordinate

subdural

below the dura mater in the skull

Subhadronic

making up the parts of the parts of an atom; very, very small; hadrons are particles made up of quarks, mainly baryons -- protons and neutrons, made of three quarks -- and mesons -- made of two quarks, so subhadronic particles may be quarks

subjoin

to append to the end of something

subjunctive

contingent on something else happening

Submoronic-to-Moronic

At one time, the term "moron" was used to describe a person who tested with an IQ of 50-69; "submoronic" by this reckoning would either be an "imbecile" (with an IQ of 20-49) or an "idiot" (with an IQ below 20). These terms came to be considered offensive and fell from use in the psychological community.

subordinate clause

A subordinate clause is a subject and a verb (a clause) that cannot stand alone as a complete sentence because it does not express a complete thought.

suborn

to bribe or coerce into committing a crime; to bribe or induce someone to commit a crime or misdeed

subsonic

of a speed less than that of sound; i.e., noiseless

subsumption

the act of placing something under a more comprehensive category

subterranean

literally underground

sucrose

table sugar

sucrotically

referring to sucrose, i.e. sugar

Sudetenlandization

Wikipedia - Sudetenland

sudoriferous

sweaty

sues for terms

i.e., sues for peace

suet

fatty tissue surrounding the kidneys of cattle and sheep, used in cooking

Suffolk County

the county in Massachusetts where Boston is

sufism

a mystic strain of Islam

sulci

plural of "sulcus," a furrow or groove, particularly between sections of the brain

sump

cesspool

sumptuous

splendid; expensive; magnificent and exuberant

Sunkist

a brand of fruit and fruit drinks

Sunstrand

not a real place. Sundstrand Corporation makes Aerospace and Industrial Products.

SUNY

State University of New York

super statiously

superstitiously

a real range east of Phoenix

on supervised probation

supine

lying on one's back; on one's back

supperst

supposed

A suppliant is a petitioner.

supplication

The act of asking earnestly; begging; making an entreaty.

suppurating

oozing pus; oozing pus

suprasubliminal

supuratively lesioned

having lesions that ooze pus

surcease

surreal

swaddled

swart

swarthy, i.e., dark-skinned; i.e. swarthy - of dark complexion or color; having a dark complexion or color, swarthy; swarthy

swarthy

dark-skinned

sweetbreads

thymus gland or pancreas of young animals (calf or lamb)

Swinburne

Algernon Charles Swinburne (1837-1909) was a British poet whose work had themes of homosexuality and sadomasochism.

swinishest

most swinish, i.e., most pig-like

Swiss metal helmets

Kate is probably thinking "Swedish" as in a Viking's helmet.

Swisshead

She may be using this particular epithet to mean "one who has holes in his head," à la Swiss cheese.

swivet

a state of nervous excitement

swotted

swotting

sybaritically

Sylvia Plate

Sylvia Plath (1932-1963) was an American poet and novelist who suffered from depression and took her own life in 1963.

sympatico

in agreement

synaptic

pertaining to the spaces between brain cells

Synchronicity

the state of happening simultaneously

synclinal

Sloping downward from opposite directions, so as to meet at a single point, like this: \ /.; sloping downward from opposite directions to meet in a common point or line

synecdoche

This complicated figure of speech is explained here .

synergism

the property of things working together

synesthesia

A condition in which one type of stimulation evokes the sensation of another, as when the hearing of a sound produces the visualization of a color. ( thefreedictionary )

synoptic

by way of summary

Synovial

of or pertaining to the fluid that lubricates the joints

Szechuan

t'ai-chi

a drafting tool

T. Leary

Timothy Francis Leary (1920-1996) was an American writer and psychologist best known as an advocate for regular LSD use.

TA

Teaching Assistant

tabescent and chachetic

Tabescent refers to a person with tabes dorsalis, and chachetic (probably misspelled) apparently refers to a person with cachexia .

Tableaux

This is the French pluralization of "tableau,"

tacit

unspoken

taciturn

reserved or reticent in speech; saying little.

tacks

Follows a zigzag course. In sailing, tacking is a change of direction through the direction of the wind.

tact

the sense of what to do to avoid offending or souring relations with someone

Tactical Phalanx

Normally a military term, this would be a phalanx (from the Latin word for "fingers") or row of soldiers deployed for tactical purposes.

taffeta

a crisp, smooth, woven fabric, often made from silk, used in gowns

tailback

in American football, the back who is positioned farthest from the line of scrimmage

tailor's notch

Notch in your tooth you get from repeatedly biting thread to cut it (or from holding a sewing needle between one's teeth)

Taj

i.e., the Taj Mahal; Wikipedia

Taka Limura

Japanese film maker - see article

talismanically

in a way suggesting something having to do with a magic charm or amulet

talking batons and low-pH chemistry

batons presumably in encouragement of Joelle's amateur career as a twirler and low-pH chemistry (the chemistry of acids) because of his work for the Dyne-Riney Proton Donor Reagent Corporation

Tallat-Kelpsa

also the name of a Latvian classical composer

tallboys

16oz cans of beer

tallly

'tall' used adverbially.

Talmudic

Normally referring to the Talmud, here it means making fine distinctions.

Talwin

brand name of pentazocine, a narcotic painkiller; Pentazocine (Talwin). Prescription drug. Treats moderate to severe pain. Is sometimes given before or after a surgery. May also be given with a general anesthesia before an operation. Belongs to a class of drugs called narcotic analgesics.

tam-o'-shanter

a Scottish style hat sometimes with a tassel, feather, or pompon in the center

tamped

packed down by striking repeatedly

tamping

packing down the tobacco

tangent

This concept is explained here .

tangrams

a type of Chinese puzzle

tannin

any of several vegetable compounds tending to have a reddish-brown color, widely used in leather- and winemaking

tantric

referring to a particular branch of Hinduism, but very particularly to the sexual aspect of this branch, which emphasizes long sessions of sexual intercourse

Taoist paraboloid logo

referring to the yin/yang symbol (seen right). In Chinese philosophy, the concept of yin yang is used to describe how seemingly disjunct or opposing forces are interconnected and interdependent in the natural world, giving rise to each other in turn. ( Wikipedia )

Tapio Martti

"Tapio" and "Martti" are both Finnish first names. Tapio is also the Finnish pagan god of forests.

tapir

a very long-nosed animal; see a picture here

taproot

something that provides a central source for growth

Tarkovsky

Andrei Arsenyevich Tarkovsky (1932-1986) was a Soviet-Russian filmmaker, most famous for Voyage in Time, made with Antonioni.

tartan

plaid, particularly when it is the pattern of a Scottish clan

tartines

a type of French open-faced sandwich

Tassigny

This character's name is perhaps taken from Jean Joseph Marie Gabriel de Lattre de Tassigny (1889-1952), a French military hero of WWII.

Taurus PT9

TBS

Turner Broadcasting System, founded by Robert Edward "Ted" Turner III (born 1938)

teak chiffonier

a piece of furniture, one of which you can see here

i.e., torture

Teddibly Soddy

tektitic

referring to fossils formed by meteoric impacts

telekinetic

able to moves things with one's mind

Telekiniption

i.e., telekinesis

telemachry

Maybe not the word Hal was looking for, but Telemachus was a monk who tried to stop the Roman gladiator fights and told the Romans to stop worshiping false idols instead of Christ. He was stoned to death, though his death is sometimes said to have ended the Gladiatorial games. So, "telemachry" could be interpreted to be trust in a higher power.

telemetry

the transmission of something automatically and at a distance -- here, Hal's toenails to the wastebasket

teleologic

regarding a final cause

teleputer

Combination television and computer, generic term for an Interlace player, see also TP

temporal-lobe

the part of the brain involved in hearing, speech, and vision

ten m.

Ten meters is equal to 32.8 feet.; 32.8 feet

ten meters

about 32.8 feet

ten-kilo

about 22 lbs

tendentiously

in a manner showing a definite bias or prejudice

tentacularly

as with tentacles

tenth rough

off the fairway on the tenth hole of a golf course

Tenuate

Tenuate is an appetite suppressant and amphetamine; drug marketed as an appetite suppressant

Tenuate Dospan

Tenuate is a brand name of diethylcathinone, an appetite suppressant and mild amphetamine; Dospan is used for the time-release pills.

tenure-jockeys

i.e., junior faculty at universities who are on tenure track

teratogenic

having an ill effect on the development of a fetus

teratoid

resembling a monster; resembling a monster; monstrous (from Greek teras, terat- "monster.")

terrazzo

a type of mosaic made of broken stone

Terriers

Rhett the Boston Terrier is the mascot of Boston University.

terry

a pile fabric used to make bath towels and robes

terry robe

a robe made with terry cloth, a pile fabric with uncut loops used to make bath robes and towels

terse

using few words

tersely

in a manner using few words

Tertiary

Third-level, after primary and secondary.

tesseract

4 dimensional hypercube

testatory codicil

A testator is someone who has a will, and a codicil is a supplement to a will.

tetanic

Pertaining to tetanus, a kind of lockjaw caused by contamination of a wound, usually.

tetrahydrofruan

Probably a mis-spelling of the solvent tetrahydrofuran (CH 2 ) 4 O

tetryl

an explosive used to make detonators

Teutons

The President seems to be using this as a place name (perhaps a malapropism of the Tetons ), but Teutons is an ancient term for German-speaking people.

Tex Watson

Besides a character in Infinite Jest, Tex Watson was the nickname of Charles Watson, one of the chief murderers in the Charles Manson Family.

thalidomide

a drug developed to treat morning sickness in pregnant women that ended up causing babies to be born missing limbs

thanatoptic

contemplating death; regarding a vision of death

Thank you Sir may I have another

a line from the film "Animal House" (1978)

That old cartridge, Nichols and the big Indian...

She's referring to One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest ; "Nichols" is Jack Nicholson .

the 5 on the French Achievement boards

The highest possible score on the French Advanced Placement Exam (for which one can receive college credit) is 5.

the A.M.'s interruptus

Presumably this means the end of the morning, although the only common English usage of "interruptus" is in the Latin phrase coitus interrruptus, i.e., "pulling out." (See the Consummation of the Levirates .)

The acromegalic and hyperkeratosistic. The enuretic.

Arcomegaly is a disorder of the pituitary gland whereby it produces too much human growth hormone, resulting in giantism. Hyperkeratosistic means that one is suffering from hyperkeratosis . Enuresis is the inability to urinate.

The afternoon's meshes.

recalls an experimental film by Maya Deren and her husband Alexander Hammid, Meshes of the Afternoon (1943)

The B.U. punter

a.k.a. Orin Incandenza

the Beats

members of the Beat generation

The Bible

The quote isn't from the Bible.

The Continent's Best Yogurt

It actually stands for "The Country's Best Yogurt," but given the formation of O.N.A.N., the change seems fitting if not necessary.

The contorted face...

The painting of Whitey Sorkin is the same one that had Hal "popping Nunhagen compulsively until his ears started ringing" when it appeared in the advertisement for Nunhagen Aspirin Co. created by Viney and Veals Advertising. See footnote 162.

the Csikszentmihalyi kid was doing a kind of piaffer

A piaffer is a trot in place where the legs are lifted high. This type of trot is usually done by a horse, but it's part of the 'Csikszentmihalyi kid's' pre-game ritual to stretch his hip flexors.

the Fenway

the Fenway-Kenmore section of Boston

The fish asking about what's water.

A reference to DFW's Kenyon College commencement speech This Is Water

The Frightful Hog

once again, Lenz's Unit (penis)

the Frightful Hog

attributed to Frederick Exley, noted for his first novel, A Fan's Notes (1968)

the Hole

prison slang for solitary confinement

the hook

presumably, the sister's hand; or the screen door is still secured by its hooking mechanism to keep him out

The horse: the gift which was not a gift

a reference to the Trojan horse

the lobsters' eyes' stalks

see OMMATOPHORIC earlier on pg. 884

the minor and soft-core Alexandrian mosaic

i.e. Byzantine erotica (cf. 29, 36)

The Noie Störkraft's? Shining Path's? The Belgian CCC's?

Noie Störkraft is Swedish "New Great Power"; it does not appear to be a new organization, though Störkraft is the name of a skinhead band from Sweden. The Shining Path ( Sendero Luminoso in Spanish) is the Communist Party of Peru, which has waged guerrilla warfare against the Peruvian government since 1980. CCC is a French acronym for Communist Combatant Cells; they were eliminated as a terrorist group in 1986.

The Old Cold Bird

a variation on cold turkey

the one about what do Canadian girls put behind their ears to attract boys

Presumably a reference to this old riddle: Q: What does a blonde put behind her ears to make her more attractive? A: Her ankles. (indeed, that is answered on page 634 by Coyle)

The pond is perfectly round...

Two things wrong here, actually. There is no 'duck pond' in The Public Garden. There is a large lagoon on which the swan boats ply their trade, but it is irregular in shape. Make that three things as the lagoon is not drained in the fall. I suppose he could be referring to the 'frog pond' but that' in the neighboring Boston Common.

the Show

professional tennis

the Snow brothers, Vigdis Simpson

One of the Snow brothers would have to be Michael Snow (born 1929), a Canadian-American filmmaker, principally known for Wavelength . Vigdis Simpson seems created.

the sort of body Gately's only ever seen with a staple in its navel

a centerfold nude in a magazine, such as Playboy

Socrates said that the unexamined life is not worth living in Apology .

The way Lenz pronounces brother involves one r.

the weekend right before Thanksgiving week and the Whataburger Invitational

Hal and Permulis set a date for a 'window of opportunity' to take DMZ. Compare Page 16, where Hal says that the only other emergency room he has ever been in was exactly one year back from November, Year of Glad. So, this may provide a nexus explaining what happened to Hal at the beginning of Infinite Jest.

The wraith is back...except now with him is another, younger, way more physically fit wraith in kind of faggy biking shorts and U.S. tank top who's leaning way over Gately's railing and... fucking licking Gately's forehead with a rough little tongue...

It's Lyle. However, Lyle, being alive and well, must be able to achieve status as a wraith via meditation (this adds significance to the "Lyle Meditates" section on pg. 700).

Theseus

a hero of Greek mythology

thespian

having to do with acting

thespio-historical

regarding the history of acting

Thevet

This is probably a reference to André de Thevet (1502-1590), a French priest and explorer. Though never in Canada, he relied on French-Canadian explorers' work for his own voyages to South America.

they all in here existed basically as Fourier Transforms of postures and little routines

A Fourier transform is a mathematical operation that transforms one function into another. This type of transform is named in honour of Joseph Fourier. [10] To exist basically as Fourier Transforms of postures and routines is to exist as an abstraction where a student is trained in postures and routines is transformed into tennis player capable of executing a variation of those postures and routines. It is also worth noting that the Fourier transform converts a signal from the time domain (that is, that the signal is a function of time) to the frequency domain (no longer a function of time but of frequency, the function being composed of wave functions). The implication being that all the "postures and little routines" are composed of repeated actions (analogous to the waves that make up a Fourier series) and can be expressed in a time independent manner.

thiamine

another name for vitamin B1

thigmotactic

Having to do with thigmotaxis, i.e., the movement or an organism as a response to a mechanical stimulus.

thiopental sodium

another name for sodium pentothal, a powerful general anesthetic

THIRD RAIL

In many subway systems (notably New York's), the third rail is the electrified rail that powers the train(s) and carries an extremely hazardous level of voltage.

third year of Subsidized Time

i.e., the Year of the Trial-Sized Dove Bar

Thomist

ascribing to the philosophy of St. Thomas Aquinas

thoracic

having to do with the chest

thorax

chest

thoroughgoingly

absolutely

Thorp's Trigonometry of Cubes

Edward Oakley Thorp (born 1932) is an American mathematician, but he seems not to have created a "trigonometry of cubes," which would be, frankly, impossible.

three-setter

a tennis game ending in three sets, rather than two. So Pemulis needs to win a set against Freer to make it to the tournament.

what turns the rudder to steer a boat; a nautical term for the device attached to a boat's rudder to assist in steering

tone of voice

timpani

large drums (kettledrums) used in orchestras

tincture of benzoin

A tincture is a mixture of a drug dissolved in alcohol. Benzoin is a balsamic resin used as an antiseptic and expectorant.

tines

prongs of a fork

Tiparillo

a brand name of cigar

Titian

Tiziano Vecellio (1485-1576) was a Venetian painter.

Tito Puente

Ernest Anthony Puente, Jr., an internationally known Puerto Rican jazz musician.

titrated

To titrate is "to ascertain the quantity of a given constituent by adding a liquid reagent of known strength and measuring the volume necessary to convert the constituent to another form" ( Random House Unabridged Dictionary ).

titration

the process of determining the strength of a compound

tittymount

i.e., "tantamount"

TMA

an acronym for trimethoxyamphetamine

to tack body to soul

More correctly, brodie, refers to [1] Steve Brodie, who survived a leap from the Brooklyn Bridge in 1886

maybe just "the maximum" (or "the max"), but also perhaps more Wallace wordplay, as in the gluteus maximus (the largest of the muscles in the buttocks), and so a pain in the ass

Tobin Bridge

the bridge that connects Charleston and Chelsea, Massachusetts, over the Mystic River

Toblerone

A Swiss-made chocolate bar .

toggle

a type of switch

toggle bolt

bolts with expanding wings used to fasten objects onto hollow surfaces, e.g., drywall

toilet-eau

eau de toilette (French: toilet water) is used mainly by women and is less concentrated than perfume, but more concentrated than eau de cologne, which is used more commonly by men

Tolstoy's sentence

The question probably referred to the opening lines of Leo Tolstoy's Anna Karenina: "HAPPY families are all alike; every unhappy family is unhappy in its own way."

Toltec

topography

a detailed description of something, usually a place or region.

topspin

toque

Now known as Rogers Centre, this is the home field of the Toronto Blue Jays.

sluggishness

Toucan Sam is the avian mascot of Froot Loops cereal. The character is a blue cartoon toucan with a striped beak. ( Wikipedia )

French: always

this is the aberration of light across a field

transverse colon

trellis

trepidation

tri-faceted

triangulating

dividing into triangles (More likely, homing in by successive approximation)

trilled r's

as pronounced in a Spanish word such as perro ("dog") The French trilled r can be uvular (on the back of the tongue) or aveolar (front of the tongue, like the Spanish perro example).

tripartite

having three parts; divided into three parts

truncheon

Baton caried by police officers in the United Kingdom from 1829 until the early 1990s. In Northern Ireland, however, all police officers carry firearms (more information here ).

Used here, it means an impulse that causes something to move.

turn blue litmus paper red

Turner

probably a reference to Joseph Mallord William Turner (1775-1851), a British painter

Turner, Bush, Casey

Admiral Stansfield Turner was head of the CIA from 1977 to 1981. George H.W. Bush (later President) was CIA head from 1976 to 1977. William J. Casey was head from 1981 to 1987.

turnipcut

i.e., tourniquet

turpitude

depravity

turrets

refers here to small towers of the kind seen on medieval castles and other fortifications, often built with battlement crenels (notches) for use by defensive archers

TURTLE MTN. INDIAN RESERVATION

a reservation for Chippewa Indians

turtle-headed

implying that Orin's neck is covered entirely but visible, as with a turtleneck sweater

twelve out of fifteen NATO nations

The last time NATO had fifteen members was in 1982, when Spain was admitted.

twenty meters

almost twenty-two yards

twenty-six meters

85.3 feet

twidgeling

one of Hal's nonce words, meaning digital manipulation

twidgelling

not a real word

twins Siamese

The Vaught twin-sister tennis players are actually conjoined at the head.

Twister

a parlor game produced by Hasbro that involves contorting the body; see note supra for page 634

two hundred kilos

over 440 pounds

Two hundred sixteen

216 is the cube of 6; thus the preliminary round would yield Les Trente-Six (36) semifinalists and the second round would produce six finalists attendants longtemps ses tours (French: "waiting a long time for their turns

two meter

a little over 6.5 ft

two meters

about 6.6 feet; an apparent exaggeration; about 6.6 feet

two-k. square

0.77 square miles

two-meter

about 6.56 feet

tympana

Plural for the Latin tympanum, i.e., "drum," here it is a drum-shaped architectural design.

tympanum

a, usually decorative, semicircular or triangular wall face above an entrance; the recess between the top of the door and the arch above it

Tyrolean hats

The Tyrolean hat, named after the region of Tyrol, is associated with the Austrian Alps. Tyrolean hats have a cord wrapped around the base of the crown and a feather or brush on the side as trim. For an example, see right.

tête

French: head

tête-à-tête

From the French for "head to head," this term denotes a private conversation between two people.

U. Vermont and UNH now history

This implies that Vermont and New Hampshire were also annexed to Canada. However, the University of Vermont had not been in the conference since 1974.

U.H.I.D.

Union of the Hideously and Improbably Deformed

U.N. Day

October 24

U.N.L.V.

University of Nevada at Las Vegas

U.R.G.

probably United Republic of Germany

U.S. Interstate 87

It runs from Champlain, NY, on the Canadian border, to the Bronx.

U.S.A. 91

Interstate 91, which runs from New Haven, Conn, to Derby Line, Vt., at the Canadian border

U.S.A. Civic War hero's Boylston St. statue

probably a reference the Robert Gould Shaw statue that Joelle van Dyne passes on p. 223. DFW appears to have moved the Shaw memorial from Beacon Street to Boylston Street.

U.S.B.S.S.

An abbreviation for the name given to the U.S. Office of Unspecified Services by the Québecois Sepératiste Left, the U.S. "Bureau des Services sans Spécificité" (see page 89).

U.S.D.D.

United States Department of Defense

U.S.O.

United States Organizations, an organization dedicated to entertaining troops at war; Undercover Special Operations

U.S.T.A.

United States Tennis Association.

U.W.S.A.

United We Stand America, Perot's political movement

ubiquitousness

the quality of always being present everywhere

UF4

chemical notation for uranium tetrafluoride, used in some nuclear reactors

UHF

Ultra High Frequency

UKRAINE, TWO MORE BALTIC STATES APPLY FOR NATO INCLUSION

Ukraine did not begin application for NATO membership until 2006, while the Baltic States were all admitted in 2004.

Ulcerative colitis

a form of inflammatory bowel disease (Wikipedia)

ultra-mach

Named for Ernst Mach (1838-1916), a Bohemian-Austrian physicist, the mach unit is a unit for the speed of sound. "Ultra-mach" would apply to a plane flying at several times the speed of sound.

Umbrian

From the Italian reggione of Umbria, in central Italy. Hal is Italian on his father's side, as well as Pima Native American. His mother, of course, is French-Canadian.

unalloyed

pure

unbent

not having yielded or submitted

Uncle Charles

Hal's Uncle, Charles Tavis, is head of the Enfield Tennis Academy.

uncolloped

having no fat

undead

the state of several unnatural beings (vampires, mummies, zombies, etc.), which is in a state neither live nor dead

undercapitalized

lacking sufficient funds to complete a business transaction

undulate

to move like waves

undulating

moving with a wave-like motion; moving in a wavelike motion

unfazable

incapable of being disturbed

unfenestrated

having no windows

ungainly

ungracefully or awkwardly

union-suit underwear

one-piece long undergarments

unironic

i.e., totally expected and not at all a surprise

unitard

a bodysuit or one-piece leotard

Unitarian

Though the term refers to Unitarianism, here it suggests a kind of hippyesque, wishy-washyness.

Unitary

having the nature of a unit; whole

univocal

unambiguous

unmoored

opposite of the nautical term moored meaning fastened or secured in place (as in a boat)

Uno

as in numero uno, number one

unperspicous

not clearly expressed or presented

unrough trade

i.e., homosexual relations between men that are both gay

unsafetied

The gun's safety is off.

UPS

United Parcel Service

uremic

Smelling like urine, because of a condition whereby waste products normally excreted in the urine are retained in the blood.; of or involving excess nitrogenous waste products in the urine

ursine

pertaining to bears

Ursuline nuns

the Order of St. Ursula, the members of which teach young girls

USC

the University of Southern California

USMC

United States Marine Corps

utility

In economics or statistics, this is a quantity/quality to be maximized in decision making.

UV-booth

UV standing for ultraviolet (as in light), this is probably a tanning booth.

V or VI

The filmography of Incandenza presented in an earlier (lengthy) endnote would seem to indicate that there were only five versions of the film, although the fifth version was apparently reviewed, which would mean that the "entertainment" so desperately sought is actually a sixth version.

V.D.

alternately this could stand for Venereal Disease; Very dearly

V.F.W.

Veterans of Foreign Wars

V.i.9

The line is "It must be 'se offendendo;' it cannot be else." The reference is to Ophelia, who killed herself. Notably, Act V, scene i of Hamlet is where Yorick is mentioned.

VA

the U.S. Department of Veterans' Affairs; Veterans Affairs (formerly Veterans Administration)

vacillation

inability to stick with a choice

vacuole

used here generically to mean a hole

vacuole and optica

These are parts of a cell, the optica likely being some kind of "seeing" organ.

vacuous

lacking in ideas or intelligence; unintelligent, foolish, empty

vademecumish

vade mecum - Latin for "go with me"; like a reference handbook intended to be carried everywhere.

Vaipassana

a type of Buddhist meditation ( Wikipedia ); usually spelled "Vipassana"

Val d'Or, Québec

city of northern Québec, 325 miles northwest of Montreal

valise

a small piece of luggage

Van Buskirk of Montreal

Bacon & Van Buskirk is a glass company in Wallace's home town of Champaign-Urbana, Illinois.

van der Rohe

Ludwig Mies van der Rohe (1886-1969) was a German-born American architect.

van Dyke

a goatee

vanity

a dressing table

vantage

point of view

vapid

lacking liveliness or spirit

vapidity

lack of engaging or challenging qualities

VAPS

an air traffic control acronym for visual approaches.; vector/angle/pace/spin

varicelliformally eruptive

a type of eczema due to herpes .

varicocele

a varicose condition of the spermatic veins of the scrotum

varicoceles

plural of varicocele (also "varicoscele"), an abnormal enlargement of a vein in the scrotum

varicose

having veins that are visible through the skin

varicotic

having varicose veins

variegated

diverse; streaked or patched with multiple colors

vas deferens

the conduit for semen from the testis to the ejaculatory duct, from which it is propelled through the urethra

vascularly hued

colored like a blood vessel

vault the net

It used to be a tradition in tennis for one player to jump ("vault") over the net to congratulate or console his/her opponent after a match.

vectored

To vector is to direct the position of (an airplane).

vectors

Direct paths to desired locations

Veedersburg IN

this town lies 22 miles west of Crawfordsville on Route 74

Veedersburg, Indiana and Powell, Wyoming

Veedersburg is about 70 miles west-northwest of Indianapolis; Powell is about 90 miles south of Billings, Mont.

veldt

From Afrikaans, this is a word for an open field with grass, bushes, etc.

velour

a piled and nappy material resembling velvet; a knitted (and therefore flexible) fabric with looped threads knitted into the ground; it can have the plush texture of velvet, which is woven rather than knitted and cut during manufacture to create two pieces, each with a fine pile (similar, but on a smaller scale, to a plush carpet); a felt that looks like velvet

venery

the gratification of sexual desire

ventral

on the side

ventricle

one of two of the four chambers of the heart

venulated

The word means "able to see the veins"; this condition of the nose is very common among advanced alcoholics.

Venus Williams

At the time this novel was published, Venus Williams would have been sixteen years old.

verbatim

word for word; i.e., word for word (written or spoken), from the Latin

verdant

green with vegetation

verdigrised

covered with grayish-green rust

Verdun Protestant Hospital

now called Douglas Mental Health Institute

verger

a church official, such as a caretaker

verisimilitude

proximity to reality, "Truth likeness"

veritable

Genuine

Vermeer

Johannes Vermeer (1632-1675) was a Dutch painter.

vermiform

looking like a worm

verminal

tending to breed vermin

verminousness

resembling vermin

veronica

refers to the bullfighting move in which the matador holds the cape out and pivots slowly as the bull charges past or through it

Vertical Hold

refers to a setting on a television that adjusts the picture's vertical stabilization

vertical hold

the control on a television that prevents the picture from rolling bottom to top

vertiginous

As in related to vertigo, the sensation of imbalance or dizziness

verve

enthusiasm or vigor

Very Large Satan

or "Great Satan," if you will

Vespa

a brand of motor scooter

vessels

He means "vassals."

vestibule

lobby or entrance hall

vestiges

a part or organ of an organism that has become reduced or functionless in the course of evolution.

Vichified

i.e., as Vichy France, which was a puppet government to the Nazis

vicissitude

a change or variation in the course of something; or a hardship due to chance

Vienna VA

a suburb of Washington, D.C., about 15 miles due west of the city

vig

the amount charged by a bookie for facilitating bets

vigorish

the bookie's fee for his services (see "vig" later on the page and the note for page 204)

VIII-Amendment

The Eighth Amendment to the U.S. Constitution protects citizens against cruel and unusual punishment.

vin blanc

French: white wine

violas

A viola is a like a violin, only slightly larger and deeper in tone.

viscera

internal organs

viscid

sticky; adhesive

viscous

Sticky, thick and liquid.; very thick

vishnu

Vishnu is the preserver/maintainer god of the Hindu Trimurti.

vitriolic

something highly caustic or severe, as criticism; the phrase prodigy of vitriolic spine must refer to someone with an impressive and courageous capacity (talent?) for scathing criticism

Vittoria

a reference to Santa Maria della Vittoria, where the mentioned work by Bernini hangs

Vittorio's Bernini Room

possibly a meeting room in the NH Vittorio Veneto hotel in Rome; or it may refer to the Cornaro Chapel of Santa Maria della Vittoria [note the different spelling] in Rome, where Bernini's Ecstasy of St. Teresa resides. Given the book's repeated allusions to the Bernini sculpture, probably the latter.

Vivian, Utah

a city about 30 miles southeast of Salt Lake City

vivisected

cut apart while still alive; slaughtered, yes, but not cut apart while still living

vivisecting

performing an operation on a living animal for research purposes

Viz.

Latin abbreviation for videlicet, meaning "that is to say"

viz.

abbreviation for videlicet (Latin), meaning "namely" or "specifically" or "in other words"

VLR

visitor's locker room

VO

a type of whiskey by Seagram's, the VO standing for Seagram's V ery O wn family blend; for cognac, the same abbreviation is for V ery O ld, denoting a minimum aging time of at least four years (see more on cognac labels

Vogelsong

"Vogel" = German for "bird", i.e. something like: bird song ("song" is not German)

Volgograd

Formerly known as Tsaritsyn and then Stalingrad, this is a city of Russia on the Volga River, downriver from Moscow.

volition

the faculty or power of using one's will.

Volkmann

Richard von Volkmann (1830-1889) was a prominent German surgeon who described Volkmann's contracture in 1881. ( Wikipedia )

volubly

to speak readily

vortexing

whirling

votaried

filled with devotion

vox- and digitus-populi

Vox populi means "voice of the people" in Latin. Digitus populi would be "finger of the people."

vulgate

common or colloquial speech.

VW-Bug

nickname for the Volkswagen Beetle automobile model

W-E

west-east

W. Miller

William Miller (1782-1849) was an American religious leader and one of the founders of the Seventh-Day Adventist movement.

W. T. Sherman

William Tecumseh Sherman (1820-1891) was an American army general, responsible for burning Atlanta during the U.S. Civil War.

w.o.m.

word of mouth

w/w/o

With and without.

wadcutter

special bullets with a flat front designed for shooting paper targets

Wagenknecht

sort of a formal German word for "chauffeur." [No, as native speaker, I do not agree. It is a quiet family name, meaning something like "cart-worker", but nobody would call a chauffeur that way!]

Wagnerian

in the style or manner of Richard Wagner, the German operatic composer

Wagnerian bass

grandiose and stentorian (in the lower register) in the manner of German opera composer Richard Wagner (1813-1883)

wakked

I have no idea.

wall- and cross-eyed

To be wall-eyed is to suffer from exotropia, which is a form of ocular paralysis in which one or both eyes turn outward.

Walpole

a suburb of Boston about eighteen miles from the city

wan

pale in color

wangs

slaps or bangs against

War of the Welles

a reference to the film War of the Worlds, itself adapted from the 1938 radio play by George Orson Welles (1915-1985), American actor and filmmaker

warbly

warbling, i.e., trilling or quavering

Ward and June

The mother's and father's names on Leave It to Beaver

Ward Boss

leader of the political machine in a specific city ward

Ward-and-Wally

referring to Theodore Cleaver's father and older brother in the CBS-ABC television series Leave It to Beaver (1957-1963)

wasn’t an M.D. yet but a resident

On the contrary, a resident is an M.D. in the first years after medical school. Residents have an M.D. degree but are undergoing advanced training.

Water Lou

i.e., Waterloo

water-drops

Being dropped into water, presumably because the football team in Seattle is the Seahawks.

Waterloo

a city in Belgium where Napoleon suffered his final defeat — the term has come to mean "final defeat"

Watertown

a suburb of Boston, ten miles to the west

WATS

Wide Area Telecommunications Service: "bulk-rate telephone service that enables a subscriber to make an unlimited number of long-distance telephone calls within a given service area for a fixed monthly charge or to receive calls from given areas with no charge to the caller" ( Random House Unabridged Dictionary )

Watteau

Jean-Antoine Watteau (1684-1721) was a French painter.

wattled

having flesh hanging from one's chin, like a turkey

wattles

wattles are ornamental skin on or near the base of the bill of certain birds, in this case the red wattles on the turkey's beak

wavered

quavering in sound

wax lyrical

to speak poetically

waxing

growing in size, as for the first half of a lunar cycle

We got him...

Obviously, the point of Stice's unfunny joke is that the statistical average of the first two shots would yield a shot that hit the duck.

weal

well-being; welfare

Weaver stance

a popular technique for firing a handgun

Weber Grill

a real brand, you can see examples here

Webster's 7th

Webster's Dictionary, 7th edition.

Wedekind festival

This would presumably be a festival celebrating the plays of German playwright Benjamin Franklin Wedekind (1864-1914), a proto-expressionist.

weedy

scrawny; Hal is probably using it to mean "thin," as in a line of argumentation

Weejuns

G. H. Bass & Co.'s tradename for its line of men's and women's penny loafer shoes (see right)

welching

swindling by not paying a debt or wager

Weld

William Floyd Weld (born 1945) was governor of Massachusetts from 1991 to 1997. Even the prescient Wallace could probably not have predicted Mitt Romney, who held the post from 2003 to 2007.

well-known tragedy

By the time Infinite Jest had been published, Capriati had been arrested for marijuana possession. She returned to pro tennis that same year, perhaps after the book went to press.

Wellesley Hills

A section of the town of Wellesley, Mass., 15 miles west-southwest of Boston.

Wellfleet Circuit Court

Wellfleet is a town on Cape Cod about 10 miles south of Provincetown.

wen

"A benign encysted tumor of the skin, esp. on the scalp, containing sebaceous matter; a sebaceous cyst" ( Random House Unabridged Dictionary ).

wens

harmless cysts, especially on the scalp or face, containing the fatty secretion of a sebaceous gland; harmless cysts on the scalp or face

Weston

A suburb of Boston, about 17 miles west of the city

wet work

sexual acts in exchange for drugs/money/etc. [Not sure of poster's source for this. Seems like a reasonable interpretation, but "wet work" usually refers to killing, with "wet" referring to blood, which is at least equally plausible in this context.]

whale

to hit hard

Wharton

the business school at the Ivy-League University of Pennsylvania, in Philadelphia, generally believed to be the most prestigious undergraduate business school in the world and also highly regarded at post-graduate levels

what he is

i.e., an alcoholic

WhataBurger Southwest Junior Invitational

A fictional junior tennis tournament, sponsored by Whataburger®, a real fast-food chain in the southwest U.S. See p. 14.

When the boulder's slipped all the way back to the bottom

a reference to the myth of Sisyphus

When the headless are blaming

a reference to "If," the poem by Rudyard Kipling: "If you can keep your head when all about you / Are losing theirs and blaming it on you..."

whey

the liquid remaining after milk has been curdled and strained

whingeing

complaining (pronounced to rhyme with "jing")

whippet

a one-inhalation dose of nitrous oxide (laughing gas)

whistling 'Dixie.'

See the discussion of this phrase in section 6 of the Wikipedia entry on the 19th-century American popular song, once considered the unofficial national anthem of the Confederate States of America.

White Flag group

A white flag is a military signal for "surrender." Many AA groups' names quote or allude to phrases or concepts from the AA program; this name alludes to the concept of surrender/abandon/acceptance or "turning over [one's] life and will to the care of God."

White halogen

i.e., the light from a halogen lamp

white- party-noise

which is to say random noise generated by the party outside the bedroom

white-gloved finger

implying that the finger is on the hand in a white glove, used to draw one's hand over a recently cleaned surface to see if any residual dirt remains

whorl

a circular arrangement

whorled

having whorls, i.e., coiled and spiral shapes

whorls

a pattern of spirals or concentric circles. A fingerprint is an example.

wicks

draws off (liquid) by capillary action

wide receiver's number

Punters are typically assigned a uniform with a number between 1 and 19, while wide receivers typically get a number in the 80s, though the NCAA has no hard and fast rules in this regard.

widow's peak

a hairline that dips down to a V-shaped point in front when the hair is pulled back; a hairline that comes to a point in the center of the forehead

Wien

the German name for Vienna, capital of Austria

Wiener, Reimann, Frege, Green

Norbert Wiener (1894-1964) was an American mathematician. Georg Friedrich Bernhard Riemann (1826-1866) was a German mathematician. Friedrich Ludwig Gottlob Frege (1848-1925) was a German mathematician and logician. Green is probably George Green (1793-1841), English mathematician and physicist.

wienerman

hot-dog salesman

Wiesbaden

a city of Germany above 25 miles west of Frankfurt (Main)

wig-and-jerkin

A jerkin is a close-fitting men's jacket. With the wig, this is the costume of the early Modern warrior.

wigless-head

Tony is carrying his auburn wig and red leather coat in a shopping bag.

Wilander

Mats Wilander (born 1964) was a Swedish tennis player with seven Grand Slam titles.

Wild Turkey

Bourbon.; a popular bourbon whiskey

wildly carbuncular wife

This is a reference to Nancy Witcher Astor, Viscountess Astor (1879-1964), wife of Waldorf Astor, 2nd Viscount Astor (the quote has also been attributed to Bessie Braddock )

wildly expensive hdcover

It's a real book and the hardcover goes for $105.85. It has been issued in softcover for $29. The publication information is either wrong or varies.

Wilmington DE

a city 30 miles southwest of Philadelphia

wimple

a cloth that goes over the head, frames the face, and is tucked under the chin, worn by nuns

wimples

the head coverings that nuns wear

Winchester

a city in Massachusetts about 8.5 miles northwest of Boston

Winchester double-aughts

Winchester 00 shotguns file shells with 7-9 pellets of nominal diameter of 0.33" (8.4 mm).

windfall

sudden or unexpected monetary gain

winged

shot in the arm

Winnipeg

the capital of Canadian province of Manitoba

winsome

charming; attractive and engaging due to a childlike nature

A wonk is "a person who studies a subject or issue in an excessively assiduous and thorough manner" ( Random House Unabridged Dictionary ).

woodie

work-study

receiving funding from the university in exchange for work rendered to the university

World's highest-calorie food except...

In fact, the pili nut has a slightly higher caloric content than the macadamia, and the pecan runs a very close third.

worsted

Look at the initials of the capitalized words.

wraith

another word for "ghost"

wraithlike

A wraith is a type of ghost.

wrench in the ointment

a mixup of "monkey wrench in the works" and "fly in the ointment," both meaning ruining someone's original plans

wrought-iron

iron in nearly carbon-free form, making it readily forged

wunderkind

German: child prodigy

Wurlitzer

the Rudolf Wurlitzer Company, a producer of organs

Wyclif and 14th-century langue-d'oc French

John Wyclif was a 14th century English theologian. He made the first translation of the Bible into English, thus his importance to etymology in general. Langue d'oc is another name for the Occitan language. The OED actually dates the word's (acceptance) earliest usage to 1596 by Shakespeare in The Merchant of Venice .

WYYY

actually a radio station in Syracuse, New York

xanthodantic

misspelling of xanthodontic, which means yellow-toothed

xerophagy

eating of bread and water only

Xerox

Why is PW like Xerox? Xerox let apple employees see their GUI in the 70s. Some say they could be as rich as apple if they hadn't. Because they failed to be the ones to bring their new GUI to the market, they don't have the eco/social damages of major computer chip manufacture companies. Compare John McEnroe and Vitas Gerulaitis developing their games at PW.

Xing

presumably a synonym for copulating with someone

XL

extra-large

XSive

excessive

y-axis

the vertical axis

Y.C.A.

Youth Corrections Act

Y.T.M.P.

Year of the Tucks Medicated Pad

yagé's harmaline

Yagé is the native name for banisteria . Harmaline is the active ingredient.

Yahtzee

a popular parlor game played with dice

Yalie

Yale student

Yankee Conference

Ironically, in 1997 (a year after Infinite Jest was published), Boston University dropped its football program.

YardGuard

a brand name of insect repellent

Yarmouth sail

a type of boat sail, seen here

yarmulke

the Yiddish word for the skullcap that observant Jewish men wear; a small round cap worn by Jewish men

Year of the Depend Adult Undergarment

Which is to say, as of 2009

Yellow-Brick-Road stutter-skip

a reference to the iconic 1939 film of "The Wizard of Oz", and specifically to the skip-dance performed by Judy Garland (Dorothy), Ray Bolger (Scarecrow), Jack Haley (Tin Woodman), and Bert Lahr (Cowardly Lion) while singing "We're Off To See the Wizard" (although the Tin Woodman's voice is actually that of Buddy Ebsen, who was replaced by Haley after filming and recording was partially completed)

Yevtuschenko's Field Guide to Clinical States

This book does not exist. The famous famous person with the name Yevtuschenko ( sic ) is Yevgeny Aleksandrovich Yevtushenko (born 1933), Russian poet most famous for his composition Babi Yar, about the mass murder of 35,000 Jews by the Nazis at this location in Ukraine during World War II.

Yevtushenko

not the aforementioned Russian poet

Yirrell Beach bridge in Point Shirley

these are references to Winthrop, a coastal town just northeast of Boston and separated from Logan Airport by a narrow inlet of Boston Harbor. Interestingly, Sylvia Plath's family lived for a time in the Point Shirley section of Winthrop and in 1960 she wrote a poem titled "Point Shirley."

yogic full lotus

the cross-legged sitting position

your six

your back, the area behind you (as if, like points on a clock, 12 represents straight ahead, and 3 and 9, right and left, respectively)

yrstruly

yours truly

Yukon

a territory of northwest Canada that borders Alaska's western border

Yushityu

literally appears to be: "You shit, you"

yutzes

plural of the Yiddish word "yutz" meaning fool (See Wikipedia )

YYY tapes

apparently recordings of radio-station WYYY broadcasts

z coordinate

Presumably, the measurement of depth; though the z axis usually refers to height

zaftig

a Yiddish word meaning, roughly, "voluptuous"

Zanesville OH

a town 55 miles east of Columbus

zealotry

fanaticism

Zegna

a clothing company founded by Ermenegildo Zegna

Zen

referring to Buddhism ultimately, although here it applies more to perfection or transcendence

ziggurats

an ancient type of Mesopotamian temple tower

Zippo

a brand of lighter made in Bradford PA

zirconium

a transition metal element, atomic number 40, symbol Zr

zither

A harp-like instrument, hand-held, associated with angels.; a string instrument showcased here

zithery

provoking the sound of the zither, a stringed instrument

Zog

i.e., ZOG, for Zionist Occupation Government, the acronym coined by American neo-Nazi Eric Thomson

Zoltan

Zoltán was a 10th century ruler of Hungary.; actually a Hungarian name, which means "ruler"

zygomatics

the zygomatic bones of the face; arches on the outer borders of the eyes

à clef

French for "by key," the term is usually given as roman à clef, i.e., a novel for which one needs a key to understand.

Æolic

an ancient Greek dialect spoken between 800 and 300 BC

çoncupiscence

Strong sexual desire

éclat

great brilliance or conspicuous success

élan

enthusiastic vigor or liveliness

étagère

a stand with a series of open shelves

Ø's

This could refer to all the zeros in the presumably large number of amps in the warning signs, but it may also refer (in plural) to the internationally recognized graphic prohibition sign, i.e., the No symbol, although the graphic incorporates a red circle with a backslash (from top left to bottom right, rather than bottom left to top right), as for the zero symbol. The numerical symbol incorporates the forward slash to distinguish it from the capital letter O. Also a Scandinavian vowel letter.

Überad

a super advertisement, using the German über ("super") as a prefix

Übermensch

German for "superhuman"

ς

the Greek letter sigma as it appears in lower case at the ends of words
